QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EVALUATION OF TENDERS FOR COMPUTER CONSUMABLES

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Administrative Services to his statement on the 7.30 Report that, after an internal inquiry, his Department had concluded that the method of evaluation of computer consumables could have been done better. I ask the Minister: will he table this cover-up report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I will not. In doing so, I will be quite different from Senator Parer who, a few weeks ago, selectively leaked documents which can only be termed commercial-in-confidence-much to his own personal gratification at the time but much, I think, to the chagrin of the people involved in the process.

ANSWER.PARA: I am accused by Senator Parer of a cover-up. In order to put the matter straight, I think I should give the Senate information on this matter. It might take me an extra couple of minutes, but, in order to ensure that we do not go on wild-goose chases this afternoon, it is important for the Senate to understand what has been involved. The policy objectives that I have pursued in contracts have been essentially threefold: first, to ensure the best value for government; secondly, to ensure a fair tendering process; and, thirdly, to ensure that our policy of purchase Australia is given teeth.

In this particular case, the cheapest tenders were not, in all cases, accepted. This was the result of the methodology used; this was the basket approach that was adopted. The average price of four products was assessed without weighting being given to items likely to be procured in greater volumes. In fact, in Nashua's case-the case that got some publicity-one of its products which failed to get on the contract was in fact 35 per cent cheaper than another supplier's successful product. By any measure, that was a sign that the taxpayer was not getting the best value for money and the best price.

I should also indicate that, despite the misinformation at the time, what we are talking about here is not a contract; we are talking about a standing offer. A government purchasing officer can choose to buy from any of the suppliers on the panel, but there is no guarantee that inclusion on the panel will result in a sale. That was a deliberate piece of misinformation that was perpetrated by the Opposition.

As I have said, price was a factor. I have also said that the Government has a purchase Australia policy. It was not taken into account in assessing tenderers. Purchase Australia does not require Australian companies to be included on supply panels, but it does require suppliers to give every consideration to Australian suppliers, especially those like Nashua, which is a long term government supplier and, I must say, of products of high quality. In fact, I am informed that one of the products it was tendering was nominated for Australian quality awards for two years in succession.

I suppose that my sins in this area are that I committed the sin of supporting Australian industry and I also committed the sin of wanting the best value for money goods on the panel, in line with government purchasing policy.

As I have said, there was some publicity at the time. I must make it clear that at all times it was clear that Nashua's original bid in relation to the two particular diskettes would have been successful if selection had been based on value for money of various items, especially high volume items, as opposed to the basket approach.

It has to be understood also in this context that suppliers can and do change their prices after these standing offers are issued. This is specifically provided for in the tendering document. I am advised that Nashua, as a previous supplier, had often reduced its prices in favour of the Commonwealth during previous contracts, as have other suppliers. I am advised that such price reductions are proper.

The Opposition has worked from a couple of selectively leaked documents. It is typical of the approach it has taken; it is typical of the approach that the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, is showing in this area. It is noteworthy that it has opposed consistently the purchase Australia campaign. It has opposed our meet-the-buyer fairs, and now it is opposing moves to improve government tendering.

We have seen Senator Parer raving on the issue. Is he asking us to believe that, had he been in the same position, he would not have acted to improve the system-he would have let the tendering system be compromised? Are we being asked to accept that he would have ignored clear problems in the tendering process? Are we also being asked to accept that he would have ignored reasonable representations from local business, which has raised this matter with a number of people? I think it is appropriate that Senator Parer may not get a chance at this job.

Senator Parer asks about the report. I am not inclined to release the report. Senator Parer irresponsibly brought commercial-in-confidence information into the public domain. Senior officers of my Department came to see me after reviewing the information and themselves indicated that there should be further investigation. I must say that the Secretary to the Department thought that there ought to be a review of the tendering process generally, including a review of this tender as one example of where concerns had been raised. Without my involvement, he chose a review team, and that review was undertaken. The team reported to the Secretary in relation to the tender.

Let me itemise a number of points that that review team made. It stated that planning for the process was inadequate and that market knowledge was partially deficient. It also said that the approach to specifications was sound-that is accepted as well; that the tendering process would have benefited from a post-tender negotiation; that the methodology was not sufficiently disclosed to the tenderers; that the evaluation could have been better done; and that the Australia-New Zealand supply policy had no material effect on the process.

Also importantly, the review team reported to the Secretary that, although these problems had occurred, it did not believe that the value of correcting the deficiencies warranted cancelling the contract. The Secretary and other officers considered this advice and, on their own assessment, advised me that leaving the matter as it was, taking the `do nothing' option, was inappropriate. I met with the Secretary and other senior officers yesterday. I was informed of the results of the review and of their own consideration of the issues and was advised, both in writing and verbally, that I should act and not let the status quo continue.

Consequent upon that and after considering the options available, as assessed and as given to me by my Department, I was advised to put Nashua on the panel as well as several other suppliers disadvantaged by the methodology of the tendering process. Those suppliers will go on for the products for which they are price competitive. I accepted that advice after balancing both equity and cost arguments.

In conclusion, as the responsible Minister in this area, I have to ensure that the process is fair and effective. I was concerned that there had been no post-tender negotiations with Nashua and others, although one supplier was given a second chance and was subsequently put on the panel after the close of tender. The Secretary to the Department has advised me that the review team will continue to review the tendering processes to ensure that similar problems do not occur in the future. I agree with that decision as well.

Our aim as a government is to encourage world class, internationally competitive Australian industry. It is imperative that we use selection criteria that do not exclude competitive local suppliers on arbitrary grounds. What we are doing is something that the Opposition has consistently opposed: we are giving teeth to our policy of encouraging Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: if the cover-up report clears him, as he claims in the media and in this chamber, what has he to hide by not tabling it?

—I would have thought that Senator Parer might have had a bit more nous than to ask this question, given the revelations of recent days. Having asked the question, I would have thought that he would have had more nous than to ask a supplementary question. I have already made it clear that his irresponsibility brought into the public domain commercial-in-confidence information. I have given a full answer to this question and I do not think that there is anything that I can add to it.
—Table the report.
—I will not table the report. There is already too much commercial-in-confidence information in the public domain because of Senator Parer's irresponsible actions.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support.
—When is he going to resign?
—What was the outcome of recent discussions with employers and unions concerning the Government's waterfront reform program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the flu, so I ask honourable senators to bear with me; I am not my usual sparkling self. Nineteen hours of inhaling the Prime Minister's cigar smoke has destroyed all my antibodies. In answer to the question, last week negotiations on waterfront reform were held with the parties involved. An agreement was reached which provides a certain wages outcome for the remainder of the reform process-something which the employers are rather pleased about. Captain Richard Setchell described the increases as realistic.

ANSWER.PARA: At the same time we succeeded in overcoming what I publicly described last year as a structural weakness in the process. Whilst incentives had been built in for those workers leaving the industry, on an enterprise by enterprise basis, no consideration had been given in the original process to providing incentives enterprise by enterprise for the workers who were remaining and working under the new conditions.

As a result of the crisis caused by the national wage case decision, we took the opportunity of negotiating with the unions-and it was a difficult negotiation-to overcome that structural weakness. For the first time in the process, we now have an agreement whereby none of these award payments will be made unless the agreements are in place in that particular enterprise. That involves the first increase of 2 per cent being paid in July and the subsequent increases being paid in January and July next year, which will carry it through to the end of the reform process. They will only be paid conditional upon the actual productivity provided by those enterprise agreements being put in place.

In response to the non-stop interjections from those opposite about resignation-not that this will be any news-I ask them to at least get the date right. I know that they are all running on John Sharp's statement that the deadline was 6 May. I said earlier that John Sharp is distinguished by not yet having issued a public statement-and his record, I can demonstrate, is impeccable-that has not been factually wrong. He is continually talking about 6 May. The deadline that I set myself was 4 April of this year. Laurie Oakes got the date right in the Sunday program and even that failed to impact on the understanding of the shadow Minister for shipping and waterfront reform. The date of 4 April came and went without a blink from the Opposition. The date was not 6 May; it was 4 April. Mr Sharp is not very sharp at all.

I said last year-and it remains the case-that enterprise agreements are the fundamental plank upon which the Government's program of waterfront reform rests, that is, breaking down the current system of a national pool of labour to that which is employed enterprise by enterprise. It was essential, despite the idiot industry commission assertions of Mr Sharp, that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission be involved in this process, despite his assertions that it had nothing to do with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I submit that it is not parliamentary for a senator to call a member of the other place an idiot or to say that he is making idiot industry commission assertions. It is unparliamentary to say that he is an idiot. I ask that you require the Minister to withdraw that assertion which defames Mr Sharp, who is in the other place.
—Order! He did not call Mr Sharp an idiot; he said `idiotic assertions' and that is not unparliamentary.

—I would have withdrawn if I had had to; my resistance is low today. Mr President, despite those assertions, the Industrial Relations Commission was an absolutely essential part in the process in that the agreements-if they were to be implemented and given force, rather than simply being framed and hung on the wall-had to be ratified in the Commission under the award. The difficulty was that there was no recognition of the enterprise agreements in any of the 20 existing awards in the industry, and that had to be overcome.

ANSWER.PARA: The force of what I said last year was that the enterprise agreements had to be implemented and the award had to be restructured to give force to this implementation. I must say that this is no news; I said it publicly on a number of occasions at the time. An interim award writing in these new conditions was successfully negotiated in July last year. On 21 December last year, the National Terminals (Australia) Ltd agreement was ratified in the Industrial Relations Commission under the new provisions of the award that were necessary to be put in place to give effect and force to the implementation. In fact, the deadline was met, as I said at the time, on 21 December last year. In conclusion, if the Opposition wants to continue to call for this resignation, at least it should get the date right: it was 4 April; not 6 May.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: COAL-FIRED POWER STATION IN WESTERN AUSTRALIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. No doubt the Minister is aware that the Western Australian Government has announced that it will proceed with the building of the new coal-fired power station at Collie in Western Australia (WA). Is the Minister also aware that the Western Australian Environmental Protection Authority (EPA), in assessing the State Energy Commission of Western Australia's proposal for a 600-megawatt coal-fired power station, described it as `one of the least preferable options' from an environmental viewpoint and recommended that conservation and efficiency improvements, use of renewable energy sources, or use of gas-including combined cycle-turbines be adopted before a coal-fired power station? In view of the Commonwealth Government's decision to adopt the target of a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2005, and the fact that the power station is to be built by Transfield Mitsubishi, is the Government prepared to use its constitutional powers over foreign investments to ensure that a decision by the Western Australian Government does not overturn Commonwealth efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions?
—I have been overseas for the last couple of weeks and--
—We noticed.

—I am glad that the honourable senator missed me. I was not aware that the Collie power station announcement had been made. I cannot say that I have been able to catch up with that, but I will endeavour to try. I was asked whether foreign investment powers could be used. That is a question that would have to be directed to the Treasurer or his representative in this place, Senator Button. Clearly, it would be up to the Minister for the Environment, if she were so inclined, to refer the matter to the Treasurer after an environmental investigation. I am not sure what Mrs Kelly's attitude to that is; but I shall endeavour to find out and try to inform the honourable senator at the end of Question Time today or tomorrow.

—I ask a supplementary question. It must be rather embarrassing, in view of Mr Hawke's recently launched energy guide-which the WA Government has obviously not taken into account-and the fact that the EPA and conservation groups believe that no new power station is necessary at all. What evidence is there of cooperation between the Federal and State governments on greenhouse gas emissions? Can the Minister give any concrete examples of cooperation between the States?

—What was conceded in the question in the first place was a program to announce something happening by the year 2005. Clearly, all the States and their energy Ministers, plus the Federal governments over the next 15 years, will be working to achieve it. I doubt very much if an announcement made very recently for a 15-year program can now be held up to investigation to see the progress; that will take some time. The announcement that was made about the program was a serious one. The Federal Government is absolutely serious about its implementation-so are the States-but we have to give this some time to achieve results.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to a statement made several days ago by Paul Leventhal, President of the Nuclear Control Center in Washington, that Iraq has slightly less than 50 pounds of highly enriched uranium that could be fashioned into a Nagasaki-sized bomb by a fairly competent team in about one year. How much highly enriched uranium did Iraq have before the outbreak of the Middle East war? How much does Iraq now have? Is Iraq a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT)? From which country or countries did Iraq acquire this uranium? Is that country or those countries signatories to the NPT? Has Australia supplied uranium to that country or those countries? Could any Australian uranium have found its way to Iraq? Could there be any Australian uranium among that which Iraq still possesses?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To our knowledge, Iraq had about 24 kilograms of fresh highly enriched uranium fuel before the outbreak of the Gulf war, all of which was and is subject to International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) safeguards. Under its NPT safeguards agreement with the IAEA, Iraq has to account for the same amount of nuclear materials as it did before the war. The location and condition of that material will be subject to a special IAEA inspection in conjunction with the United Nations (UN) Special Commission on Iraq in the next week or so.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the third question as to whether Iraq is a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, yes, it is. Regarding the question of from which countries Iraq acquired its uranium, the answer is France and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR). As to their status in relation to the NPT, France is not a party, but the USSR is. As to the final question regarding Australian uranium, Iraq is not an approved destination for Australian uranium exports and no nuclear safeguards agreement exists between Iraq and Australia. Under the stringent safeguards arrangements applying to Australian uranium exports, no Australian obligated nuclear material is in Iraq or could have found its way to Iraq.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. In view of the great concern which has been expressed about Iraq still possessing that uranium and the possibility that it could manufacture a nuclear weapon with that uranium, what confidence can we have in the Non-Proliferation Treaty and in the IAEA safeguards agreements?

—It is simply a matter of confidence in the particular context of the UN special commission on Iraq which has now been set up, the chemical dimension of which will be headed by a very senior and highly regarded Australian. Were it just those provisions applying in the abstract without the enforcement mechanism of the UN special commission, endorsed and set up under the peace treaty arrangements, maybe one's degree of confidence would be a little less, but the fact that the IAEA safeguard exercise is being conducted under those auspices does give us some good grounds for confidence.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer the Minister to the ongoing political violence in South Africa and the deadline of 9 May set by the African National Congress requiring the South African Government to stem such violence, failing which the ANC would consider withdrawing from negotiations. What is the Minister's assessment of the current situation in South Africa and the prospects for further progress towards dismantling the apartheid system?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has to be said that the current period in South Africa is really one of crucial importance in that that country is facing perhaps the most serious crises to threaten the reform process to date. In the first place let me comment on the progress that has been made in relation to the surmounting of the so-called obstacles to further negotiation. It is a matter for disappointment and concern that the South African Government has failed to meet in full the commitments that had been agreed upon with the African National Congress for conclusion by 30 April in relation to the release of political prisoners and the clearing of the way for the return of exiles.

ANSWER.PARA: So far as prisoners are concerned, according to the South African Government itself on 30 April, 933 prisoners had been released or were in the process of being released. On the same day the Human Rights Commission, which is a very well respected South African non-government organisation, estimated that just over 900 identified political prisoners were still in detention. Again, on 30 April the government announced that indemnity had been granted to 4,530 exiles out of a total of 5,872 applications dealt with so far. The total number of exiles is still unclear, with figures varying between 20,000 and 40,000, not all of whom would be expected to return but clearly a large number of applicants do remain.

So far as the remaining obstacles in addition to those are concerned, it was promised that there would be a review and repeal of repressive security legislation. In that respect, on 2 May-just a few days ago-President de Klerk did foreshadow significant amendments to the Internal Security Act. Although the extent of changes to be made remains unclear, it may well be reasonable to assume that here, and with the prisoners and exiles matters, the remaining issues will be capable of being resolved in the next few weeks.

Similarly, as to the remaining preliminary issue, that is, the repeal of the three legislative pillars of apartheid so called-the Group Areas Act, the Lands Act and the Population Registration Act-although a number of questions have arisen about the details of some of that legislation, including in particular the Lands Act, again I do not think there is any room for great pessimism at this stage. It is likely, in other words, that this legislation will be through the parliament, as promised, by the end of this legislative session. So on these issues the record is mixed; not terribly happy so far as the 30 April deadline is concerned, but not a cause for enormous alarm, either.

Where there is ground for very serious concern is the continued high level of political violence: 771 people have been killed as a result of political violence so far this year, with over 100 killed in the past week alone. On 5 April the ANC issued an open letter urging the South African Government to meet, by 9 May, various demands regarding political violence, failing which it would consider withdrawing from negotiations. This cannot be regarded as an empty threat and the figures I have quoted indicate the tragic dimensions of the situation that currently exists.

Clearly no side in this is blameless but I must record the Australian Government's particular concern about persistent reports of the complicity of police and other security forces in acts of violence. It is essential that the South African Government demonstrate a genuine commitment toward ending political violence. While all parties must be prepared to take immediate steps toward controlling violence and restoring public confidence in the administration of law and order, the South African Government has a particular responsibility for ensuring the security of its citizens.

The Australian Government has over recent months consistently welcomed progress made toward dismantling the apartheid system, and I am very pleased to note that President de Klerk has acknowledged the constructive approach we have taken. But he and his colleagues must also be aware that the support of governments such as our own for the reform process cannot be taken for granted in the absence of concrete and decisive action towards stemming the tragic violence now taking place, and the creation of the necessary political conditions so that a peaceful negotiated settlement to South Africa's political problems can be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question: in view of the progress being made, can the Minister outline whether the anticipated meeting of the Commonwealth foreign Ministers could discuss these recent developments?

—It is presently anticipated that that meeting will take place in early July, by which time we should certainly know how the violence issue has been resolved and whether in fact it has led to a breakdown in negotiations, and by which time we should also know the outcome in terms of the achievement of those various criteria for further progress that the Commonwealth foreign Ministers had previously identified. An earlier opportunity for Commonwealth discussion of these issues will be in fact the high level meeting of heads of government which will look at Commonwealth reform issues in London in the first or second week of June.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question, which also refers to the Bolkus tender cover-up, to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to his letter of 4 March 1991 to his Department in which he directed his Department to reinstate Nashua Australia Pty Ltd on contract PC03 for computer consumables following a meeting between the company and the Minister. I ask the Minister: who arranged the meeting between Nashua and himself? Who attended the meeting? Were representations made orally, in writing, or both? What was the basis of those representations? What commitment did the Minister give to Nashua?
—I missed part of Senator Tambling's question, but I can assure him that there was not a meeting between Nashua and me. We did get representations but there was no meeting between Nashua and me.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am afraid that the Minister obviously did miss the early part of my question, in which I asked him very directly: who arranged the meeting between Nashua and himself; who attended the meeting; were the representations made in writing; what was the basis of those representations; and what commitment did the Minister give to Nashua? In light of the Minister's answer, which seeks totally to avoid the issue, why is he seeking to duck the matter?

—It is a case of pure and simple logic: if there is no meeting, obviously no-one has arranged it. I would have thought that answered Senator Tambling's first question. I did not meet with Nashua. Representations were made in writing. I met with officers of my Department on this matter, and they were in fact the only people with whom I have met to discuss this matter. Why do we not get that right? Senator Tambling is premature in coming forward to claim a cover-up. He should listen to the answer. As they say overseas, read my lips: there was no meeting.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of media reports last month which suggested that Australians could be giving tax free donations to the Irish Republican Army through a Sydney based charity? Can the Minister advise whether the Australian Taxation Office has investigated these allegations? Can the Minister assure the Senate and current and potential donors to the fund that that is not the case?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course I am aware of some of these reports; they got headlines. That is undoubtedly what they were designed to get-headlines. Every now and again at an Estimates committee meeting some little snippet comes out and a press release is made by an Opposition member of the committee which gets a headline. Senator Short, whose allegations have been before a Senate Estimates committee, in fact generated a number of newspaper articles. He has since publicly apologised to the relevant charity. The charity in question is the Australian-Ireland Fund.

ANSWER.PARA: The objects of the Australian-Ireland Fund were read into Hansard in June 1989 when the legislation concerning the fund's inclusion in the gift provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act was debated in this chamber. The trust deed which establishes the fund indicates that the purposes of the fund are to promote peace and harmony and to improve the general living conditions, welfare and quality of life of people living in Ireland and Northern Ireland-exemplary objectives, one might have thought. The provision of aid to the Irish Republican Army does not come within any of these purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Australia-Britain, Australia-America and Australia-China. Why aren't they on the list?

—Senator Patterson is engaged in some verbal guerilla warfare on the other side of the chamber which I cannot hear, and I am not taking any notice of it anyway. The provisions of the trust deed are totally inconsistent with the provision of aid to the Irish Republican Army.

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of Senator Short's subsequent apology to the fund, the Australian Taxation Office has advised the Government that it does not consider it necessary to investigate the fund's activities, but that process was set in train. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. I remind the Minister of the promise he made on 6 May last year-which was reported fairly widely-that he would resign within 12 months if he had not completed the award restructuring process and had several enterprise agreements negotiated. Given that award restructuring is nowhere near completed and that only one enterprise agreement has been negotiated-and that one is with the Government's own stevedoring company-it is obvious that the Minister has failed in delivering that promise. Will the Minister do the honourable thing and keep his promise to the Australian people and resign; or will he continue the disgraceful tradition of this Labor Government and break a promise that he never intended to keep?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have in fact already answered this question in answering a question from Senator Faulkner. I am pleased at the encouraging sign of personal advancement from Senator Campbell: at least the question was not about Western Australia Inc. I am glad he has broadened his horizons somewhat in that respect.

ANSWER.PARA: Last year in an interview that I gave in May I did identify, as I have already said, that the fundamental plank of the Government's reform program was to secure enterprise agreements, enterprise by enterprise, in ports around Australia in order to deliver the much needed reform on the Australian waterfront. Essential to that process was the implementation of those agreements. As I have said in the Parliament many times before, there is not much point getting an agreement if it cannot be implemented in the workplace. To give legal force to those agreements, the in-principle agreement provided for those enterprise agreements to be ratified in the Industrial Relations Commission-despite the nonsense from Mr Sharp last year when he said that there was no mention of the Industrial Relations Commission anywhere in the process. In fact, it is an absolutely essential part of it.

Last year when I gave that interview I discussed the question of award restructuring because the 20 awards that existed at that time did not have any provision for the ratification of enterprise agreements as such a creature had never existed before. Therefore, there had to be a restructuring of the awards so that they could be ratified in the Commission. Because of the difficulty with human resources which occurred last year-and all this has been said in the Senate before-it was clear that it would be difficult to advance simultaneously the negotiations on enterprise agreements whilst negotiating the award.

But at the same time I went to Bill Kelty with this problem-the reason I went to him was that it was essentially a union problem-and I said, `Well, we've got a difficulty'. The original thought in my mind when I went to Bill Kelty was that perhaps the Australian Council of Trade Unions could provide additional human resources to carry out the award restructuring component of the reform process whilst the unions themselves got on with what they had to do, which was the enterprise agreements.

His response was to come up with a better idea-and all of this is contained in the Senate Hansard-of an interim award which specifically corrected the award restructuring problem and gave the opportunity for these agreements to be ratified in the Commission. That award got up as a consent agreement with the employers in July last year-and, again, that was advised publicly to the Senate then. The deadline that I had set myself in May was met-as I have also said before publicly-on 21 December last year when the National Terminals agreement was ratified under the new award provisions in the Industrial Relations Commission.

All of this fuss seems to have been made since the interview that I did on the Sunday program. Nothing that I said on the Sunday program was new; it had all been said before. The only conclusion I can draw from all of this is that news has not actually happened until it is reported on the Sunday program. Perhaps that is the case.

That deadline was met and I might add-in order to correct once again the mistake which has just been perpetuated by the honourable senator opposite-that the deadline was in fact 4 April this year, which came and went without any response from the Opposition, not 6 May. But the target that I set myself was in fact achieved on 21 December last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the Minister said, we have heard it all before and it is in the Hansard. But the Australian people are interested to know why he broke his promise. They do not want excuses. How can a number of enterprise agreements be considered to be in place when only one is in place with the Government's own stevedoring company? Whether it is 4 April, 6 May or 7 May, why has the Minister not resigned?

—Senator Campbell has got it wrong again. I did not say a number of enterprise agreements. I specifically said one major enterprise agreement in the ports of Sydney and Melbourne. I said to Paul Lyneham at the time- he did not subsequently publish the interview, but if the tapes still exist the words will be on them-that it was `a modest'--
—There have been a number of agreements since May 1990.

—Yes, there are a number of enterprise agreements. There are National Terminals enterprise agreements for the ports of both Sydney and Melbourne. That is two enterprise agreements. It is very difficult in Question Time to have to go back and explain to an honourable senator, who has had a very latter day interest in this entire process-I think it is the only question he has ever asked on it-that these agreements are specific not just to the companies concerned but to the ports in which they are negotiated. Therefore, a National Terminals (Australia) Ltd agreement for the Port of Sydney is one agreement and a National Terminals agreement for the port of Melbourne is a second agreement.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the Minister provide the Senate with an estimate of the amount of wheat sales Australia has lost due to targeting of our customers by the United States? Has the Minister any figures relating to wheat sales lost because of the competition from the European Economic Community (EEC)? What are the short term prospects for Australia's wheat sales, having regard to the above questions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first question about targeting of our customers by the United States, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has estimated that the price discrimination effect of the United States export enhancement program (EEP) has cost Australian wheat growers between $A127m and $A174m in 1990-91 in terms of forgone income. Subsidies up to $US50 per tonne have been made in recent months under this program. In addition to this cost, Australian growers' export returns have been further eroded by the general global price depressing effect of the United States export enhancement program. This effect is more difficult to quantify but, clearly, it substantially increases the overall cost of the export enhancement program to the Australian wheat industry. For example, prices in some subsidised markets have recently been discounted to as low as $US65 to $US70 per tonne.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of competition from the European Economic Community, the impact of the EEC's export subsidies on export restitutions is more difficult to quantify than the impact of the export enhancement program, because the European Community export restitutions is just one element of a complex and interrelated support structure of the European common agricultural policy (CAP). The other major elements of the CAP are domestic intervention prices and import barriers. Separating and quantifying the specific impacts of these three elements is not easy. However, given that the European Community's export restitutions are currently prevailing at some $US150 per tonne, European Community export subsidisation is clearly having a substantial depressing effect on world prices and, therefore, the returns to Australian wheat growers.

The last question concerned the short term prospects. As the world price for wheat is bid down in the aggressive trade war between the United States and the European Community and as Australian markets are depressed by subsidies, the Australian wheat industry is, of course, forced to accept lower prices in order to deliver tonnages into these markets. The impact of this on grower returns is only too obvious. The Australian Wheat Board's estimated pool return for 1990-91 has fallen to $A115 per tonne, which will generate significant hardship to many in the Australian wheat industry. Against this background, the Government has announced an extension of the Government guarantee of Australian Wheat Board borrowings by around $100m for this season. In addition, the Government has protested strongly to both the United States and the European Community about the current aggressive level of export subsidisation.

As the Senate will know, a joint parliamentary delegation led by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Dr Blewett, recently visited Washington to register strongly Australia's concern at the EEP and to highlight its impact on the Australian wheat industry. The Australian Government will continue to register our strong objections to both the United States and the European Community export subsidisation practices at every available opportunity and will continue to seek the winding back of subsidies and other trade distorting measures in the Uruguay Round of trade negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. In the light of donations from Mr Lang Hancock to Mr Brian Burke, will the Minister explain to the Senate the basis for the Minister's approval that Mr Burke should continue to help Mr Hancock's business interests in Romania while Mr Burke was Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See? Did the Prime Minister support the Minister's decision in this regard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Burke's involvement in a visit to Romania seeking to do business on behalf of Australia but involving Mr Lang Hancock was the subject of a full question and even fuller reply in the Estimates Committee last week. I have nothing I can really add to the answer I gave there but, for the benefit of other senators, let me summarise the gist of that response.

ANSWER.PARA: In September 1988, on the advice of my Department-which, pre-empting Senator Hill, I am happy to table as the Prime Minister will in the other place in response to this same question which he had just a few minutes ago-I agreed to Mr Burke's request that he be given a continuing role in respect of Australia's trade with eastern Europe. Mr Burke, as Premier of Western Australia, had of course had contacts with a number of eastern European countries, in particular Romania, and an ongoing role in trade matters was considered on balance to be beneficial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not political balance.

—Not on political balance. In terms of the balance of Australian national interests involved, given the particular character of the assistance that he was arguing he would be able to render, assistance which was carefully evaluated by my Department and on balance agreed to by me.

ANSWER.PARA: That visit-and he made only one such visit to eastern Europe-was made on the basis of certain conditions that I specified with some precision. It was only an approval to travel in his capacity as an official of the Australian Government. He had to give advance notice of his travel to my Department and to relevant posts to ensure effective coordination.

In addition to the visit to eastern Europe in April 1989, he made a visit to Geneva in September 1988 to meet Mr Hancock and Soviet representatives, but his visit to Romania in April 1989 was for discussions with senior Romanian Ministers. On the latter visit he was accompanied, as I told the Estimates Committee, by the Australian Ambassador to Romania, who is resident in Belgrade, and the Australian Trade Commissioner.

In 1990 when the issue came up again, I decided that in the light of developments in eastern Europe as well as the new role that David Charles, formerly of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, was playing in terms of developing and encouraging trade with that region, the arrangement involving Mr Burke was no longer required, and it was brought to an end. There was absolutely nothing secret about this arrangement. Again, as I told the Estimates Committee it was raised with my office by Mr Peacock's office in January 1990, and my understanding is that full details were then given, but Mr Peacock was unable then or is unable now to make anything of it.

As for the Prime Minister's involvement in that, I think there may have been some passing reference to him by me about my intention to respond in this particular way, but it was not a subject which was substantively discussed, as I recall, and certainly not a matter on which the Prime Minister expressed any particular view. He left it to my judgment. I table that document.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask whether the Minister's answer means that he no longer agrees with the statement of Senator Coates, with which he agreed, on 12 February:

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It in no way contradicts the expressed view of Senator Coates. My view is, as I have expressed it on a number of occasions publicly, that indiscriminate arms sales are bad. I have not opposed them because we are a country that is a net importer of defence equipment. If, by that, Senator Spindler is saying that we are making immoral every other country that sells to us, I would be interested to hear his views.

ANSWER.PARA: The real crunch and the real nub of the issue, as was especially highlighted by the Gulf war, is that the indiscriminate sale of large capital equipment items, et cetera, can destabilise a region and, on that particular basis, it tends to fit the description that Senator Coates gave it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Now that Mr Burke's own evidence shows that he knowingly avoided paying tax on money held in accounts under his control, and continued to hold and direct Australian Labor Party campaign funds while Ambassador, will the Minister now immediately sack the Ambassador to Ireland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No. The question of tax liability is one for determination by the Commissioner of Taxation and it is begging a number of questions as to whether there was indeed--
—Order!

—It is begging a number of questions-when I can get a word in-as to what Mr Burke's state of mind was about tax liability to make the assertion, as Senator Knowles did, that he knowingly avoided the payment of tax on those funds. In fact, as I recall it, the evidence is to the contrary in so far as it has been articulated by Mr Burke.

ANSWER.PARA: This is obviously one of those numerous matters which are appropriately left for resolution by the Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters. In that respect, I have to say that I endorse completely what Senator Hill said in this respect on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on the afternoon of 29 April when, referring to Mr Burke's still acting in an allegedly political manner while Ambassador to Ireland, he said:
But these are the issues that will be examined no doubt in depth and when there's a finding we would respond to them further.
These are questions before the Royal Commission. They will be the questions for evidence and assessment before the Royal Commission and no doubt we will respond accordingly.

That was an admirably balanced judgment by Senator Hill. This is a statement offered by Senator Hill in response to questioning of him on the afternoon of 29 April when the newspapers were full that morning of a number of accounts, stemming apparently from Mr Burke himself, that he was, in fact, engaged in some form of activity in relation to the leader's account while he was Ambassador to Ireland. So it was in response to that very question that Senator Hill gave the answer that he did.

Of course, I am aware that there is some evidence stemming now from Mr Burke himself when before the Commission of some degree of activity involving the operation of a leader's account or fund perhaps for the purposes of directly supporting political campaigns. The full facts of the handling of that account are not a matter for me to make judgments about. As I have said, that is for the Royal Commission. Senator Hill seems to agree with me. The question, though, of whether active political involvement, if it did occur, is appropriate--

TALK.START.PARA: —Aren't you still paying him?

—I will address the substance of the issue. I am not trying to avoid it. It is a question of characterisation of what was going on, and the full facts clearly remain to be resolved. A relevant consideration might be whether the operation of the account in question was an active political exercise or whether rather, for example, it was simply a belated endeavour to divest himself of previous responsibilities in a way that we might think unwise but nonetheless raises questions different from active political involvement. It is that kind of fact that remains to be resolved. The question, however, and let me address it-if there was active political involvement, would it be appropriate behaviour for a serving ambassador?-is one that, of course, I have had regard to.
—You know it is not, don't you?
—Mr President, this squawking parrot on the front bench is--
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—There are simply no formally applicable or codified clear-cut standards in this area. We do have the Bowen code of conduct governing public officials and we do have Public Service guidelines, neither of which are technically applicable to ambassadors but which I would regard as appropriately applicable to them. None of them, however, in any way expressly rule out the question of active political involvement by serving public servants, however senior, in any way that would be regarded as directly applicable to the kind of circumstance we are dealing with in Dublin. If anything, they endorse and give an imprimatur to an appropriately judged level of political activity by the people in question. There is certainly no absolute ruling out of it.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I do acknowledge that, while it is difficult to codify the standard of behaviour expected of officials in these circumstances, the standards applicable to an ambassador may in some circumstances differ from the standards which are appropriate to public servants and office holders generally. I have taken all of those considerations into account, and it does seem to me that certainly such activity, if it did involve active political activity by a serving ambassador, would be both imprudent and inappropriate. I am in no doubt of that. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is in no doubt of that, and has given me advice to that effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister described it as improper, I gather.

—It is a matter of judgment as to what language Senator Hill would like to use. `Improper', in Public Service parlance, extends across the whole spectrum from hanging offences to mildly admonitory offences. That is the kind of language that public servants employ. The best way of judging how seriously these sorts of things are regarded is to establish what would be regarded as an appropriate penalty.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. We frequently have problems with Ministers who want to comment on other portfolios. I wonder whether you could ask the Minister, seeing that he is trying to answer the question, whether this time he would take responsibility for the matters which are clearly in his portfolio and answer Senator Knowles's question.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I conclude by saying this: it is certainly my own view that such activity, if established-such active political involvement in the form of contributing to campaigns in a way that does not simply involve the divestment of previous responsibilities-would be, as I have said, imprudent and inappropriate. It is my Department's view that in such or similar circumstances it would have considered appropriate a reprimand and firm instruction to cease the activity in question accordingly. On that basis and on the basis of my own judgment to that effect, I have written to Mr Burke to make it quite clear that, for such remaining period as he holds the office of ambassador, he should not engage in activity of that kind.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I draw Senator Evans's attention to the fact that he said that he would act on any evidence of illegality. Now that Mr Burke has actually given that evidence, why is Senator Evans still refusing to act?

—With the utmost respect, Mr President, if Senator Knowles is unable to appreciate the difference between illegality at one end of the spectrum, impropriety of a kind justifying dismissal from office or the non-holding of an office in the middle, and other forms of imprudence or unwisdom at the other end of the scale, then she should not be occupying the seat that she is now.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the significance of the Antarctic Treaty parties' agreement reached in Madrid last week to conclude an environment protection instrument which will prohibit mining in Antarctica?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The outcome of the Madrid meeting is extremely gratifying, a very fitting culmination to the intensive diplomatic campaign which was initiated by Australia and France just two years ago. The Madrid meeting agreed to a draft legal instrument which prohibits mining in Antarctica and which establishes a comprehensive regime for the protection of the Antarctic environment. It will provide the most comprehensive environment protection possible and marks a quite major breakthrough in prohibiting mining indefinitely. The prohibition of mining has been central to the package of stringent environment protection measures which are advocated by Australia and our co-sponsors-France, Belgium and Italy.

ANSWER.PARA: The mining prohibition provisions are extremely tight. Only after 50 years could any party to the Treaty call a review conference on the instrument generally. Any amendments to the mining prohibitions emerging from such a conference would require the agreement of all current consultative parties, of which Australia is one. Thus it is the case that Australia and the other 25 current consultative parties effectively hold a veto on mining in the future. The draft negotiated in Madrid now goes back to the Antarctic Treaty governments for formal agreement. Australia expects that governments will not have difficulties in endorsing the outcome of that meeting. We are urging governments to move quickly so that parties can finalise the negotiations at the next meeting, scheduled for June in Madrid.

Finally, it was only in May 1989 that Prime Minister Hawke announced the Australian Government's decision not to sign the Minerals Convention but to seek a permanent ban on mining activity and a comprehensive environmental protection regime for Antarctica. Given the intense initial international opposition to this approach from so many powerful countries-not least the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Japan-to get to the present point in just two years represents an extraordinarily successful exercise in Australian diplomacy. I pay tribute to the dedicated efforts of the Australian team drawn from three Government departments, led by my own. Their work is of major importance not only to Australia today but to future generations of the whole international community.
