DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AND OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION POLICIES

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 7 May 1991, from Senator Durack:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to clarify its new Industrial Relations and Occupational Superannuation policies in the light of its espousal of enterprise bargaining and the rejection of the central role for the IRC.'
Senator for the State of Western Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Government to clarify its new Industrial Relations and Occupational Superannuation policies in the light of its espousal of enterprise bargaining and the rejection of the central role for the IRC.

The Opposition has brought forward this matter of urgency today because of the extraordinary degree of conflict and confusion which the Government has created as a result of its own policies relating to the industrial relations system and occupational superannuation following the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the national wage case on 16 April this year.

The degree of confusion since then has been remarkable, with quite evidently different views being pursued by different Ministers and the matter largely being taken out of the hands of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. However, before I detail to a greater extent those aspects of the matter, I would like to make it perfectly clear that, as is stated in the urgency motion, the Government's espousal of enterprise bargaining and its rejection of the central role of the Industrial Relations Commission are movements in the direction of the Opposition's policy.

The Opposition strongly supports the establishment of true, genuine enterprise bargaining in our industrial relations system on a purely voluntary basis, of course, which I do not know that Senator Cook fully understands. The fact of the matter is that in this Senate on 18 December last year there was a debate in which the Opposition put forward the details of that policy. I simply want to reiterate the fact that the Opposition regards that as the centrepiece of its industrial relation policy. It has been developed steadily over the years that we have been in opposition, but it was fully established as long ago as 1986 and there have been certain refinements to it since then.

Our policy on voluntary agreements being made at enterprise level between employer and employee, subject only to the need for minimum hourly rates and the observation of health and safety conditions, does not require further approval by the Industrial Relations Commission, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) or any group of Ministers who may be self-appointed guardians of that system-a development which now seems to be occurring.

The Opposition is certainly not here today to criticise those aspects of the Government's debate which seem to be moving-although not really very clearly-in the direction of true and genuine enterprise agreements, agreements voluntarily entered into by employer and employee governing the terms and conditions of employment in a particular enterprise. To that extent, in so far as we can give any very clear indication at all about Government policy, we would certainly welcome it.

Because of the stand that we take in relation to major reform of the industrial relations system, inevitably there is in our policy a change in the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Obviously, if our policy works fully as, indeed, we are determined it should, the role of the Industrial Relations Commission will be reduced and certainly will be a very different role from that which it has played traditionally under a centralised industrial relations system-the sort of system of which Senator Cook has been one of the most ardent advocates. It is the advocacy which he has pursued in relation to the central role of the Industrial Relations Commission that has added to the confusion which we now see.

I want to make it perfectly clear at the outset of this debate that the Opposition is not opposed in any way to the developments which seem to be occurring, in which there may be some hope that the Government itself, in reconsidering its own position, will move much closer to and, indeed, adopt the views of the Opposition on this vital subject.

However, what is of such concern and such urgency is the fact that the Government seems to be in a state of confusion, with conflicting views being expressed about the way in which it sees enterprise bargaining being brought into effect and about the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. The reason for this confusion is that the Industrial Relations Commission did not allow itself simply to be a doormat and a rubber stamp for the Government and its accord. We in the Opposition would not agree with many aspects of the Commission's decision of 16 April. But the Government, which has been strongly supporting the Industrial Relations Commission and its role, has now refused to accept what Senator Cook has constantly maintained in debate in this chamber, that is, that the umpire's decision has to be obeyed.

In so far as the Industrial Relations Commission is an umpire, the Opposition, under its industrial relations policy, strongly supports the decision of the umpire. Where we fundamentally differed from the Government in the past was our belief that the jurisdiction of that umpire should not be all pervasive and that there should be this very major role for voluntary agreements. But where there is not a voluntary agreement, where there is conflict and where the parties go to the Industrial Relations Commission, as they will be able to under our policy, the umpire's decision must be respected. Not only is the Government not respecting the umpire's decision but also it is repudiating it and proceeding with its own employees to enter into a totally different agreement from that of the umpire. It is conspiring with the ACTU in its endeavours to undermine totally the umpire in this particular case since 16 April.

Let me go back to some of the reasons for this confusion and conflict on the part of the Government on this vital matter. If one looks at the accord mark VI entered into by the Federal Government and the ACTU on 21 February 1990, one sees the pre-eminent, central role that is accorded the Industrial Relations Commission. Paragraph 3 of accord mark VI states:
Accordingly the parties have agreed that the focal point of the wage system must continue to be the National Wage Case. The National Wage Case should consider-
a number of things, including-
The principles upon which enterprise agreements would be determined.

Of course, the Government has now said that it will not accept the views of the Industrial Relations Commission on enterprise agreements, and it is proceeding to cobble together some sort of policy of its own. I hope the Minister will be able to enlighten us today about the way enterprise agreements may be determined. As far as the Government is concerned, they certainly will not be determined by any principles that the Industrial Relations Commission lays down in a national wage case, which the Government's own accord says is the way it should be done.

The accord also records that the unions have given a number of commitments to facilitate restructuring, including commitments required by the Industrial Relations Commission. It goes on to say that these commitments will be honoured by the union movement. These commitments are being totally repudiated by the union movement led by Mr Kelty and Mr Ferguson, the President. As I said, in conjunction with the Treasurer (Mr Keating), they are proceeding along a totally different route from the very accord under which the Government has said it has been operating. One of the first questions must be where the Government is going in light of the fact that it is repudiating not only the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission but also its own accord.

The attitude of Senator Cook until 16 April, or in fact until a few days after 16 April, in relation to the Government's policies on the industrial relations system-I might add that my colleague Senator Alston will deal with the subject of occupational superannuation and I propose to address myself simply to this question of the policies relating to the industrial relations system-was shown in his response during the debate on an urgency motion in the Senate on 18 December last which, on that occasion, was:

The need for the Parliament to enable employers and employees to make voluntary agreements to determine the conditions of employment in their own work place without the intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission.

Senator Cook got terribly excited about the proposition that we put forward: that anything should be done without the imprimatur of the Industrial Relations Commission. Senator Cook went so far as to say:

What this urgency motion does is a most scurrilous and unprincipled thing . . . it attacks the umpire. It says, `The umpire has no place; the umpire is out of court; it should not apply; the umpire has no standing'.

That was of course very wide of the mark in answering the Opposition's case. But the fact is that Senator Cook went to great lengths to reiterate this central role of the Industrial Relations Commission as recently as 18 December last. He went on to say:

The process of conciliation and arbitration was founded in this country in 1904 . . . It has served this country well. It is highly regarded . . . It is passing strange that the party that aspires to be the government of this country should now want to undermine the central institution which guarantees good industrial relations outcomes in this country . . .

Indeed, that is the very thing that this Government, in conjunction with the ACTU, is now doing itself in relation to the conciliation and arbitration system. The position of the Government at the moment is totally at odds with that which Senator Cook so strongly, indeed if not violently, espoused as recently as December last year.

It was not only in the Senate that Senator Cook had this to say about the Industrial Relations Commission. On the AM radio program the next morning he was interviewed by a person named David Burgess who said to him:
If you can't get agreement with the unions, what should happen to the SPC deal?
That was the debate that was going on at the time, which we all remember so well. Senator Cook replied:

It should go to the Commission, where it's intended to go now, and the Commission should arbitrate. And when the Commission makes a decision, it will be the right decision. There is an independent umpire; we support the system of arbitration in this country. We should simply, when there is a problem, step back and let it do its job.
The Government is now doing everything in its power to stop the Industrial Relations Commission doing the job which the Government itself had assigned to it.

Senator Cook made a number of other statements to a similar effect at about this time. I will not repeat them, but I simply report that he is on the record, time and time again, as having spoken in that vein about the central role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Of course, we now know about the decision which so offended the Government because it so hurt its pride. The Industrial Relations Commission had the independence, which I understood the Government thought was a good thing, but once it exercised its independence and did not rubber-stamp the Government's submission and what was said to be the application of the accord-although it is doubtful whether the accord would have allowed for this-the Government went along with the ACTU in really rejecting the system that it had supported for so long.

The President of the ACTU, Mr Ferguson, has also made remarks about the demise of the centralised system. We know clearly that Mr Kelty is the one who is leading the charge against the system as a result of the ACTU losing its case before the Commission in the national wage case.

The major changes to the role of the Industrial Relations Commission now foreseen by the Government are being espoused by the Treasurer himself, Mr Keating, who is relegating its role to a very minor one indeed. When addressing the Economic Planning Advisory Council on 19 April, he concluded with these remarks:

Within the Accord framework we intend to press ahead with the achievement of a more decentralised system of wage determination . . . It is a framework we hope the Commission may find its way to embrace for the Commission will continue to have an important role to play in providing a safety net for the lower paid and in the settlement of industrial disputes.

That is a very attenuated role. The role assigned to the Industrial Relations Commission, recognised by Senator Cook himself in an interview with Michelle Grattan reported yesterday in the Age, is a minor one compared with the role of the Government to determine within the accord the major wages policy for the nation-not the Commission. But there seems to be great confusion as to how far that will go. Will it be done entirely at the political level between Mr Keating and Mr Kelty, or whoever holds the roles as Treasurer in the Government and Secretary of the ACTU? It is certainly not a role that has been assigned to the Minister for Industrial Relations, who in recent weeks seems to have been assigned to a bit player's role in this whole exercise.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not seem to be particularly happy with the Keating role or the Kelty claim, if I may put it that way. He seems to be seeing some sort of halfway role between the traditional one of the Commission, which has been so strongly defended and supported by Senator Cook in the past but maybe not so strongly now, although that is not clear. The Prime Minister seems to be looking for a role for it, as he recognised in the waterfront agreement. We have this confusion, this conflict between a very different industrial relations system which is foreseen by the Treasurer, Mr Keating; a more traditional role which has been referred to by Senator Cook; and some sort of halfway role in the system, which seems to be that which has been referred to by the Prime Minister.

The result of all this is confusion-confusion which must be cleared up by the Government as soon as possible in such a vital area as this. Not only the waterfront but also the metal trades and the whole of the industrial relations area are confused and unable to understand what is expected of them. Then there is the Industrial Relations Commission itself, which must be in a state of total misunderstanding about the role which is expected of it. I refer finally to the Minister's remarks in the debate in December when he said, `If you do not have a wages policy, you do not have an economic policy and you cannot govern'. That applies to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an urgency motion under the signature of Senator Durack, which claims that the Government needs to clarify, to quote the words of the motion, `its new industrial relations and occupational superannuation policies'. This motion must fail on the grounds of that assertion alone. There is nothing new in what the Government is saying or in what it is doing in industrial relations. There may be confusion, as Senator Durack has said, but if there is, it is confusion for him. There is no confusion for the Government. Anyone who wants to see the thread of continuity between our position prior to the national wage case and now need only turn to the national wage case submission put on behalf of the Commonwealth. That sets out more clearly than any other document the philosophical and policy view of the Government on wages and wage fixation, and follows through many of the arguments that Senator Durack held in his speech to the Senate a moment ago as being matters of confusion.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to clear up one of the confusions that Senator Durack has mentioned. He said that there is an apparent move by the Government in the direction of Opposition policy on industrial relations. That is just not true. The Opposition policy and the Government policy on industrial relations is one of the great divides in Australian politics. It is one of those things that separates a Labor government from a conservative coalition. We are not moving to Senator Durack's policy whatever. We are moving, consistent with our mandate achieved at the last election, on the directions laid out in accord mark VI, to decentralise the centralised wage fixing system, and to do so through the agency of embracing what I will call, for the sake of making the distinction, company level bargaining rather than Senator Durack's term, in current usage by the Opposition, enterprise agreements.

One of the great distinguishing features about a Labor policy on industrial relations is regard for people who have weak bargaining power, who have little industrial muscle and who therefore cannot, by the exercise of industrial muscle, obtain outcomes on wages that are fair and reasonable. Our policy recognises that there is a rational case in many of the examples of people in this sort of situation, and they need to have access to an industrial relations commission to be able to argue why, despite their lack of industrial muscle, wage justice in their case should apply. The decision should be based on the rationality of the case.

Lest anyone jump to a conclusion that I am advocating use of industrial muscle in other areas, let me disavow that immediately by saying that we are talking here about a framework created by the accord which enables moderate wage outcomes to be achieved; which enables living standards in the broader community to be protected; which enables Australia to turn itself, in the face of our industry statement, in reducing tariff protection and exposing industry to greater international competition; and which enables Australia to become a more competitive entity. They are not things contemplated in the Opposition's industrial relations strategy. We have a wages policy and an accord with the Australian trade union movement which enables us to implement that policy.

The Opposition has a collection of theories and a list of wishes and bigotries about industrial relations that blinker its members. That is not surprising, given that the architect of Opposition policy is someone who, in his ordinary working life, has been a solicitor; who is now a politician who has not spent any time in the real life of an Australian workplace; and who paints an idealised picture of what an outcome might be. That idealised picture is meant to be a feelgood picture-let us all feel good and nice about what this lovely outcome would be-but that picture never ever explains how one moves to that fuzzy, lovey outcome from the present set of circumstances. What are the transitional steps? How does one manage them? What are the adjustments one needs to make? It is a picture that never ever explains where else in the world there is a model to which the Liberal Party in Australia aspires so that we can look at a working model and examine how it operates and test the theories and assertions about the Liberal policy against real life. There is nowhere else in the world that the Opposition can point to as a living, working example of what it means. It is an invention of its own.

The Opposition has another fatal defect; that is, it is not able to manage wages policy in this country with any degree of certainty of what the aggregate wage outcome will be, as a macro-economic management tool, for the wider economic management of Australia. It has no way of saying how, under its policy, that can be obtained and how a wages policy can work to the national good. There is no element of explanation. The inquiries as to how that is to be done are passed off while this vague image of what a new future might be is explained.

The Government's policy is a proven policy. It is a policy which enables the aggregate wage outcome to be set. In the eight years that this Government has been in office, every time we have set it in our Budget we have reached it or in fact overachieved and undershot that level of aggregate wage outcome. It is a policy which has enabled unit labour costs in this country, over the eight years of our administration, to fall by 10 per cent. It is a policy which has enabled the level of industrial disputes in this country, comparing the Hawke years with the Fraser years, to fall by 61 per cent. If the Greiner Government of New South Wales had had a more enlightened industrial relations approach, and if New South Wales did not drag down the average for Australia and distort it because of the higher levels of industrial disputes than in other Australian States, that figure would have been better.

It is a policy which has led to a massive increase in employment. Even now, in the midst of a recession, the record of this Government over that of the Fraser years is an increase in employment of 1.4 million people. That is a significant achievement. It is a policy that has meant that the inflation rate in Australia is below that of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average and is trending even lower. They are the achievements of our policy.

To compare our policy with that of the Opposition is to go back to the Fraser years when Mr Howard, now the Opposition spokesman, was Treasurer and when Dr Hewson, now the Leader, was economic adviser to the Prime Minister. If they are the people holding themselves up as an alternative, what was their record? Their record was massive disputation; Australia divided; Australians versus Australians; double digit inflation; double digit unemployment; negative economic growth and a wages explosion which blew out to 18 per cent in the last year of their term.

As I have said, our policy is proven-but so is theirs; it is proven as a failure. Ours is a policy which, at base, tries to evolve a cooperation model in the industrial workplace of this country, not a conflict model which is so typical of the Opposition. I might also say that ours has worked and the Opposition's has failed.

There are four central issues that need to be understood to bring clarity of thought and precision to the discussion of what is happening in industrial relations at the moment. Those four issues are, first, that the accord between the Australian Government and the trade union movement provides a framework through which moderate wage outcomes can be achieved, can be spread fairly in the community, will be linked to increasing productivity and will devolve in a managed way to company level bargaining.

The second major issue that needs to be understood is that for us the role of the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC) is still vital; but the role must change. It was always a role which would change as the system decentralised. Honourable senators should bear in mind that accord mark vi, negotiated in January 1990, proclaimed a move to a decentralised system. Back then, it was a role of a commission in a more decentralised structure that must change, and I will say more about that in a moment.

The third thing that needs to be understood is that because of the nature of the national wage case decision it has become unworkable. I say that for this reason: one needs to be precise now because we are talking about actual words in a decision and the actual way in which industrial relations operate as opposed to the gloss or the broad assumptions erroneously made by many Opposition commentators. Let me be precise with language: the national wage case decision put on offer an up to 2.5 per cent wage increase, subject to unions volunteering a no extra claims commitment-that is to say, not to ask for any more than that-subject to unions continuing award restructuring and subject to unions doing a number of other things, at the company level, to generate greater productivity.

The wage case decision invited unions to come forward and to give those commitments in exchange for 2.5 per cent. We have seen the unions of Australia say, `Well look, we do not wish to volunteer for up to 2.5 per cent and give those claims'. The Commission's decision did not award guidelines for us to pursue company level bargaining to generate productivity in a more decentralised system that we wish to share in. The national wage case decision did not award superannuation, which was part of the claim, which would enable a safety net to be put under the superannuation entitlements of ordinary Australians and meet a retirement incomes policy for the next century.

But the invitation in the decision was for the unions to come forward and give those commitments. For the decision to work, it requires the unions to voluntarily accept those terms. The fact is that they do not choose to voluntarily accept those terms because they want to rely on the accord framework, which guarantees tax cuts and which guarantees not just wages but living standards; under the accord we are not negotiating simply wages, but the whole incomes environment of a family. We are talking about wages, about tax cuts and about other provisions in the social wage; there is a whole section in the accord about family child-care. We are talking here as well about commitments by the Government on industry policy, to use wages policy as a lever to generate more productivity in the economy. The unions say that they do not wish to accept the Commission's invitation for an up to 2.5 per cent increase because it does not provide them, after taking from them some of the key elements, with a fair deal in the context of the restraints on them.
On the basis of that, they approach employers for the purposes--

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't obey the umpire.

—Honourable senators should understand this point, which is a central point, if they understand nothing else of what I say: unions are invited to voluntarily accept the terms of the decision and to give commitments. Unions are saying, `We do not like the terms of the decision, so we will not volunteer'. No-one can tell them that they should or should not accept those terms. They have proclaimed that the terms are not acceptable; they have not volunteered; and they now wish to negotiate with employers directly.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators should also bear in mind that the fundamental objective of the Commission is to prevent and to settle industrial disputes. In this case, no industrial disputes have been referred at this point of time to the Commission because of the direct negotiation between unions and employers. There are continuing reports that some of these direct negotiations have resulted in agreements. One could not gainsay the importance of having the parties at that level achieve those agreements.

The fourth point that needs to be understood is fundamental. It is that the coming recovery of the economy from recession to growth, and how that is managed in an orderly way so that in the course of that recovery we transfer into a more productive society, is central to this decision as well. I say that because the key element here, as union bargaining power now is weak but later will become strong, is to make a transition so that that union bargaining power is not exploited to the full for what the market will bear but, rather, is curbed in the national interest to achieve a moderate wage outcome and to achieve structural reform in the Australian economy at company level in negotiations where unions, workers and employers sit down to work out together how they plan strategically in a particular company to achieve a greater productive environment. They must plan strategically to see that the benefits of that higher productivity are taken in the form of, in the first instance, the community interest-that is, lower prices for the product offered by that company-and, in the second and third instances, in the form of wages as an enduring incentive to continue to make the productivity leaps that are necessary and, in return, profits on the company side for return to shareholders and reinvestment.

The four points that need to be understood are these: the accord is absolutely fundamental in an incomes policy environment to provide a framework for continuing moderate wage outcomes and managed, calm and orderly devolving from the central to the decentralised system; the role of the IRC, which is a constant in our lexicon but not in the Opposition's, continues, but it is less the central player and more the decentralised player, more the dispute settler; the national wage case decision that has come down is unworkable because unions do not wish to volunteer to make those undertakings, and are thus free from the terms of the decision if they do not accept those terms-if they wish to negotiate another outcome, that is their right; and our concern as a government is to manage the recovery of the economy in these circumstances.

I have said that the accord is not a wages policy. The accord is about living standards. It is not narrowly focused simply on wages. We are not looking here at an environment in which there is a wage increase partly eroded by a tax bite and partly further eroded by a pushing up of prices. We are looking here at a way in which we manage outcomes for families by balancing wages with tax cuts; with efforts to try to contain prices through the Prices Surveillance Authority; and by putting into place a whole mechanism of social wage-benefits provided out of taxpayers' money by the Government to the community, particularly for the less well off in the community, to provide a decent living standard for them.

All of this is linked to an industry policy geared at making Australia more productive. That is not well understood, but it is essential to the ability to deliver an aggregate wage outcome which makes this economy much more manageable and for which there is no answer from the Opposition. The framework of the accord does all of those things. This particular decision failed on the basis that it did not answer essential elements of the accord and, therefore, the unions withdrew.

As I have said, the enduring role of the Industrial Relations Commission exists and will continue under our Government. Whether that is the case under an Opposition government of the future is doubtful if one looks at the words of many of the Opposition spokespersons. Indeed, its own spokesperson has said that he will legislate for minimum wages and has thrown into doubt whether the Commission will exist at all. For us it is important that the Commission exist so that workers who wish to have award coverage can apply for it and achieve a wage outcome that is a minimum rates award for them, and if that is an industry-wide award, so be it.

On the basis of an industry-wide minimum rates award which now applies extensively in the private sector, there is a capacity in our policy, with and through the Commission, to look at enterprise-based or company-based bargaining, build on that minimum standard for the particular industry on a company-by-company basis and achieve, with and through the Commission, the enterprise focus that the accord speaks of.

As I have said in this place many times, section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act enables both companies and unions to opt out of the system and construct an arrangement that suits both of them. If that arrangement is found by the Commission to be struck between equals and regarded as fair, they are perfectly at liberty and at large to do so. I would like to see that situation achieved more often. I would like to see now, as well, in the newer emerging environment of a more decentralised system, a commission more attuned to being a facilitator to achieve in workplaces the type of cultural shift that is necessary to create the productivity basis of which I have spoken. That is an important element in the future role of the Commission.

I conclude by saying that it is essential that the accord package which has served this country well serves it again, lest the recovery from this current recession simply leads to a wages break-out and not a moderate outcome, and in order that the living standards of this community are not simply pushed up in terms of what maxima are achieved, but that there is a steady evolution of the economy rather than it being subject to undue wage pressures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is often said that hope springs eternal. We all hope for many things. Two things that we all hope for are a secure income now and a secure income in our retirement. Australians have traditionally looked to governments to support us in achieving these two hopes. There are few things that are more important to the average Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats believe that ordinary Australians have every reason to feel insecure about these two hopes and to be confused about how both governments and oppositions intend to assist them in the fulfilment of these dual aspirations. Certainly, since the wage case judgment last week, we have seen at least what appears to be confusion in some camps. I acknowledge the contribution made by Senator Cook in clarifying what the Government's position is, because the Democrats have no option but to accept the essence of the proposition before us that, in fact, there has been confusion. The whole process that we are debating today is, indeed, inherently confusing. It is inevitable that it will cyclically go through periods of clarity and periods of confusion. It is difficult to argue that the last eight or so days have not given ordinary Australians reason to feel confused about the position of, frankly, both Government and Opposition.

Senator Cook's observations concerning the wording of the motion are quite correct. There is a turn in the wording which tends to suggest that the Government's position has shifted. Perhaps it has not. Perhaps the value of this motion is that it has provided the Minister, and indeed the Opposition and the Democrats, with an opportunity to clarify their positions in light of the wage case judgment of last week. Of course, that not only confuses the mechanisms in relation to wage determination, but also throws some doubt upon the future of superannuation. Indeed, tomorrow, my colleague Senator Spindler will give notice of motion calling for a national summit to address the whole question of superannuation.

I turn now to the specific intention of the urgency motion before us. The Democrats interpret it in its round terms rather than in its specific wording and, therefore, we will support it, in that it fundamentally suggests that it is appropriate that confusion be clarified. We accept that. I believe that there is reason and justification for ordinary Australians to feel that the Government, perhaps, and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) have been ambivalent in their position in relation to the Industrial Relations Commission. Perhaps they have been trying to have their cake and eat it too.

Both the Government and the ACTU have wanted a strong and independent Industrial Relations Commission. As I said last week when the Commission brought down its judgment, it would appear that that is indeed what we have: an Industrial Relations Commission which has sent out quite clear signals that nobody is its master. In that respect, the Australian Democrats welcome those signals.

However, we do not welcome some of the specifics of what is in that judgment. We do not welcome the 2.5 per cent increase mechanism. We agree that that impacts adversely upon low income earners in this country, and that is not good. Nor do we welcome the fact that there will not be provision for the additional 3 per cent superannuation that was sought. Nor do we welcome the fact that the Industrial Relations Commission has turned away from the accord as the fundamental mechanism by which wages have been stabilised and wage grants have been held in place over the last six to eight years.

As I said, we do, however, welcome signals of a strong, independent stance on the part of this Commission. We welcome the suggestion on the part of the Commission that much more homework needs to be done before it is prepared to accept the fact that enterprise bargaining should become the prime mechanism of determining what average Australians receive from their employers.

The position of the Australian Democrats is quite clear. We accept the role of enterprise bargaining. However, we have always said that we would require the outcomes of such processes to be registered and monitored by a strong, independent industrial relations commission. We have always acknowledged that we prefer the centralised model of industrial relations to the decentralised model. Why should ordinary Australians be confused about the position of both the Government and the coalition, that is, the alternative government?

Over the past three years, very important industrial legislation has been enacted by this Parliament. In 1988 the Government put in place a new model of industrial relations. It put aside the model of arbitration and conciliation, which had become worn out. It was more than 70 years old. It had been amended in excess of 50 times-sometimes major amendments. It was time to put it aside and to put a new model in place. That occurred by way of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

In 1990 that Act was built upon by the introduction of major amendments. The primary thrust was to create a strong industrial relations commission. It is ironic that today we have in the chamber legislation which strengthens and consolidates the role of the Industrial Relations Commission. Today we heard Senator Durack state that the Opposition sees a pivotal role for an industrial relations commission where agreements cannot be reached by alternative processes. I have interpreted his comments as meaning that the Opposition acknowledges the need for a strong and independent industrial relations commission. We will have the opportunity to support legislation in this place today and tomorrow which will ensure such a commission.

Ordinary Australians have reason to be confused by the fact that both the Government and the ACTU walked away from rulings and judgments of the Industrial Relations Commission eight days ago. The statements which emanated from the ACTU special conference were very strong. I think ordinary Australians have reason to be confused as to which of the two points of view-the Kelty or the Keating-will prevail. There have certainly been mixed messages emerging from that special forum. Despite its supposed unanimity, there were mixed messages in the air going out to ordinary Australians, even within hours of that conference having supposedly arrived at a unanimous rejection of the decisions of the Industrial Relations Commission.

The long and short of it is that there is an enormous amount of game play occurring at the moment. New Acts are in place, new procedures are settling down and the major players-the Government, the Industrial Relations Commission, the ACTU and the peak organisations of employers-are playing out their roles. Ordinary Australians are seeing and are being confused by what is little more than political game play and the realities are yet to emerge.

One reality is that, should there be a change of government, there would certainly be a massive upheaval in the area of industrial relations. The confusion of May 1991 may well pale into insignifi- cance alongside the confusion that would prevail for some years should there be a change of government and an attempt to make the quantum leap, in quick time, from the centralised to a decentralised model. Little wonder therefore that ordinary Australians are feeling insecure about their dual hopes and aspirations for a just and adequate wage now and a secure, assured income in their retirement.

Frankly, I am no less confused about the statements that the Opposition has placed before both the Parliament and the constituency at large in the past three years in which these significant matters have been debated. I was in this place to hear former Senator Chaney, as the former shadow Minister for Industrial Relations, respond and argue in a way that left me with no doubt that he shared the attitudes and the value set of the present shadow Minister, Mr Howard, and the present Opposition Leader, Dr Hewson, that should there be a change of government the Industrial Relations Commission would be dramatically weakened. I do not believe that it is possible to read the Hansard and arrive at any conclusion other than that, if the decentralised model were put in place, a weakened and less independent industrial relations commission would result.

As to the Howard imagery of recent days of the new generation of unemployed, such people would be putty in the hands of employers in the context of a decentralised model where enterprise bargaining carried the day. Therefore I welcome the decision of the Industrial Relations Commission that a lot more homework needs to be done and a lot more confidence and credibility has to be established before enterprise bargaining becomes the fundamental process determining wages in this country.
The Business Council of Australia and the Confederation of Australian Industry, in their recent newsletter Business Background, had this to say:

While the decision rejected the Accord, it did not reject a move towards enterprise negotiations. What it did propose was for the ACTU, Government and employers to have consultations to try and resolve the differences which exist over how the concept would operate.

The reality is that there are enormous uncertainties about how these alternative processes would operate. There is not the degree of confidence in them that we are sometimes led to believe by the Opposition. If we look at the two experiences of enterprise bargaining, namely, the airline pilots dispute and the recent negotiations regarding conditions and pay on the wharf, we would not have much confidence in that process at all. On both occasions, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was called into the action and that is hardly evidence of the fact that this process is one in which ordinary Australians should have a great deal of confidence. In the case of the airline pilots dispute, the matter was referred to the International Labour Organisation-an external world organisation-for its opinion on the process of enterprise bargaining.

The Australian Democrats believe that there is a great deal of confusion and that there is reason for ordinary Australians not to have confidence in the light of what they have heard and seen in recent days. Therefore, we reject the semantics of the objections that we have heard to this motion and we accept it in its round terms, but there is need for clarification.

The Commission went on to request the Commonwealth to convene the national conference-which the Government has studiously avoided doing for the last six months; indeed, it has not even had the courtesy to respond to written requests from the Business Council of Australia and it simply adjourned the proceedings. That was a fundamental rebuff and I can understand its fit of pique; but I would have thought that if this Government considers itself to be responsible in any way at all, it would have had the decency to then respond by at least pointing out how it proposes to deal with some of these manifest inadequacies-and they are legion.

The question of non-compliance is probably the most burning one and has the greatest capacity for embarrassment for the union movement. The facts are that on the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, only about 56 per cent of the work force is covered by superannuation-or is receiving it, I should say, because there is a vital difference. People such as Senator Cook like to pretend that because there is award coverage, somehow people have got superannuation. I am sure that Senator Cooney knows the facts. The fact is that in the private sector only 40.6 per cent of workers are currently receiving any superannuation at all-not just award superannuation. There is a massive non-compliance problem.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) will tell us it has a strategy in place that will make this a non-issue by the end of the year. I am waiting to see that. It has not been successful since 1986 in significantly reducing the non-compliance problem. I cannot for a moment imagine how it is going to be able to get out to the back blocks and pick up those hundreds of thousands of employers who are simply not complying with award obligations. It is a very serious problem-we all know that-and it imposes legal liabilities on employers which will, in some circumstances, be catastrophic for their businesses.

The fact remains that those workers are not getting that superannuation payment and the Government simply ignores it as a problem. It is not even prepared to talk about a realistic target. The Business Council said, `10 per cent by the year 2000'. I think one can say that that figure may well be generous in the circumstances and that we may not need to go that high; but the Government has refrained from setting a target. Most importantly, it has not addressed the fundamental criticism, that the award superannuation has evolved in a way so that it has simply become an industrial relations solution to a wages claim.

That is manifest in a number of ways, the most significant of which is that instead of ensuring a minimum level of superannuation entitlement, it is simply a 3 per cent add-on across the board. Where we have, say, in the public sector, people with 20 per cent plus who do not need any more superannuation, where we have most of the constituency of the Business Council getting in excess of 10 per cent and, therefore, do not need another 3 per cent, we have, nonetheless, had this commitment to imposing it across the board. This is all part of the managed approach that the accord partners have to industrial relations. This has nothing to do with delivering an effective and appropriate superannuation outcome for those whom they purport to represent.

If ever we have been misled it is when people like Mr Keating have the gall to say that this is all about extending superannuation to those who have never had it before. The fact is that, unless one is in the trade union movement, one misses out altogether. In the private sector, about a third of workers belong to the union movement and about 40 per cent get superannuation. In the public sector, 75 per cent belong to unions and just over 90 per cent get superannuation. That is where it starts and finishes.

There is no incentive for any trade union organiser to go out and flog superannuation to those who are not getting it. The trustees of many of the industry funds have no interest at all in seeing commission paid to commercial agents-be they solicitors, accountants or anyone else-to try to encourage people to come within the system. There will not be any progress made on that issue; the same group of people will get more superannuation and the disparity between the haves and the have-nots will become even greater-quite the opposite to what the Government professes to stand for and quite the opposite to what the ACTU should be on about.

The other outstanding deficiency of the current arrangements is the nonsense that has been put in place on a piecemeal basis by way of tax concessions for employees. The category a person is in-whether one is getting some award superannuation, is getting no award superannuation, is self-employed or has modest levels of employer support-determines whether that person gets a rebate or a deduction in the first instance, whether limits are placed on that or whether the person is disqualified altogether. It is an absolute nonsense and everyone knows it. It is impossibly complex and clearly deters employees from wanting to invest any more in their own superannuation schemes.

Maybe that suits the Government's agenda fine because at the end of the day it sees this measure as taking money out of the pockets of employers, not encouraging employees to contribute and therefore having some responsibility for their own savings during their working lives and their own levels of retirement income. In other words, it is all about forcing the employers to cough up and nothing about self-reliance. We think that that is a flawed model.

Again, I would have thought that the Government should have at least been prepared, in the weeks that have passed since the national wage case decision, to spell out where it stands on these sorts of issues. Is it in favour of legislating? We do not know. All we have is selective leaks to journalists in the Australian and the Australian Financial Review, with front page stories saying that the Government is thinking about it.

The reality is probably that this measure is simply in terrorem stuff to try to intimidate the Commission on the one hand and bring the unions into line on the other. It does not seem to be driven by any work that has gone on in the relevant departments. It would seem to be just another kite to distract attention from the fact that the Government does not have an alternative agenda and does not want to spell out how it intends to approach the issue. It simply wants to lock arms with the trade union movement and get out in the field and into that other 3 per cent, irrespective of the fact that the Commission and every other responsible commentator has demonstrated that there is just no capacity to pay at the present time.

This 3 per cent, the second round, was cobbled together in a pre-election environment in February last year which took no account of even the possibility of a recession. It was simply assumed that employers would be able to afford to pay, or that at least those who had already been paying-as we know, they are only a relatively small proportion of the total in any event-would be able to continue to do so. It is light years away from current circumstances. Yet once again the Government is not prepared to acknowledge that; it is simply out there wanting to go for broke.

We can look at statements from Mr Kelty, Mr Ferguson and all the others. They could not give a damn; they are only interested in enforcing that accord by hook or by crook. They do not have a skerrick of concern about whether it is affordable, rational, sensible, or counterproductive. It is likely to be counterproductive because many employer funds will simply be folded into industry funds. No doubt that is part of the Government's agenda. But the end result is that those workers will not be any better off at all. There will be massive disobedience on the part of the small businesses simply because they cannot afford it, whether they already have substantial liabilities under existing award obligations or not.

There is a whole host of problems with the current system. The Government has just refused to address them. Once again Senator Cook has turned a blind eye to them. I just hope that Senator Cooney, with his background in industrial relations, will have the ability and the foresight at least to deal sensibly with some of these real problems which everyone else recognises but which the Government is simply keeping its head in the sand about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could say that this topic is a timely one to bring before the Senate and indeed this Parliament. It is a topic that deals with the way the Government is handling industrial relations in this country. It deals with the admitted problems that have been found to exist with the latest decision from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC). Those issues are vital ones for this community, so it is a very proper motion to address in this chamber, as Senator McLean from the Australian Democrats spoke to it, in broad terms. One sees from the actual particulars set out in the motion that the motion contains an allegation of fact which is just not true.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the statement that the Government has rejected the central role of the AIRC. I take it that that is based on the following evidence: that following the latest national wage case decision, the Government has expressed disappointment with the implications that arise from that decision. The fact that a government, or indeed anybody, expresses a disappointment with a particular outcome does not mean, and cannot be held to mean, that there has been a rejection of the central role of the AIRC. Indeed, the evidence to the contrary is that, the waterside problems having been solved among employers and employees, unions and government, that solution has been taken to the Industrial Relations Commission. That indicates that all those bodies have nothing but the highest respect for the Industrial Relations Commission. I say in passing that the three Ministers-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), Senator Cook and Senator Collins-involved in the solution to the waterside problem need to be thanked by the community and this chamber. Had that solution broken down, quite disastrous consequences could have followed generally.

The solution to that problem shows how important it is that employers and employees, unions and government are able to go forward together on an agreed basis. That is really what has been done through the accord. It is a fair and proper debating point to say that the Government has expressed some disappointment about the Industrial Relations Commission and therefore it has changed its policies and left things confused. I have explained that that is not so.

I will now explain why the Government, quite rightly, was disappointed with the outcome from the Commission. For example, the figures indicating the industrial disputes in Australia since 1972 and the working days lost per thousand employees show how great a service has been paid to this nation by the accord and the concomitant features of the accord, such as the coming on board of the employers and the good relationships that have come to exist amongst government, unions, employers and employees compared to what went before. One sees, for example, that, in 1976, 773 working days were lost per thousand employees; in 1980, 649; in 1981, 797; and in 1982, 348; followed by a dramatic fall. In 1983, 249 days were lost; in 1984, 248; in 1985, 228; in 1986, 242; in 1987, 223; in 1988, 269; in 1989, 190; and last year, 1990, 216.

If there is a substantial threat to the existing agreements between the various parties in industry-that that relationship will break up and that there will be a return to the old days when industrial disputes were much more prevalent, when relationships between those groups were much more soured than they are now and when the workplace culture has been changed, that change occurring in 1983-then, quite properly, this Government should do something.

The Industrial Relations Commission is an august body that we must follow and obey. However, if the Government perceives that a decision of that body would prejudice the work of a decade, the Government should quite properly say so and explain to the unions and employer groups that the Government does not agree with a decision that would return industrial relations to a time which, fortunately, has now largely passed.

In responding to a situation where disaster might well befall the workplace, the Government should express disappointment with the decision and signal to the various parties in the industrial relations field that it understands such problems. To save what has been at times so excruciatingly purchased and hard earned is to act responsibly.

The motion calls on the Government to clarify its new industrial relations and occupational superannuation policies. There are no new industrial relations and occupational superannuation policies. The motion implies that somehow a person's labour and place in the workplace is simply another factor to be taken into account by economists in the same way as machinery, investment capital and marketing plans are. That is not the case at all. The Government acts to look after not only workers but also the unemployed, those in need of social security and those who are retired and in need of superannuation. Senator Alston spoke about superannuation and described the superannuation scheme as having some `blips'. There are blips in the scheme. According to Government the purpose of the proposed legislation is to create flexible labour market practices so that production efficiencies will be encouraged; they in turn will lead to economic growth. I leave out the next part. The document continues:
The legislation assumes that the free pursuit of his or her interest by the private individual automatically leads to the public or common good of society.

ACTU president Martin Ferguson issued a warning to employers, saying industrial reform could stall as unions turned up the heat in the quest for the accord.
In the same article the Secretary of the ACTU, Bill Kelty, said:
. . . it was a sad and emotional decision, but even in a recession workers would rather fight than accept the 2.5 per cent offered by the commission.

This highlights that the main players, when the umpire makes a decision which is what they want, agree and accept it; but when the umpire makes a decision which is not what they want under current industrial law in this country, they take the law into their own hands. One must conclude from these statements that both players would prefer to put more people on the unemployment scrap heap than address the excesses of Australia's fundamental work practices.

The real question is: how high will the Government jump when the ACTU refuses to abide by the Government's own appointed umpire, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission? Should we be asking: what has the ACTU told the Government to do with regard to future industrial relations policy?

Let us look at the Government's own employees, the Public Service. Public Service employees operate under paid rate awards. In other words, they have to be paid precisely what the Industrial Relations Commission determines as the maximum. The Government has committed itself by statutory declaration to the Commission that no higher rates will be paid. The breach for breaking the provisions of a statutory declaration is gaol; therefore, in offering to pay the accord package contrary to the Commission's decision of 2.5 per cent, the Government will place itself in breach of an undertaking to the Commission by maintaining paid rate awards. Or will the Government have one set of award setting arrangements for public servants and another for the remainder of the work force? The Government has lost its way. Inconsistency is the order of the day.

Let us look at the first foray into the new order of this policy: the waterfront. I want to quote a couple of paragraphs from the final settlement proposal which has gone back to the Commission. It states:
(a) the first adjustment to be $12 per week from the first pay period on or after 16 May
(b) an aggregate 6.12% adjustment in three equal instalments consistent with the agreed classification structure

The document goes on to deal with implementation from 1 July 1991 and from 1 July 1992. In terms of this document I have to ask: if this is the new order, why have not the excesses which exist on the waterfront been addressed? If this is the new line that the Government is going to take, surely those work practices-those things which exacerbate Australia's economic position-should be addressed?

Let us look at some of the excesses and situations which exist-and this is just a small sample of them. Firstly, the gross average weekly earnings for a general class waterside worker are $824 a week for an average week of 27 working hours. Can honourable senators believe it-27 hours! In some of the smaller ports around Australia the figures are worse. For example, in Thevenard in South Australia the worker averaged $360 per week for an average week of six working hours. The waterside worker enjoys five weeks annual leave with a 27.5 per cent leave loading. The waterside worker enjoys 10 sick leave days per year. In addition, these can be accumulated over a period of time and cashed in after 10 years of continuous employment.

In Western Australia free taxis are provided for workers to travel between Fremantle railway station and the Fremantle wharf. Workers who choose to drive rather than take a taxi from the railway station are paid for five minutes travel time. Those involved in the transport of container cargo were paid a weekly consolidated disability allowance of $11.20 to compensate them for dirty working conditions under which they might be forced to work. Those not adversely affected by the conditions still get the allowance. Workers who earn overtime for more than one hour also earn a meal allowance of $9.15. Tradesmen on the wharf earn an average of $977 per week for working 31.7 hours.

In this, the first foray by the Government into its new industrial regime, none of these things are touched. The list goes on. Unfortunately, I do not have the time to deal with them all today, but I shall refer to a couple more. In regard to live sheep loading, the manning levels are excessive. Currently, approximately 12 men are required to load one ship. Most consider that two men and a dog could do the same job. Currently, there is a rumour that a group in Tasmania tried to enrol a dog as a member of the local Waterside Workers Federation to increase productivity.

Under the agreement that has been put in place, none of these things will be addressed before 1 July next year, and they may not be addressed then. We are looking at reform in the workplace-reform of the industrial practices that we have in this country, and a new order. But the Government has achieved nothing in terms of this agreement. It is an absolute tragedy. All that this agreement does now is give a pay rise. The excesses continue, unemployment rises and the recession we had to have rolls on.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wants the matter to go back to the Commission. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) does not, as I have already indicated, and Senator Cook wants two bob each way. I wish to quote Senator Cook once again to demonstrate the inconsistency of his position in relation to this issue. On 18 December 1990 in the debate on a matter of urgency Senator Cook said:

I look at Senator Winston Crane on the other side of the Chamber, who just last week asked me, as a Minister of this Government, to intervene and to tell the umpire to do certain things in a particular dispute. He wanted intervention in that dispute. I was asked yesterday by Senator Durack, who has propounded this item, whether I would intervene in this particular dispute. I am not going to intervene in this dispute, as I was not going to intervene in the other dispute. The Government is not butting in. The Government is not saying, `We are Big Brother; We know best'. We are simply saying, `If the deal is fair . . .
But just a few days ago a press report stated:
In an unusual move, Industrial Relations Minister Peter Cook issued a statement saying cabinet had reaffirmed the key role of the accord in wagefixing over that of the IRC.

I emphasise that it was `over that of the IRC'. It is obvious that in the national wage case he sides with the ACTU against the umpire. In the case of `Meatgate', which is before the Harrison inquiry at present and which Senator Cooney referred to before in his comments about superannuation, the Minister will not do anything which is effective in bringing the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) to heel. The activities of the AMIEU in this particular dispute-as I have outlined before in this place-have now cost somewhere in excess of $250m in lost export earnings. They have also sent a number of export abattoirs in this country broke.

Is it any wonder that confusion reigns supreme? Is it any wonder that we have had to bring this motion before this place today in order to have the Government's position clarified? The Government has become very inconsistent in its dealings with regard to these particular issues. It is quite clear to me that there is much disagreement about the position which is being adopted by the various players within the Government. In the case of the waterfront agreement we saw the Prime Minister having to move in over Senator Collins. We see Treasurer Keating adopting a position which is different to that of other Ministers in the Government.

I conclude by making a few observations in relation to enterprise bargaining. I also support what Senator Durack said earlier: enterprise agreements will become a fact of life in this country as we move towards the next decade. But enterprise agreements will not work, be effective, or provide the real benefits which are required unless the legal rights rest with the employer and the employee without intervention; unless closed shops are abolished; and unless there is legislation for enterprise unions. The Government should clarify its position. Today it has failed to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In listening to the contributions of those speakers opposite, and particularly that of the last speaker, Senator Crane, we could be forgiven for asking why the Senate was presented today with an urgency motion relating to superannuation. SPEECH.PARA: We had the contribution from Senator Crane about the need for the Government to get back on track. But those opposite were not even on the track when it came to superannuation, and I will detail more about that later. We heard a lot about freeing up the labour market and enterprise bargaining and I will also make some comments about that later.

Prior to the election of a national Labor government, the record of those opposite on the issue of superannuation was very patchy, ill-conceived, ill-planned and ill-thought out. Until the election of a national Labor government and the policies that we have implemented with regard to superannuation-which I will comment about-there was no national retirement plan for this nation.

A very small proportion of workers in this country enjoyed superannuation. It tended to be concentrated on those workers who were better paid and who were male. Vast sections of the work force, such as females, those in lesser paid occupations, and those who worked on a casual or seasonal basis, had no superannuation at all. They had very little to look forward to except a pension which, given the demographic changes in this nation, meant less and less in real terms. Those opposite had developed no policies and had done absolutely nothing about providing an effective retirement package for people in this country.

In fact, to rub salt into the wound of those who did not have superannuation in this country, there was a tax deduction for those who did have superannuation. So, in effect, those people who were well off and who enjoyed superannuation were being subsidised through the tax system by those people who were less well off and who did not have superannuation. That highlights the inequities that existed in the area of superannuation under the previous national Liberal Government. Nothing had been done in this area.

When I saw the text of this matter of urgency I realised very quickly, from the way it was worded and the basic contradictions contained in it, that those opposite do not have a very great understanding of superannuation policy or, indeed, of the way in which the IRC operates, or of the way in which enterprise bargaining has operated in this country for the last 90 years and the way in which it will continue to operate. Maybe enterprise bargaining will take a more central role in our industrial negotiations.

I return to the election of a national Labor government. It moved immediately to implement a sound, comprehensive, consistent, long term and responsible economic approach to superannuation and retirement policy in this country. What did our Government do? Firstly, it ensured that all workers in this nation had access to superannuation. Along with the union movement, it presented a case to the Industrial Relations Commission for the implementation of a 3 per cent productivity award for all workers in this country-not a selective few as had occurred when those opposite were in government.

Secondly, it encouraged the establishment of industry superannuation funds rather then personal superannuation funds. The important advantages of that for workers of this country are that industry funds are portable, and that people can move from occupation to occupation, from employer to employer and they do not lose their money. Employees can rest assured that the moneys that they have accumulated in the funds are their moneys to be collected when they retire. That is not what occurred when there was individual or company dominated and company-sponsored superannuation. That is one of the important changes that have been made.

The massive size of these industry funds also ensures that the administrative charges are minimal. With regard to personal superannuation or the old employer superannuation, the administrative charges ranged from anywhere between 2 to 5 per cent of the total contributions. The administrative charges of the industry funds are, in real money terms, much lower because the funds are much larger and they are operated much more efficiently.

This Government through the tax system has also encouraged employees optionally to contribute to these industry superannuation funds. In legislation that I spoke to last year, this Government has also changed the Industrial Relations Act to ensure that there is greater enforcement of the superannuation provisions within industrial awards in this country and to ensure that for those workers who are legally entitled to their superannuation, which in many cases is not being paid by employers, it is legally enforceable and able to be collected.

In summary, that has been the policy approach of the Labor Government in this country, which stands in stark contrast to the policy of those opposite when they were in government. Our policy is an activist policy and a fair policy. The policy of those opposite was an inactive policy, a `do nothing' policy which lacked planning and forward coordination.

In the latest accord, accord mark VI, the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) intended that a further 3 per cent should be added on top of the 3 per cent that already exists. The reason for doing this is that, in this country if a person is to have a reasonable income on retirement, the equivalent of 10 per cent is needed to be saved and put aside for that retirement. The Government, quite rightly, saw it as necessary for the long term incomes policy in this country that additional contributions should be made.

Regrettably, the Industrial Relations Commission did not consider that the 3 per cent staggered in one per cent payments should occur. Instead it said that in November of this year there should be a national conference of the various parties to consider the future of superannuation. That was the decision that was made. But that does not mean the end of occupational superannuation policy and, frankly, it does not mean any change in this Government's attitude or policy on superannuation, as this urgency motion suggests. It does not mean the end of a coordinated approach on superannuation. There is no inherent contradiction between occupational superannuation that is being pursued by this Government and enterprise bargaining.

We can still have enterprise bargaining and national occupational superannuation. This is where those opposite do not have any fundamental understanding of either the industrial relations system, enterprise bargaining or superannuation. If one has enterprise bargaining then what is important is the issues that are bargained at the enterprise level. So far as this Government is concerned, superannuation is not one of those issues that are going to be bargained at enterprise level and left to the option of the employer to implement if he or she so wishes.

There are certain minimum standards that this Government has set and intends to improve on in the area of occupational superannuation. I do not think that those opposite have considered the role of superannuation in the enterprise bargaining process, should they ever be elected to government. Those opposite have suggested, in their fairly brief industrial relations policy that has so far been detailed, that through enterprise bargaining everything should be bargained between the employer and individual employees except a minimum wage.

Again, last night, the industrial relations spokesperson for the Opposition, John Howard, when talking about changes in New Zealand said that the only minimum would be a minimum wage set by the Industrial Commission. Everything else would be negotiated and I assume he includes superannuation. This is where those opposite have not thought out their policy approach on superannuation. If superannuation is one of those things that are to be bargained between the employer and the employee under the policy as enunciated by those currently in opposition, should they ever get into government and it is put into practice, I suggest that there would not be any national cohesive superannuation policy for this country.

I know what I would do if I were an employer and I had the power that the Opposition is going to give employers; if there were no check; if there were no independent adjudicator through the Industrial Relations Commission; if the employer had the absolute right to hire and fire; and if the employer had enormous bargaining power because he was flanked by industrial advisers, lawyers, accountants and security firms. I know what would happen to the individual employees in that sort of bargaining process. I suggest that their ability to bargain for improved superannuation benefits, let alone hold onto what they have, would be minimal. In fact, workers in any sort of individual bargaining process without any protection, which is what the Opposition is advocating, would very quickly lose what they have at the present time-whether it be annual leave, sick leave, superannuation or weekend penalty rates. We would lose any sort of coherent and national superannuation policy.

The concept of individual bargaining, which has been advocated by those opposite during the debate, is not the same as enterprise bargaining and this is where those opposite have a fundamental misunderstanding about industrial relations negotiations. Bargaining can take place at the enterprise level and, indeed, it has taken place for some 90 years. Overaward negotiations have occurred at most workplaces in this country on a variety of issues. So, enterprise bargaining has taken place and will continue to take place. But if we are to ensure equity and justice for workers in this country, enterprise bargaining must take place with an industrial relations system where there is an independent authority, such as the Industrial Relations Commission, to determine what is fair and what is just. One can continue to have enterprise bargaining provided that one has certain minimum protections for workers in the way of superannuation.

The rejection by the Industrial Relations Commission of the package that was negotiated between the ACTU and the Government is but a temporary setback in the pursuance of both national superannuation for all workers in this country and adequate superannuation protection. By `adequate' I mean sufficient money to ensure that all people when they retire from the work force have a decent income to live on, which stands in stark contrast to the absolute nil record of those opposite when they were in government. This will continue to remain one of the central policy options of this Government. In my view, one of the greatest achievements of this Government is that we now are starting to have a national superannuation policy providing for adequate protection for all workers in this country.

The Industrial Relations Commission will continue to play a very important role in the establishment and development of superannuation. It will continue to play that role because superannuation minima are provided for in almost all industrial awards in this country. They are required to be registered before the Industrial Relations Commission and therefore that Industrial Relations Commission role will continue.

In conclusion, I say that our policy stands. Whilst there has not been implementation of the second 3 per cent, we have ensured that there is a fair tax system in respect of superannuation and that there are productivity funds which ensure that all workers can have access to portable superannuation. We have established the 3 per cent minimum, although many workers receive more than that. Those opposite have done absolutely nothing in the area of superannuation. Their only answer is vague terms and cliches about free collective bargaining, enterprise bargaining and removing the shackles of the Industrial Relations Commission. This urgency motion should be rejected. It is totally inconsistent. It is typical of the stand of Opposition senators on the issues of industrial relations and superannuation. They know not what they are talking about.
