Recycling is the fastest growing waste management technique employed by governments worldwide. For any waste management strategy to be successful, it must have the support of the public, industry and State, local and Federal governments. It is good to see in the two volumes of the Industry Commission's report on recycling suggestions as to what the Government should do. Volume I of the report says:

. . . local governments influence recycling indirectly through their waste disposal policies and directly through their collection systems; State Governments influence recycling through their environmental and industry development initiatives, their own purchasing policies and their controls over local government.

Of course, the Commonwealth Government, of which we are a part here, can have an influence through its coordinating role in environmental matters and its powers over customs and excise duties and sales tax. The report is very comprehensive and far-reaching, and I have picked up a number of points from reading volume I. The report makes the following point:

When alternatives to recycling are apparently cheap there is little incentive to participate in recycling. This will be the case when councils charge for garbage disposal through general rates, subject to rate pegging, and fail to pass on the full costs of disposal through `user pays' charges.
The report goes on to say:

If disposal choices are based on private costs which fail to reflect all the costs of using the community's resources, as in the case of illegal dumping, there may be a bias against the supply of recyclables.
It further states:
The use of recycled materials in manufacture depends not only on their relative costs but also on the demand for the products of the manufacturing process.

I believe that we in Australia are on the road to doing not a bad job in recycling. For example, 31 per cent of the 325,000 tonnes of aluminium consumed in Australia each year is recovered for reprocessing or exported as scrap. In regard to lead, about 36,000 tonnes or 60 per cent of consumption was recovered in 1989-90. However, 20,000 tonnes were exported as scrap in that year. About a fifth of all the copper consumed in Australia is recovered for reprocessing, equivalent to some 24,500 tonnes. Around 26 per cent of the steel consumed in this country is recovered as scrap. So a great deal of our materials are recycled and used again in Australia, which is a great achievement.

Plastics account for 8 to 11 per cent by weight of the household waste stream of Australia's three largest cities, around one million tonnes of plastic resins are consumed in Australia each year, and some 450,000 tonnes of plastic products are discarded annually. There is some concern that, while around 15 per cent of plastic waste is recovered and reprocessed, this consists mostly of industrial and commercial scrap. Only 1,000 to 1,500 tonnes or less than half of one per cent of plastic in household waste is recovered.

This report contains some other interesting facts. One relates to the recycling of disposable nappies, a matter of great concern to many people. People just throw disposable nappies in garbage cans which sit around and create a problem in terms of hygiene and in other ways. I believe that that area has to be looked at. Madam Acting Deputy President, things have changed a lot since you and I were babies and there were no disposable nappies. There is a problem there and it is something that all countries and all Australians should be looking at. Underneath the plastic, the inner or absorbent part of the disposable nappy is made up of woodchips, which are a reusable resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be severely criticising the Industry Commission in relation to this two-volume report on recycling, but before I do so I would like to say that, accepting the present economic model as an immediate market assessment, this report contains some very useful information. But it is precisely in that area that the major criticism must lie. Quite clearly, one cannot have a continuation of the present market system which simply looks at instantaneous prices and costs and determines whether materials should or should not be, or whether they can profitably be, recycled.

SPEECH.PARA: On the subject of recycling, we have to remember several things. We must remember that the materials which a modern industrial society uses can be divided roughly into potentially renewable materials, such as the food we eat, the fibre that we use in making paper and so on, and non-renewable resources such as copper, other metals, glass and so on which come from finite resources. The bottom line in all this is that we live on a finite globe and that resources are indeed finite. There are limits to the extent to which resources can be used and strict limits to the extent to which resources can be recycled. Those limits are set by the availability of energy. Energy is the primary determinant in the recycling process because energy itself can never be recycled. Energy is a non-renewable resource; once used it is gone forever. That is essentially the basis of the second law of thermodynamics.

In looking at the way in which this analysis has been done, no value has been placed on resources in situ-on non-renewable resources in the ground. One of the constant complaints of the conservation movement is that, while we assiduously measure gross domestic product and the rate at which resources are used up, which is what GDP really measures, we do not keep any measure of the capital value of resources in situ.

If we were to put a reasonable value on resources in the ground, such as lead ores, zinc ores and sand on our beaches which is mined to make glass, the way in which that material is depleted would show up in our national accounts as a reduction in the capital account and a transfer of value from the capital account to the cash flow account.

Going through these reports, one finds that no value is put on resources in situ. Therefore, all of these economic analyses contained in these reports, in terms of the environmental requirements-that, I point out, is a requirement which is placed on the Industry Commission specifically within this reference and generally under its legal charter-are quite deeply flawed.

Similarly, at the other end, while the reports repeatedly mention land fill, no consideration is given to the value which future generations may attach to land which, because it has become an area for land fill, with many of the materials being toxic, will therefore be precluded from use for other purposes. While the Commission mentions these things all of the way through, it purports to give an unbiased and comprehensive economic analysis of recycling. But it cannot do that because it accepts this very deeply flawed economic model on which our present industrial civilisation is built. If we do not redress that, we cannot ever move towards a sustainable society. Only by putting proper values on those non-renewable resources, which are finite in their sources, can we ever build a truly sustainable society.

I wish to say that the topic of this Report of the National Inquiry into Racist Violence in Australia, Racist Violence, demonstrates very clearly a very sad fact about Australian life. It is something that we cannot move away from; that is, that Australia is a racist society. Here is a document, 535 pages long, which proves it. It is a very great shame that that is the situation.

This report will be a very valuable document for those of us who wish to promote racial harmony in this country and better education about racial issue because there are so many clear examples given in it of racism in so many different areas of Australian life. It really is very important that this document is noted, that it is read and that it is considered carefully, particularly Chapter 8 `Drawing Conclusions from the Evidence', Chapter 12 `Strategies to Confront Racism' and, of course, the 67 recommendations which really ought to be noted. I hope that they will be noted by the Federal Government with great speed. There is a matter of urgency about these situations.

The Committee looked at racism in many different aspects of Australian life: towards our indigenous people, the Aboriginal people; Asian people; Middle Eastern people of Muslim extraction; Middle Eastern people of Jewish extraction and non-English speaking people.

I want to make my remarks today mostly about the Aboriginal situation because it is one that I have followed very closely. It does not mean that I am not as concerned about racism that has been directed against other Australians in the groups that I have mentioned. It is all bad and it has all got to stop.

Appendix 14 is particularly illuminating. It contains 57 pages listing some of the evidence. Many people who testified before the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission did not want their particular circumstances and names to be known, for fairly obvious reasons. They have been subject to racist attack and, therefore, were not prepared to allow their names to be published. There is a great deal of confidentiality about some of the material that went before the Commission, but there are 57 pages listing in a shorthand version, if you like, the incidents which were brought before this Commission. They are pretty horrendous.

On the topic of Australian attitudes towards our real history of contact with indigenous people, we will never have justice in this country unless we recognise the dark side of our history. That needs to be looked at in two ways. There is the proud side of the dark side of our history-that is, the Aboriginal side. Aboriginal people ought to be able to tell their own story and non-Aboriginal Australians should be encouraged to learn to appreciate and to respect Aboriginal culture. That is beginning to happen and a great deal has changed in that respect in the last 20 years.
Unfortunately, the other side, the side of violence which is perpetrated against Aboriginal people, is endemic in the community. I quote from the Commission report to highlight this:

The Inquiry considers that racism permeates the day-to-day lives of Aboriginal people either through direct acts of violence, intimidation and racist abuse, or through the more insidious process of discrimination. Discrimination in this context is particularly significant because it operates often through the threat or use of violence, and because it underpins the structural and institutionalised violence which is part of Aboriginal life.
That is a day-to-day fact of life for Aboriginal people. Any honourable senators who have contact with Aboriginal people will know that to be true. One witness said:
. . . what I am saying to you is that the very foundation, the very bureaucracies, the very infrastructure . . . is fundamentally racist . . . I guess it is called institutionalised racism . . .
A person testifying before the Committee in Perth said:

Most Nyoongah [Aboriginal] lads, or adults for that matter, when they see the police, instead of seeing them as someone there to help us in this society, people duck for cover and run away. I am making the point that racial violence is only allowed when society allows it to happen.

There are so many examples of this attitude. I do not want to be seen as having a bash at the police. I know that in most States now there are education programs to correct the imbalance of information given to police trainees about Aboriginal culture, but a great deal more needs to be done. I also recognise that often the police are faced with very difficult situations, particularly when they are called in to deal with domestic violence involving Aboriginal communities.

The report also concluded that racist attitudes and practices, both conscious and unconscious, pervade our institutions, both public and private. We need to know no more than this to conclude that this is a problem which must be addressed before it widens and further scars our society.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst there has been a deal of comment on and controversy about some of the report's findings, there has been little debate over the important recommendations it provides as indications of what should be done to deal with the problems identified. I wish simply to emphasise some of these recommendations and to call on all political parties and groups to consider supporting their implementation.

Some of the recommendations are legislative in nature, focusing on implementation or tightening of laws aimed at preventing or appropriately penalising racist harassment, racist violence and intimidation and incitement of racial hostility. Other recommendations are aimed at making our legal system more accessible and effective through, for example, guaranteeing access to interpreters well versed in the judicial system and enabling a more representative composition of juries.

The report recognises that it is vital that appropriate training for many professions, including police, educators, journalists and clerical workers, is developed to counter more effectively racist stereotypes and attitudes and to encourage greater awareness and sensitivity of cultural differences between Australians. The role of government instrumentalities is also vital. All areas which provide assistance or service to the public, such as housing, welfare, training, immigration and industry, must be administered and delivered in an anti-racist fashion. The report provides many recommendations to enable this to happen.

There are quite a number of recommendations for the media, too, in this report. I notice that, whilst the media has made much comment on the report's negative findings about the police and others, they have been strangely silent about the report's criticisms of the media. Some of the report's recommendations would not be hard to implement, and they would have a significant impact. These include: encouraging the recruitment of Aboriginal, Islander and non-English speaking journalists; developing a detailed code of practice for journalists reporting issues relating to race and ethnicity; and ensuring that cultural and inter-racial issues are included in journalists' training. I hope that the media consider adopting the report's recommendations, as this would surely help to provide a much more balanced and less sensationalist approach to the reporting of race related issues.

There is also the issue of resources. I know that it is fashionable to want to restrict government expenditure at every opportunity, yet this report shows that we have a clear responsibility to ensure that those members of our community who are subject to racial violence and vilification have access to effective support services. Currently, migrant resource centres and Aboriginal and Islander legal and community centres play a vital role in this, but their effectiveness is hampered by a lack of resources and-as this report makes quite clear-by a lack of support within government and the legal system.

I have already touched on the recommendations which call for our social structures to be more accessible to enable racial problems to be addressed more effectively. This costs nothing and may save money through greater efficiency, but the fact remains that financial support is also needed to allow those working within the affected communities to address the problem more effectively. Similarly, community relations and education programs do not exist on goodwill alone. They need a firm commitment of funding from all tiers of government. Many of the recommendations are not difficult to implement if there is the political and social will to do so. The report says:
. . . political will and leadership are crucial in addressing concerns expressed to the Inquiry . . . about the commitment of government authorities to deal with the problem.

When we consider this report in conjunction with the findings of the many reports on Aboriginal deaths in custody, it is absolutely obvious that we can no longer find excuses to delay urgent action in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the Report of National Inquiry into Racist Violence in Australia. Firstly, I believe that we owe a great debt of gratitude to the Federal Race Discrimination Commissioner, Irene Moss, and indeed the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission for placing this document before us and the community. The report, consisting of 535 pages, documents in great detail the problems that we as a society face. It is up to us now to take action to remedy these matters, which are a blot on our society.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to address briefly one particular aspect that is covered in this report-that is, the relationship of our police force with the Aboriginal population. The responsibility of the police force is to guard our civilisation and certainly to guard law and order. But I believe that the responsibility of the police force goes further: it should be our guardian, ensuring the fair treatment of all people who come in contact with the law.

Unfortunately, the evidence in this report does not bear that out. There are numerous instances where Aboriginal people have been mistreated by police in Western Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory. The time that is available to me does not permit me to go into detail but the evidence is, indeed, horrific. There is evidence of physical mistreatment, treatment that is psychologically cruel and treatment that simply disregards the human status of Aboriginal people as they are caught up in our legal system.

It is essential that we take action to remedy some of these matters. During a recent visit to Western Australia I discovered that in that State there is no independent police complaints authority. It seems to me that it is essential, on the basis of the evidence of this report alone-also on the basis of many other reports that have come from that State-that we ask the Government of that State to institute an independent police complaints authority, to ensure that people who cannot obtain justice when they have complaints about the treatment that they have received at the hands of police can do so. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901 I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 25 of 1990-91, Australian Federal Police-Efficiency and Effectiveness of Fraud Investigations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This is a report by the Australian National Audit Office entitled The Australian Federal Police-Efficiency and Effectiveness of Fraud Investigations. The report has some disturbing conclusions. I will deal with this very briefly because Senator Bishop wishes to deal with it in some detail. The major matters raised in this report include, for example, ministerial direction. The report says:
The Direction outlining priorities and objectives for the AFP is five years old. The changes that have occurred during this period warrant the Commissioner seeking a fresh directive.
As to agencies, the report goes on to state:

The ANAO reviewed the agreements for liaison and referral of fraud matters from Commonwealth agencies to the AFP and found that there was generally a lack of consistency in agreements and inadequate administration . . . the relationship between the AFP and the Agencies could be improved to ensure that the best use is being made of AFP resources. In some cases the lack of an effective relationship had impeded the investigation of serious matters. The ANAO made a number of recommendations designed to encourage co-operative and effective relationships . . . the corporate plan did not clearly direct AFP activities to the priorities indicated by the Minister. The ANAO considered there should be a clearer nexus between administrative and policy objectives.
The Auditor-General, on information systems, says:

. . . in general, the systems reviewed by the ANAO were found to be inadequate as the basis of decision making. The ANAO has recommended a series of changes that will improve the quality of management information.

. . . the ANAO noted that the AFP does not adequately direct its fraud resources toward large scale fraud which is identified as a priority by its Minister. A significant proportion of AFP resources are utilised in the investigation of fraud with relatively low value despite the recommendations of the review of fraud.

Obviously, this is ludicrous. Apart from the fact that it is obviously a misuse of resources, it is not following ministerial direction. The report continues on to staffing of investigations involving fraud under $500,000 and says:

The ANAO analysis indicated that the AFP had an excess of staff in this area. However, the ANAO also noted that the adoption of some of the recommendations and changes to legislation would require additional staff resources which would, at least in part, absorb this excess.
On the management of major fraud investigations the report says:
. . . the ANAO found that the AFP did not adequately control or supervise major fraud investigations and this may have had a negative effect on the success of investigations-
that seems to follow naturally-
The ANAO recommended the adoption of a number of measures to standardise procedures and investigative methodology.

. . . the ANAO found that there was evidence to support the view that fraud investigation units did not have adequate administrative assistance or access to technological support. The ANAO recommended a review of this area.
These are all very serious comments which are backed up later in the report. I want to raise briefly a couple of those conclusions. The Auditor-General says:
* there was evidence the `large scale' fraud investigations had not been adequately managed in terms of proper direction to junior staff or supervision of investigative activity

* although the co-operation and assistance of agencies was frequently vital to a successful police investigation, the ANAO noted situations where the lack of co-operation by Commonwealth agencies with the AFP impeded the effective investigation of serious criminal offences

* `large scale' fraud investigations frequently take a considerable period of time and in the AFP this has, on occasions, led to a high turnover of case officers. It is the view of the ANAO that staffing changes can result in inefficient or inconclusive investigations

* the ANAO noted a lack of consistency in administrative practices and a wide variation in the approach to investigations. The ANAO is of the view that an investigation methodology (as is currently observed in the NOD investigation teams) and standardised administrative procedures would greatly enhance the potential for the management of investigations . . .
Then we come to a particularly serious one-

* the ANAO was concerned at the low `success' rate in investigations and the frequently protracted period of investigation required in `large scale' fraud matters. Whilst the success of an investigation is in part outside the control of the AFP, the ANAO noted instances where the AFP may not have taken all the available steps to conclude an investigation. It was also apparent that some matters were left for significant periods whilst (presumably) higher priority matters were investigated. These delays would not improve the likelihood of a successful outcome for investigations.
These matters, along with the various recommendations, are of some substance. I think we should commend the Auditor-General for his comments.

In conclusion, however, there is one question we have to resolve: what is the estimated level of fraud against the Commonwealth? There have been suggestions that the identified value of fraud against the Commonwealth has been in multi billions of dollars. In 1986 the Special Minister of State referred to cited estimates of the value of fraud against the Commonwealth ranging between $1 billion a year and as much as $30 billion a year. He went on to say that these assessments could be exaggerated. Either we are pursuing only a very small proportion of these matters, or the earlier estimates of the value of fraud against the Commonwealth are significantly overstated. The identified value of fraud against the Commonwealth, according to the Auditor-General, is something like $55m a year. Of this figure, prosecutions involving fraud offences valued at $42m were completed in respect of matters referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions by the AFP. This represented prosecutions involving large scale fraud valued at $38m and prosecutions of other fraud valued at $4m. As I mentioned earlier, I do not intend to spend much time on this as Senator Bishop wishes to proceed with the matter. I commend the Auditor-General for this most useful report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Audit Report No. 25 1990-91 on the Australian Federal Police, I too would like to commend the Auditor-General for the manner in which he addresses some very important points. There are two with which I would like to deal specifically-the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and the privacy legislation. The Cash Transaction Reports Agency and the legislation which created that Agency and determined how it was to operate were heralded by the Government as being an important tool to detect major crime, following Costigan's idea that one should follow the money trail. Yet, this report from the Auditor-General says that all those sorts of aspirations and hopes that were held for this legislation simply are not being fulfilled.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General found that there were several aspects which required his criticism. I will deal firstly with 2.4.9, where the Auditor-General said:
At the time of audit all reports referred to the AFP by the CTRA related to suspicious transactions and the majority involved transactions with a value of less than $10,000.

The figure of $10,000 was originally touted as being a crucial sum-that it was this amount and amounts above that which would lead us to major criminals. In relation to the concentration on suspicious transactions, the Auditor-General said:

As a result the AFP was investigating matters that were not high priority in terms of the Ministerial Direction. It was also conducting the initial investigation of possible fraud occurring in agencies. This activity was identified in recommendations of the review of fraud as the prime responsibility of the agencies.

The Auditor-General pointed out that the result of all of this meant that, in a way, people who were reported pursuant to this legislation via this agency were treated in a discriminatory way as opposed to those people who were investigated by the agency which had the responsibility for the area where the fraud was taking place. The Auditor-General went on to say:

The current arrangements will lead to inequities in the treatment of cases of fraud. It was accepted by Government that minor instances of fraud should be dealt with administrative remedy wherever appropriate. Under current CTRA legislation the AFP must deal with the matter itself and, as it is unable to apply administrative sanctions-
it simply has no power-
either it will not investigate the matters, due to other priorities, or alternatively it will prosecute them.
That same matter, if dealt with by the agency responsible, could have been dealt with in an administrative way. The report continues:
The ANAO is of the opinion that this inconsistency in the treatment of routine instances of fraud arising from CTRA reports should be addressed.

I will deal with the need to address that question and compare it with the requirements of the privacy legislation and the problems that are posed by accepting the Auditor-General's suggestion that perhaps minor matters should be able to be referred to the agency, that is, that they should breach the Privacy Act 1988 principle 11 and pass on information so that it can be dealt with in an administrative matter. The worry I have is that that opens up a loophole in the privacy legislation which, in my view, is far from satisfactory anyway.
Under the heading, `Cash Transaction Reports Agency' on the question of privacy, the Auditor-General says:

The AFP has had some difficulty in maintaining confidentiality of the source of the referrals. Legal opinion has been sought to determine whether the method of dealing with CTRA reports was in breach of the privacy provisions of the Act. The opinion of the Counsel General was that the AFP was acting to enforce Commonwealth law and was able to reveal certain information in respect of these enquiries to an agency (such as the Department of Social Security) where the referral related to that agency. However, the AFP was required to retain control of the investigation.

Here we have a dilemma in that we have two possible interpretations of a privacy legislation which was designed to be the safety valve to prevent the misuse of information that has been gathered pursuant to the Cash Transaction Reports Agency and indeed other legislation.
Under the section headed, `Privacy legislation', on page 16 of the report, the Auditor-General sets out a very useful paragraph where he simply says that:

Privacy legislation was enacted in 1988 and established a number of privacy safeguards for the treatment of information. In general terms, the principles deal with the methods of collection of personal information, the storage and security of personal information, the accuracy of records, the use of personal information and access to their own personal information by individuals.

Privacy principle 11 of the Privacy Act, which restricts the disclosure of information, subject to five exceptions, is then set out. Exception 1(e) of that principle relates to the disclosure and says that it is:
. . . reasonably necessary for the enforcement of the criminal law . . .

The word `reasonably' was put there for a deliberate purpose. This has been interpreted by the Privacy Commissioner to require that a reasonable suspicion has been formed that an offence has been committed.

But this interpretation is apparently not one shared by the Attorney-General's Department, which has expressed the view that law enforcement includes activities of detection as well as investigation. We already have, by way of opinion from Crown law officers, the exceptions whereby people are forbidden to share or hand over information, which has been gathered pursuant to various pieces of legislation, to other agencies.

In the course of the recent Estimates hearings, we have heard many instances-they are starting to form a growing list-of concerns where the privacy legislation is being breached. For example, we have heard that officers within the Australian Taxation Office are creating and selling tax file numbers, and that evidence given before the Independent Commission Against Corruption in New South Wales has shown that customs officers have been to information swapping parties and broken the law by handing over information. We have heard reports from the Auditor-General that security in the Tax Office is far from satisfactory. As well as those blatant breaches, we have identified in this most useful report of the Auditor-General definitions of the provisions concerning privacy being broadened and extended to the detriment of the protection of privacy of individuals.
The Auditor-General says:

The interpretation is important to the AFP, in that it directly influences its capacity to detect and investigate fraud (and other matters). The trade-off between intrusive law enforcement investigative methods and legitimate privacy interests requires a balance to be set. A narrow interpretation will limit the extent to which the AFP can detect and investigate fraud matters, but to allow unrestricted access to information may raise legitimate concerns over privacy.

These are matters which the Government must address. Every time the question of privacy and worries of the type that I have just demonstrated in the Estimates committees are raised, we have been given a bland assurance that it really is all right and that we do not have to worry because we have the Privacy Commissioner and legislation. Clearly, as the calendar rolls on, we see more and more examples of things simply not being all right in protecting privacy.

The final point I raise concerning this report deals with finance directions. The simple statement of what financial directions are and how they are required to be obeyed is important. Again and again we have seen-usually deriving from Estimates hearings where we are able to ask questions and elicit answers-many occasions when departmental officers breach finance regulations. The most blatant example recently concerned the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce where we heard the most amazing statement from Dr Bell, a very senior officer in that Department, when breaches of the Audit Act were pointed out to him. In one case an appropriation had been made for one purpose and departmental officers had simply taken the money from that appropriation and used it for a non-appropriated purpose. When queried about those matters, his answer was simply that they are only technical breaches and that his Department has a difference of opinion with the Auditor-General. I am afraid that that will just not do. Officers of the Commonwealth are obliged and required to obey the law.
The definition or statement that the Auditor-General sets out at page 18 is most useful to have. Various departmental officers ought to learn it off by heart. It says:

The Department of Finance (DoF) issues Finance Directions that provide the basis for control in the administration of financial matters. The Directions establish the set of rules that are required to be observed when dealing with Commonwealth revenues or expenditures. The Audit Act requires conformity with these Directions.

I consider that this report of the Auditor-General is a most useful one. I dare say it will be discussed widely and could well have important ramifications for amending legislation which we may subsequently see.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that this report demonstrates very clearly the value of the work done by the Auditor-General. The picture that is emerging from the report is one of an organisation or agency where the type and volume of work being done has changed quite substantially yet the organisation, as bureaucratic organisations tend to, has continued on its merry way using methods which are now totally inappropriate. In 1986-87 the agency-the Australian Federal Police (AFP)-in this area had a total of 43,700 referrals on fraud matters.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet as a result of direct bank payments to recipients as well as a recommendation by the review of systems for dealing with fraud on the Commonwealth that agencies investigate and prosecute fraud themselves and generally refer only those cases of a more complex nature and larger in scale to the AFP, that volume fell to 9,500 in 1989-90. However, the report found that the AFP had continued to devote a large proportion of its resources to the investigation of low value fraud. More than 50 per cent of the matters investigated by the AFP had a value of less than $1,000 and more than 80 per cent had a value less than $5,000.

We should also note the request, which is one of the most important ones in this report, that the very objectives of the organisation should be reviewed since the last direction obtained from the then Special Minister of State is now five years old and several matters-in fact a large number of events-have taken place. I shall mention a couple of those.

The National Crime Authority (NCA) was formed under the relevant Act in 1984 and has indeed been active in matters such as drugs and organised crime, which had been identified as high priorities for the AFP. As we know, under its new chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, the National Crime Authority will also carry out substantial work in the white collar crime area. Yet it would appear that at this stage no clear definition of the potential overlap and how these agencies will work together has been arrived at.

As a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority I am particularly interested in this matter, and I trust that this is one area that will receive urgent attention as both the effectiveness of the NCA and the Australian Federal Police could be called into question unless their respective roles are clarified. The other major area which is listed in the report and which would impinge on the work of the AFP is the formation of the Australian Securities Commission which has been established, giving the Commonwealth much wider responsibilities in respect of corporate law.

I do not wish to repeat the comments made by Senator Michael Baume about the details of the report but in the recommendations there are three matters which the AFP has not noted with support. An interesting pattern has developed, and can be seen in the list of recommendations, where the AFP supports each recommendation, with the exception of those three, sometimes with an addendum. But there are three which the AFP has left without such a comment and one cannot help wondering whether the AFP is prepared to cooperate in the implementation of such recommendations.

One of them is recommendation No. 3, which suggests that criteria be developed for inclusion in the agreements with other agencies. The AFP, while in general terms supporting the recommendations, puts in a proviso saying that the criteria should not necessarily be determined in terms of the size of the complaint but that several other criteria should be considered. In this respect clearly the AFP is at variance with the Auditor-General and some further work needs to be done. Recommendation No. 19, which indicates that the AFP should act to ensure that performance indicators are consistent and indeed reliable measures of AFP activity, does not receive any comment of support from the AFP either. One can only wonder why such a measure, which would go to the efficiency measurement of the AFP, is apparently left without agreement by the AFP. The Auditor-General recommends that the AFP adopt procedures to ensure full and timely review of case files by managers during and at the completion of investigation. Once again we find that there is no supporting comment made by the AFP.

There is a statement in the report that inter-agency agreements have not only been difficult to conclude-and two are mentioned in that category: the Australian Customs Service and the Telecom agreements-but that there is at least one exception, the Department of Defence, where, despite consistent efforts, such an agreement has not been concluded. This must be a matter of concern because, clearly, the objective of the AFP to investigate fraud in Commonwealth government agencies cannot proceed with efficiency unless such agreements are concluded speedily.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO ROMANIA, GREECE, ANZAC PARLIAMENTARY GROUP AND THE NORTH ATLANTIC ASSEMBLY, NOVEMBER 1990

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Romania, Greece, Anzac Parliamentary Group and the North Atlantic Assembly of November 1990. It was my privilege to be selected for this delegation and it became my pleasure to be a part of it. The first country which we visited was Romania, and I intend to speak at some length about our visit to that country. It was a most important visit. We were the first parliamentary delegation to visit Romania since the overthrow of the Ceausescu regime and since that country moved from communism towards some form of democracy and held its elections.

SPEECH.PARA: There are in my view some lessons for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans and the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, who respectively are sending people to China and Bougainville to conduct inquiries. For the week we were in Romania we conducted substantial inquiries. I say to those Ministers that there are major difficulties in making adequate inquiries in any foreign country unless one speaks the language and is aware of the subtleties of language passing backwards and forwards among people. There are major difficulties in any event in making an assessment of a particular country in a relatively short period.

I draw attention to the number of times that Australians complain about some visitor to this country who, having been here for five minutes, proceeds to make profound statements about what is wrong with the country, what we ought to be doing to it and all the rest of it. That is taken with a grain of salt in Australia. That is why I say that what our delegation says in relation to Romania needs to be taken with a degree of caution. With all due respect to Senator Gareth Evans's delegation to China and Senator Robert Ray's delegation to Bougainville, those reports will have to be treated very cautiously. In particular, I urge them to consider sending someone along who speaks the language as a native or an interpreter who is able to understand the language as a native. At least that will provide us with that advantage.

Nevertheless, we made this investigation into Romania. One of our major aims was to assess the changes that had taken place since the fall of Ceausescu, including whether democracy in Romania has a future; the state of its economy; whether it has learned about human rights, especially regarding the Hungarian minority; whether it realised there was a relationship between economic aid and human rights; and Romania's attitude towards the so-called miners' revolts on 13-15 June, which were in fact riots, allegedly involving miners allegedly called in by President Iliescu.

We were welcomed with great generosity and warmth and spoke with a wide variety of people-from parliamentarians, both Government and Opposition, Ministers, bureaucrats, media and welfare workers to ordinary people. There were no limits, although it must be remembered of course that our itinerary had been set by our hosts. As I mentioned, we did not speak the language. We formed a number of tentative-I emphasise the word tentative-conclusions.

The people of Romania have been repressed for longer than anyone alive can remember. They have suffered the tyranny of monopoly or oligopoly rule for centuries. Therefore, it is no surprise that they have little understanding of democracy. Likewise, after nearly 50 years of communist domination, their knowledge of free market economies is at best superficial and theoretical. They talk about the pain of moving into a market economy situation, but they are already suffering great deprivation. What further pain could these people put up with without revolting again? Could a democratic government maintain office while it was inflicting such pain upon its own people? It is interesting to make a comparison of the achievements of Chile under the dictatorship of Pinochet and that of other countries in South America which operate under elected governments.

The impression of the whole delegation was that the elected parliamentarians, the Ministers and the bureaucrats are determined to make the transition to a Western style democracy and to a free market. We had many opportunities for confidential conversations with members of the opposition parties and individuals, but there were few major complaints. I recall one complaint from a citizen which demonstrated a total lack of understanding of democracy at work. This woman was from the Transylvania area and acted as our interpreter. We discussed her views on what was happening in Romania.

Her bitter complaint was about the Opposition, not about the Government. She thought that the Opposition should appreciate the Government's difficulties and should support its efforts. She said, `After all, this Government is really doing its best and the Opposition should shut up and support the Government in what it is endeavouring to do'. I could not help but think of the Australian Labor Party; that is what it would have us do. It was a total demonstration of what happens under a one party communist-controlled system. Here was an intelligent woman in her thirties, an interpreter who spoke a number of languages, who had so little idea of democracy that she thought that the Opposition ought to be blamed because it was not helping the Government out.

Some Opposition members of parliament told us publicly that they believed there had been some fraud in the 1990 elections. The estimate of one of them-he was said to be the extremist Opposition member-was that the maximum amount of fraud was about 15 per cent. However, he and all of the Opposition members agreed that whatever fraud had occurred made no difference to the result. Romania has a parliament which has, in effect, been elected for the purpose of drawing up a constitution. That is its aim.

The Government is very concerned to ensure that the constitution requires full disclosure. We discussed with government members and with one of the legal committees the sort of terminology that might be used. We discussed with them the difficulties that a written constitution containing expressions of freedom will bring about for a government. But they were determined that its constitution would set out the fundamental principles of freedom. At the end, the overwhelming feeling of the delegation was that the parliamentarians-both Government and Opposition members-who had been elected in May last year following the overthrow of Ceausescu are determined to adopt a fair, open and democratic constitution. That is what they are working on. Although we should be cautious in our conclusions about their ability to adopt such a constitution, we feel they were fair dinkum about it and applaud them for it. It is expected that the constitution will be finalised and new elections held no later than the middle of 1992.

We did discuss the so-called miners' revolt with everyone-parliamentarians, Ministers, bureaucrats and ordinary people. We concluded that the lesson-that they really cannot treat their people in a way where a group of alleged miners comes in to beat up their fellow citizens-had been learned. Of course, our conclusion may be invalid. We think that the message has been learned. As I say, that conclusion may be invalid: if the pain of reform becomes too great, as I indicated before, that could lead to a further revolt. Alternatively, the basis for our premise-that is, what we were told had happened-may prove to be invalid. The worry is that the allegedly dismantled Securitate-the security police-may have been involved in the riots; we do not know. We certainly were not told that they were, but subsequent reports and investigations by other people have indicated that this is a possibility. If that is so, I am sure that the approach of the Securitate next time will be much more subtle than that of June last year.

Our wide-ranging discussions involved both economic and political reforms. I have been talking about political reforms. Moving to the economic discussions, the country and its people are impoverished. They desperately need the West's capital, expertise and technology. They have some resources and they have no foreign debt. Ceausescu was concerned about paying off the foreign debt. He forced the people to work six and sometimes seven days a week for the state to ensure that the state had no debts and built him a marvellous palace. This marvellous palace, situated in the heart of Bucharest, has not been completed. The people are impoverished. They have little in the way of efficient infrastructure. Membership of the European Community and a free market seems like a golden apple to many of them.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that I am delighted to see you in the chamber while I am addressing the Senate about the report of the delegation to Romania because you went to Romania to observe the May 1990 elections and reported to the Senate on that visit and you were kind enough to brief our delegation before we left for overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: Before the dinner break I was saying that this country is quite poverty stricken and, to many of the people of Romania, membership of the European Community and a free market seems like some sort of golden apple. The truth of the matter is that, although they say they understand that the transition will be painful, I fear they really do not understand the depth of the pain that they will have to suffer-especially as they are already in a situation of great deprivation. I fear that further pain might lead, ultimately, to another revolution of the people and/or possibly to another dictatorship which might arise to take over in those circumstances.

The problems of the country are enormous. But I say to any people who are thinking of investing there that I think there are enormous opportunities. I understand that a number of British people have already invested in Romania. In particular, I would urge Australians of Romanian origin who speak the language and understand the problems and who have been successful business people in Australia to look at the opportunities for sound investments in their former country.

I shall be brief in mentioning orphans and health care. I refer the Senate to the report. Members of the delegation did visit two of the orphanages and also met Stephen Toma and Dr Barbara Bascour of World Vision. These people estimate that up to 9 per cent of Romania's orphans are recoverable to normality and they are seeking help to achieve this. It is a massive problem. It was also brought to our attention that the physically and mentally handicapped people of Romania were living in terrible conditions and the plight of the aged was equally dreadful. I refer the Senate to the report for further details about those problems. By contrast, Ceausescu's palace, Romania House, stands as a monument to an egotistical monster.

Romania is grey and cold, especially in Bucharest in November. Life is grim; survival is a fight. There were no smiling faces and little animation, except at demonstrations, and most people still carry with them a sense of fear. For example, we heard a story of a fellow who wanted to sell his pig. Previously under Ceausescu the sale of animals was forbidden-a person did not really own an animal; it belonged to the state. This fellow apparently went to some authority and asked whether he could sell his pig. He was told that, yes, he could just go and sell it. He said, `Give me a bit of paper that says I can sell it'. That is the sort of fear which still existed in 1990 in this country.

Bucharest is like many other old European cities, with large squares and some beautiful old buildings. Unfortunately, they are decaying and the recent bullet holes do not help. One wonders when this country will ever have sufficient resources to be able to restore those buildings to the condition they were in many years ago.

The only spark of life and animation that we saw was when four members of our delegation were caught on the edge of a demonstration. That was a grim and purposeful affair. Mr Peter Duncan, who apparently has some knowledge of what happens at demonstrations, recognised immediately what was going on and flashed us past this group of people. My wife and I were somewhat casual about it and did not recognise how grim and purposeful it was until we were caught in the middle of it.

By contrast, our hosts, guides, and interpreters could not have been warmer or more welcoming. Our whole delegation was moved and encouraged by the Romanians' endeavour to democratise their country. But we must keep in mind their history of tyrannical rule and understand that it is just as difficult to unlearn the lessons of the past as it is to learn lessons for the future.

I now turn to Greece. The delegation arrived in Athens in the evening and the contrast with Bucharest was incredible. We had been in Romania for a week and we had forgotten that there were no lights. In the hotel it had been practically dark because only one globe was alight every now and then and the wattage was about 20 or 15 watts or less. There were few lights in the streets. Then we arrived in Athens in the evening. It was just unbelievable. We had come from a grim city of people in desperate straits who were fighting to survive, to a noisy, bustling, thriving city of the West-it was a bit like coming home. There were lights everywhere, traffic, noise, people laughing and talking, and butter-it was the first butter we had tasted for a week.

What was not like home was the unbelievable pollution from the vehicle exhaust gases. I tried leaving my hotel window open but at one o'clock in the morning I had to get up and shut it because I could not cope with the fumes coming up from the square outside my hotel. A walk around Athens makes one's eyes burn and jogging is out-one runs out of oxygen if one tries to jog.

TALK.START.PARA: —I won't do it, you have convinced me.

—Senator Ray says that he would not jog, and neither would I. I am not really being any more critical of Athens then I am of any other city in the world because on the way to Athens I went to Seoul and the pollution is just as bad there. I know that it is also as bad in Tokyo, New York, London, Paris and Rome. I really do believe some of the environmentalists of this world should have a look at this problem and join with people like me in saying, `This world desperately needs electric motor cars for our capital cities'. That may mean we have to have nuclear power stations.
—No!
—No!

—I know that is a problem for people on my left, but if they went to those cities they would see how desperately we need electric motor cars which would stop polluting the atmosphere with these foul fumes which come from motor vehicles of all sorts.

SPEECH.PARA: Our very worthwhile meetings and discussions in Greece are detailed in the report, but I do not want to go into them. I want to refer specifically to two meetings that we had-one with the President of the Pasok Party, Mr Andreas Papandreou, and the other with Mr Charilaos Florakis, the Chairman of the Coalition Left and Progress Party, which is in fact the Communist Party of Greece. I think its membership comprises nine or 10 members of parliament, so it is a fairly solid sort of Communist Party. There are very few Communists.

TALK.START.PARA: —Almost as many as the Democrats.

—More than the Democrats. I have to be honest and say that I did not want to see Mr Papandreou. We had to go to see him at his home. He is, of course, subject to prosecution and he is living almost a hermit's life. It meant a drive through the streets of Athens for about three hours in heavy traffic and, as far as I was concerned, it was all for what? To go to meet an elderly gentleman who was yesterday's man. Let me assure the Senate that I was wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked him the first question-a simple question-would he like to talk to us about the Gulf? For an hour and a half he held us absolutely spellbound about the crisis in the Gulf. One has to appreciate that at that stage the debate was about: would there be a war? How long would it take? How many people would be killed? How many of our service people in the United Nations coalition forces would be killed? Would there be a war or would Hussein finally see the light and give in?

As I say, this fellow held us spellbound. Of course, he knows Saddam Hussein personally. He was able to predict Hussein's reactions for us. He went further and, for the first time among the people I had been speaking to, he started to talk to us about what would happen after the war. There was no question, of course, but that the United Nations forces would win. He then started to raise with us the Kurdish problem-what would we do about the Kurds in the northern part of Iraq? What would we do with the problems in Turkey? He raised those difficulties with us.

He also predicted that Hussein would not leave Kuwait without setting fire to the oilfields. He raised the sights of the whole delegation to beyond the war, and this was before the Gulf war started. All of his predictions have come true. He demonstrated that sort of leadership which makes one understand why he was the Prime Minister of Greece for a period of time and why he is still the leader of the Pasok Party.

The other fellow was Mr Florakis, who is an old communist warhorse with an engaging personality. He was a personal friend of Joe Stalin, and there would be few of them still around in this world. Mr Florakis still believes-because I raised it with him-that the Soviet march on Hungary and Czechoslovakia was an internal matter and not for outsiders to criticise. It will not surprise the Senate to know that he and I clashed, but we ended up with mutual respect for each other and, on my part, a sneaking admiration for an old political warhorse that I recognised the moment I started to talk to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you tell him you knew Menzies?
—I hate to tell Senator Ray, but I really did not know Sir Robert Menzies. I might mention that Mr Florakis was one of the original Greek guerillas fighting in Greece during the Second World War.

SPEECH.PARA: There are strong bonds between Australia and Greece and yet Greece is only our forty-eighth trading partner. In the report we make recommendations about trying to improve this situation but, personally, I fear that Greece has so much to gain from membership of the European Community that trade with Australia will always be of minor importance.

The reception afforded to our delegation was first-rate; we were cared for wonderfully well. For most of us it was our first trip to Greece, and we will remember for a long time the wonders of ancient Greece that we were privileged to see.

TALK.START.PARA: —And an island?

—Yes, we did go to an island and it was most enjoyable for a weekend. As a matter of fact, the leader of the delegation sought time off from a function that we were attending on the island in order to make a telephone call to his electorate.
—It wasn't Con Sciacca?
—That was Mr Sciacca. I gather that that telephone call received considerable publicity back in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: We flew to London to participate, we thought, in two forums: the Anzac Westminster Parliamentary Group and the thirty-sixth annual session of the North Atlantic Assembly. However, unfortunately, the Anzac Group was destined not to meet on this occasion because on the day we arrived the Prime Minister of England, Margaret Thatcher, resigned. There was parliamentary turmoil and the delegation was privileged to be invited to be in the Strangers' Gallery of the House of Commons on the day she resigned.

Not one of us will ever forget the magnificent parliamentary performance of Mrs Thatcher on that day. Never have I seen such strength and sheer raw courage, notwithstanding how she must have been feeling. She came into the chamber for Prime Minister's Question Time, which goes on for just over 15 minutes. She took it and she was absolutely brilliant. When it finished, she slumped in her chair and I looked at her knowing that within the next two hours she had to come back into the chamber to defend a censure motion. I could not see how she could possibly recover sufficiently to come back in.

However, she came back into the chamber and she gave us 30 minutes of an absolutely brilliant speech. She demolished the Opposition and she demolished her own side, I might say. She demonstrated beyond any shadow of doubt that she was the most able parliamentarian in the House of Commons on that day. It was a performance that all of us will long remember and I might say that it impressed the Australian Labor Party members of the delegation as much as it impressed me.

The North Atlantic Assembly is the parliamentary forum of the North Atlantic Alliance. Until this visit, Australia and Japan were the only non-member countries granted observer status and we had been pushing for a greater participating role. This time, after some deliberation, the standing committee of the Assembly afforded non-member parliamentary delegations, including Australia, a more active role. We were permitted to take a seat at the committee tables with a right to speak both in committee debates and plenary sessions but, of course, with no voting rights.

In addition to granting these rights to Australia and Japan, the Assembly granted the same rights to the eastern European former communist countries, with the notable exception of Romania. The so-called miners revolt in Romania has meant that Romania is not trusted. Its elected parliamentarians were not given the acknowledgment and encouragement that we thought they deserved, and we made the point that we thought that they deserved recognition to the President and others of the Assembly.

The Australian delegation was well received and participated well. Participation in this Assembly is worthwhile and should be nurtured. Continuity of attendance is of great importance because that will increase our ability to have our views heard, as well as ensuring that the Assembly takes a global perspective and not just a Euro-American one. I do not know how we overcome this because on both sides of the chamber we swap the delegates for each of these Assembly visits. The result is that we are always new delegates who are feeling our way, instead of delegates who know the people there and who can push their views more strongly, perhaps, because of their knowledge of the procedures.

I would like to thank the North Atlantic Assembly for its hospitality, which was very good. All of us especially enjoyed the reception which we had at Buckingham Palace, the chance to have a look at Buckingham Palace and the chance to meet and speak with the Queen.

Finally, I would like to report that the delegation was particularly harmonious. Incredibly, we spent most of our spare time together even after a month of living in close contact with each other. For this I would like to thank the other members of the delegation: the leader, Con Sciacca, and Tina Sciacca; David and Monique Connolly and their son Ellis; Arch and Cathy Bevis; Peter and Julie Duncan; Rod and Aldona Sawford; Bruce and Cynthia Goodluck, who were with us only briefly because Bruce was unwell; and, of course, my wife Willie. The secretary of the delegation deserves a special mention for her unfailing good humour, her enthusiasm and her ability to get the job done. I say a very sincere thank you to Anne Hazelton.

It was a most informative and worthwhile trip. Romania was an education. Seeing a beautiful country with so many people in such desperate straits touched us all. It also made us more aware of our great good fortune in having freedom and democracy handed to us without bloodshed or years of struggle and deprivation. Greece, the cradle of democracy, has her economic problems as we have, but the contrast with Romania and, indeed, the rest of eastern Europe is like life and death. Greece is also a member of the European Common Market and we received a sympathetic hearing for our trading problems with the Common Market body. Likewise, in London, the delegation made known the interests of Australia in the many levels of discussion that took place there. I thank the Senate for allowing me to attend this delegation.
