SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am continuing my remarks from 17 April on this subject of uranium concentrate and the payments that should be made by companies, particularly for the clean-up operations. This applies particularly to the Office of the Supervising Scientist attached to the Ranger uranium mine. The point needs to be re-emphasised that those of us who are concerned about the environmental impact of the uranium industry believe that all uranium mining, including Roxby Downs at the moment, which is the only other operating mine, should come under the auspices of the Office of the Supervising Scientist and that the companies involved should pay for the operation of that Office and that the Office should have more teeth to be able to make prosecutions rather than just recommendations as is the present situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I then went on to talk about the present expansion of the uranium industry debate which is going on in the Australian Labor Party at the moment in the run-up to the centenary conference of the Labor Party in Hobart in June. I had mentioned that Mr Kerin's famous letter, leaked and very widely publicised, was flawed in many different respects. I went through the five different points and I think adequately showed that the arguments Mr Kerin put forward just do not stand up.

In the time remaining to me in this debate I want to move on to a couple of other issues connected with this possible expansion of the uranium industry in this country. One of those which are outstanding is the question of insurance. This is a very difficult, dicey question for insurance companies globally as they try to grapple with the problems which can be faced by them in terms of compensation claims relating to the nuclear industry. I am indebted for some of these remarks to Greenpeace which has put together a lot of very useful lobbying material which is circulating particularly among members of the Australian Labor Party at the moment in the hope that there will not be a change in the direction of the expansion of the uranium industry.

Obviously uranium mining in Australia should not be allowed to expand as we are clearly contributing to an industry which the insurance markets believe is so dangerous that it cannot be covered in the normal way. Victims of nuclear accidents will not be properly compensated. Australia's uranium trade implicates the country in an industry which exceeds the risks of other industrial activities. To give a couple of examples-the British life insurance companies have expressed an unwillingness to offer cover to workers at the very famous Sellafield nuclear plant in that country. British Nuclear Fuels which operates the site has paid a total of $1.8m in compensation to workers who have contracted cancer. In court cases on behalf of the children of Sellafield workers, the successful insurance companies might well refuse any cover for reprocessing workers, because it is just too dangerous. The companies do not know how many cases they will be up for.

A case closer to home of which Australians need to be aware is that Indonesia has announced plans to build 12 reactors by the year 2010. I hope that this never comes to pass because it could create all kinds of problems for Australia, particularly if the plants which may not have the latest technology, or even if they do have it, run into difficulties in future years. As a close neighbour to Indonesia, we could suffer from fall-out effect as the countries in Europe suffered from the Chernobyl disaster.

As well as that there is a problem for the Labor Party because Indonesia lies in an earthquake zone and we need to know whether insurance companies in this country would be prepared to take on insurance policies with relation to any possible nuclear contamination emanating from plants in Indonesia. That is a matter that certainly needs to be considered. There are no international boundaries, as we know, and following the Soviet example, it is clear that the Soviet Union has yet to pay any compensation to the European countries which were contaminated as a result of the Chernobyl disaster. It has left them in an invidious position, and we do not want to encourage that to happen here.

Another question I want to touch on briefly is that of safeguards. It has been demonstrated very clearly in the past that safeguards are not worth the paper they are written on. We had a perfect example of that today. Senator Coulter directed a question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) about Iraq's capacity to build nuclear weapons, how much uranium it had before the war, how much it has after the war, and so on. The Minister said that there will be an International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) inspection coming up next week, so it has taken a war to force that to happen. The IAEA is promoting the nuclear industry as well as monitoring it. That has always been an unacceptable contradiction in my estimation.

The Minister went on to say that France and the Soviet Union supply to Iraq, and Australia supplies France, so that there is no guarantee that Australian uranium has not ended up in Iraq and could be used in its reprocessing and preparation for nuclear weapons. France sells to Iraq enriched uranium and it has been very clearly demonstrated by the huge row that erupted here 3 1/2 years ago that Australian uranium entering the French nuclear fuel cycle goes through a tricastin plant in particular which is directly linked into the French nuclear weapons making program; it is not restricted to use for nuclear energy.

We know-we have had it demonstrated-that the safeguards are not worth the paper that they are written on. We know that there is a direct possible link from Australian uranium through France to Iraq. I think that that is totally unacceptable. It is another very good reason for not expanding the industry.

There is always the question of waste. Mr Kerin seemed to think that the waste problem was no longer relevant. I do not know how he arrives at that conclusion because we have already got a huge problem in Australia relating to the nuclear fuel rods from Lucas Heights. There are 1,600 highly radioactive spent fuel rods in storage at Lucas Heights because the Government does not know what to do with them. I do not envy it the problem of trying to figure it out either; it is a really hard one. The last thing we want to do is to add to that problem.

Mr Kerin talked about Synroc as a possible answer, but not one country that has nuclear power has purchased the Synroc technology. Obviously, it has not been proven to the extent of being acceptable to the users. We have an enormous problem, internationally, with all levels of waste-low level waste, medium level waste and high level waste. Synroc may solve the problem to some degree, but it has not been accepted by the nuclear industry internationally as an answer to the problem. I think we have to remind the people of Australia that the end product of uranium mining is nuclear waste and, even worse than that, it could be nuclear weapons. The waste problem has certainly not been solved-not by any stretch of the imagination.

Another issue which has not been mentioned very much, certainly not by the proponents of the industry-they do not want to mention it; they want to keep it very quiet-and not even by people within the Australian Labor Party who have some misgivings about it, is the decommissioning of existing nuclear plants. There are many plants which are nearing the end of their useful lives. They become so highly contaminated, so highly radioactive, that they are not safe for workers; they are not safe to be in or around. The decommissioning of plants is something that will be increasingly on the international agenda in the next decade.

There has not been a successful device worked out for how to do that. These reactors are huge and they can be mothballed-that is, encased in massive amounts of cement-in which case we are building ghastly, ugly monuments for future generations to have to look at. There is no guarantee that mothballing in a thick layer of cement will do the trick either. We just do not know. The cost is absolutely prohibitive. Whatever way is devised to deal with this decommissioning-it has not been done yet; there is no proven tested way of dealing with it-we can be sure that the cost will be astronomic. This cost is never built into the cost of the provision of nuclear power; it is never once mentioned. It will be a huge environmental problem, adding to the existing waste problem from the smaller items that I have already mentioned, the plants themselves and, of course, the cost factor which is never taken into account. I think that is something of which we need to be very much aware.

Since speaking in the debate on 17 April, there has been a delegation of Martu people visiting Perth. They were very obviously lobbying the State politicians about their possible plight if the uranium industry were expanded in this country. The Kintyre deposit, which has been explored by CRA Ltd, is ready to go. The industry is very keen to get the go-ahead for that and it would have devastating effects on the Martu people. I want to stress again that 120 or so people travelled all the way from the Rudall River region to Perth for the protest rally about mining in national parks. The decision from the Labor Party in Western Australia to excise areas out of our three major national parks in Western Australia-Rudall River being one of them, and particularly relevant to this topic because uranium is a mineral that is up for mining there-has been really disappointing.

The decision will not only affect a national park and a dry river ecosystem and be a uranium issue; it encroaches right on to the self-determination of the Martu people from the Pangurr, Punmu and Cotton Creek communities, which have tried for the last 10 years to go back to their traditional lifestyle. They have been through all of the problems associated with being fringe dwellers-all of the negativity associated with that. They have taken themselves back to their traditional country and they deserve every bit of support. They have a dry community there, they have set up a school and they are teaching their kids their culture. Apart from the threat that they constantly feel from the insecurity of tenure that they have on their own land because of CRA's push for uranium mining there, with the conflicting signals that they are getting from the Western Australian Government about it and the uranium issue being on the agenda of the national conference they feel extremely threatened indeed. They should not have to go through that; they should be getting our full support.

I find it really puzzling. I would have thought that the results of the committee of inquiry, which is now nearly three years old and which took submissions from hundreds of people around Australia, 98 per cent of whom were against the expansion of the industry, would have been a clear enough lesson to the Labor Party not to put uranium mining on the agenda again-not to try to change this policy in the direction of expansion. I do not think the Labor Party can afford it. There are enough difficulties to deal with around the country without adding in something like this which is totally unnecessary to argue about at the centenary conference.

This certainly has a sense of deja vu about it as far as I am concerned. When I was first elected to this place in 1984 uranium mining was one of the main platforms on which I campaigned-and here we are again. It is really quite difficult to understand. I know that the Left faction is firm on this one. I trust that it will stand absolutely resolute on this one. It has caused enough angst in the Party already. I hope that the Centre Left faction does the right thing and makes it clear before conference, and certainly at conference, that this will not get a run from the delegates at this conference.

This industry is a discredited industry; it is declining internationally. I made that point in the first part of my speech a couple of weeks ago. If we needed any other reminder about the dirt and the problems that come from this industry, we needed only to look into the eyes of the Chernobyl children who were here very recently on a get well visit. It was great that they were able to come here. But those kids, and many more like them, are suffering the effects of the nuclear industry in their country. It is a morally bankrupt industry, full of lies and deceit. It is not telling the truth about the dangers, but trying to cover up all the time where there are problems. I think we should leave it well alone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991. The legislation essentially proposes to increase the export duty on uranium concentrate produced in the Alligator Rivers region in the Northern Territory from $1.15 a kilogram to $1.30 a kilogram from 21 February 1990. It is clear that this is due to increasing costs.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant to note again that the Government has chosen to levy only the Ranger uranium mine and not other companies which are attracting activity by the Office of the Supervising Scientist (OSS). For instance, the Office of the Supervising Scientist now has responsibility for the conservation zone and Coronation Hill, in particular. Yet, thus far, there is no levy upon Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) for the expenditure in that area.
I note that the second recommendation of a review of the OSS by Professor G. Taylor, set up, I think, by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in 1989, was:

The collection of the costs for the Office of the Supervising Scientist from companies in respect of the Conservation Zone be by way of an annual fee upon renewal of exploration authorities, and if mining commences, by means of a levy specified in the lease conditions.

Let me just say that one of the concerns I have is with the level of efficiency that we find in the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The Office has been subject to very considerable legitimate criticisms. It has been subject to a number of inquiries and perhaps one of the most trenchant critics is Ranger. So far, it seems to me that other than inquiries there has been no constructive change to the administration or the style of the Office of the Supervising Scientist.

Until 1989-90 something like $56.37m of taxpayers' money had been spent by the Office of the Supervising Scientist. Notwithstanding a number of recommendations from a number of inquiries, the Office continues to be based in Sydney. If my memory serves me correctly, a condition of employment of the Supervising Scientist was that he be based in Sydney. It is interesting that, I think, up until 1986-87 the Office had spent $2,650,000 in air fares alone on flights between Sydney and Darwin. At that time, the total expenditure of the Office of the Supervising Scientist was about $40m. About 8 per cent of its total costs went in air fares so that the Office of the Supervising Scientist could be located comfortably in the capital city of Sydney.

If we look at the average annual cost per employee of the OSS, we will see that it is approximately 50 per cent higher than the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation, 20 per cent higher than the national resource division of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and 28 per cent higher than the Alligator Rivers region unit of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in the Northern Territory. Notwithstanding very considerable criticisms thus far, the Government has done nothing about it, either by way of this legislation or by any other process. With Senator Parer's agreement, I seek to withdraw the second reading amendment moved by Senator Parer to the Customs Tariff (Uranium Concentrate Export Duty) Amendment Bill 1991.
Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate calls upon the Government to abolish the present three mine uranium policy noting:
(a) the huge potential loss of export income;
(b) the damaging effect on Australia's international reputation as a fair and responsible trading nation caused by the continuation of the current restrictions on the export of uranium;
(c) calls for the development of the uranium mining industry in Australia, subject to environmental considerations, appropriate safeguards and the national interest.''

Let me say from the outset that, notwithstanding the prejudices of this Government and the ideological, myopic attitude it has, nuclear energy is here to stay. Whether we have a three-mine policy, a one-mine policy or a no-mine policy, nuclear energy is simply here to stay. Twenty-nine countries have chosen to have nuclear power as an integrated and integral part of their energy resources. This group is made up of every major industrialised nation in the world. The United States of America, for instance, has 112 nuclear plants in operation. France is building a new nuclear plant every two years. Japan is to increase its electricity generated by nuclear power to 35 per cent by the year 2000. Of course, Canada has committed itself to expanding its capacity.

At the present time, the market is depressed and so are prices. For the time being, demand will be satisfied by current inventories. However, there will be a significant increase in demand in the coming period. Australia has 29 per cent of the world's reasonably assured resources, and it is capable of taking part in that very significant upturn in demand. But, of course, not only do we have a three-mine policy at the present time; we have already locked ourselves out of a number of markets, not the least being the Taiwanese market. We have locked ourselves out of the Taiwanese market because of the absurd attitude that we continue to have towards Taiwan. I understand that the general line of argument is that the Government says that it can enter into government-to-government agreements only in respect of safeguards. It does not acknowledge Taiwan as a government, so we do not export uranium to Taiwan. That does not stop the Americans, who have entered into a very satisfactory agreement in respect of safeguards, an agreement which is monitored by the International Atomic Energy Agency; and yet we find ourselves locked out because of the bizarre way that we treat Taiwan.

It is obvious to all, not least to Senator Button, that this Labor three-mine policy is based on ideological obsessions. It is spurious in its arguments, and it is now shadow-misted in red herrings. It has absolutely no foundation of logic whatsoever. Nobody seeks even to defend it on the grounds of its own merit. It is a policy driven by crude policy expediency.

In 1977, as I recall, the Labor Party policy was to oppose all uranium mining. In fact, it went further than that. In 1977 the Labor Party was saying that it would repudiate current contracts. In 1977 what the Labor Party thought did not matter much because nobody took any notice of it. It was in the wilderness; it was going to stay in the wilderness. In fact, in Western Australia it got a worse vote in 1977 than it did in 1975. But, as we got towards 1983, it became apparent that the Labor Party, the scourge of this country--

TALK.START.PARA: —Really, don't be silly. You are going overboard, aren't you?
—Senator Button is surely not seeking to defend this wretched Government of which he is unfortunately a member.
—Where have you been?

—I was sitting in my office thinking to myself, `How can I convince Senator Button to have the courage to stand up at a centennial conference and argue the position that he put privately about the absurdity of the three-mine uranium policy?'. In 1982, when it was obvious that the Government had some prospect of winning the election, of course, the policy changed. It changed to this extent: it was possible that the Government would win in Canberra and in South Australia, so a compromise deal was done. The deal was done in part because in 1982 the present Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, said:

SPEECH.PARA: No conservative Prime Minister in the history of this country will have been given a more effective weapon to stop the election of a Labor government.

That is what he said in 1982 at the Federal conference. He said that because Labor's policy at that point was not to allow export and to repudiate current contracts. So, in the crude expedient way which drives this Government, the policy was amended to allow existing contracts to remain. Presumably, it thought that they would be there forever except that, as those contracts ran out, they would not be renewed.

In respect of Roxby Downs, it was said that if Bannon got elected the deal was that the export of uranium which was mined incidentally to the mining of other minerals be allowed. How absolutely absurd. It is just like being a bit pregnant. Uranium mined is uranium mined. Whether it is mined with copper, zinc, lead or gold, it is mined. It was a crude, grubby way of not risking Bannon's defeat by knocking Roxby Downs on the head. The price of government in South Australia was Roxby Downs.

I give the Government credit for one thing: there is nothing that it will not do to hold office. On the weekend, I heard an ex-Minister of the Labor Government say that this Government was driven by power, not principles. Frankly, I thought that that was a very eloquent statement about this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have been drinking, have you?

—I hope Senator Button is not going to do a Senator Collins. What a terrible price this country has paid for this Government's expediency. As we all know, the more pragmatic, the more realistic, but perhaps no more principled Ministers of this Government, in their weaker moments, have stood up and been counted. Senator Button said something like, `It does not matter whether you come from the one-mine school or the three-mine school or the no-mine uranium school, the issue is presently an absurdity; there is no logic to it'. Senator Button was dismissive of any who thought that they could stand up and argue in support of the present policy. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has said the same sort of thing. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) said that the Government should face reality. The reality is that there is no logic in the present proposal. We are denying this country export earnings. The present policy of this Government achieves absolutely nothing; it only placates the Left.

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding the overwhelming wave of logic, we are now being told that there will be no change to the present policy. Why will there be no change to the present policy? Is it because it is impeccable in its integrity? Is it because it is the best policy for Australia? Or is it simply because it gets this Government off the hook, saves this Government from plunging itself into an imbroglio at its centennial conference? In other words, it is not because it is good for Australia; it is because it is perceived as being good for this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right. We need a few more Chernobyls.

—I cannot ignore Senator Aulich's interjection. It is so profound that it ought to appear in Hansard in due course. No doubt the Prime Minister is concerned about the quality of the debate, not the quantity of the debate. Having heard that comment, I can understand why he was driven to make sure that this matter was not on the Government's agenda. The remark by Senator Aulich represents the sort of emotional rhetoric which drives this debate; it is totally divorced and totally removed from fact. It plunges the whole debate into an area of friction.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not having a debate and we are not changing this policy, irrespective of what is good or right for Australia, simply because it is bad politics for the Government. This issue is a bit like other decisions that we are seeing pop up, such as the third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. It does not matter whether it is good for Australia or good for the economy; it does not matter whether it is logical. Because there might be one or two seats in it, we do not have a third runway.

When logic is so overwhelming that even this Government is vaguely embarrassed about it, we have a process that guarantees that two elections will be held before any decision has to be made. As we saw in the period before the last election when we were dealing with Coronation Hill, the Government, for a change, could not bring itself to do the right thing. I have no sympathy for BHP; it welches every single time it is taken to the barrier. Perhaps there is a bit of poetic justice in this issue for BHP. Irrespective of whether it is good for BHP, this Government did not have the courage to follow the obvious and apparent logic. For the time being, it sought to take this matter off the agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you really believe this stuff?

—I do not know where Senator Aulich was prior to the last election, but clearly he was not part of the political debate that was going on in this country. I do not know whether he was on an overseas excursion. In the end, the Government took this matter off the agenda because, for the time being, that seemed to diffuse the issue. Of course, it did not; the matter came back to haunt the Government. Then we had this absurd situation where the decision was not to do with Coronation Hill; it was about the wider implications of the conservation zone, which just happens to be geographically there, drawn on a map. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was poring over a map trying to find a piece of land that he could rescue from the determination to lock up what he described as `clapped out buffalo country'. So we are where we are now. The Resource Assessment Commission was meant to be the Solomon of the Labor Party. It was supposed to solve all the Labor Party's problems; of course, it did not.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister says that he governs for all Australians, that his decisions are for all Australians. That is absolutely hypocritical hyperbole. This Government governs the sectional interests that confine the pressure points to which this Government has a knee-jerk reaction. The only time we find the Prime Minister saying `I am doing what I am doing to you for your own good and I know it is hurting' is when we have had another screw-up and we have pain that we did not need-such as we have with the economy in the present recession, which we are told we need to have, in spite of the fact that for two years the Government denied a recession was occurring and was causing hurt. We finally got the recession. We were told we all needed it, it was for our own good, and we should not think that the Prime Minister would ever do this dastardly thing to the Australian people if it was not needed. Of course, we know that the truth is that the recession was driven by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You just keep attacking the Government. This is very boring.

—From time to time I get confused with the role I am supposed to have in this Parliament. I suppose that I imagine fancifully that we are on the other side. Perhaps my time frame is two years ahead of reality. We now find ourselves in a situation where it is not the environment that is causing the problem; it is the Aboriginal community-something that had not been thought of before the last election. If the Prime Minister had thought of this issue before the last election he could have saved himself a lot of pain. Suddenly, we had the Jawoyn people making a land claim application for this very area. It was rejected by the Commissioner, who said that they had no intrinsic relationship, no spiritual relationship, no historical relationship, no religious relationship-in fact, no relationship whatsoever-to the land. We now have a born-again Bula in the area. We now have a new issue which takes this difficult problem of uranium mining off the agenda for the Australian Labor Party. The Prime Minister, in his desperate squirming, is trying to tell the mining company that this should be considered as a precedent. This Government does not create precedents; every decision it makes is a new decision.
—Are you talking about platinum or uranium?

—I am talking about mining in the conservation zone generally, particularly Coronation Hill. Uranium mining would probably do less damage to the environment than would goldmining. What comes out of a goldmine would do more damage than the waste that comes out of a uranium mine.
—That gold is causing a lot of problems in Western Australia.
—Senator Button is right, it certainly has caused a lot of problems in Western Australia for those who have been dealing in it or for those who have got it and should not have it.
—We will support that there should be no mining at Coronation Hill when you move that way.

—I shall not be moving that way because I can find no compelling, logical argument to do so. The newly found Jawoyn people now have an objection. Of course, mining will not affect the environment in any significant way. The Resource Commission has said that. The truth is that for those who do not want mining in Kakadu it does not really matter what the argument is as long as mining is stopped. It does not matter whether the argument is the environment, the nuclear cycle or the Aboriginal problem. The sad thing about this debate is that it is totally debased, totally intellectually barren. There are very few people who will stand up and use their own arguments; they will use everybody else's arguments. That is the sad thing about debates of this nature in the Parliament. One cannot come to grips with them because invariably one finds that one is not debating the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: In speaking to my amendment in particular, I conclude by saying that I find this one of the sorry and sad episodes in Australian politics. It shows a government driven by factions, unable to make the proper decisions, unable and unprepared to make decisions in the best interests of Australia; but purely basing its decisions and determinations on what it judges to be its own best interests. As I am concluding, I am inspired because I have now found Senator Button's comments in an article in Australian Business. The article reads:

Minister Button is also scathing. ``Whether one supports the `none' or `more' schools of thought (on mining),'' he writes, ``Australia's present practice of `some but not too much' seems quite incongruous.''
That is a very gentle and delicate way of putting it. A much more forceful way is to say it is hypocritical rubbish and it has no justification except in the bowels of the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have come into this debate at a late stage. It is so sad to see Senator Crichton-Browne upset. If ever I have heard a speech in the Senate by an upset person, it was his tonight. Probing his memory-like Hotspur summoning spirits from the vasty deep-Senator Crichton-Browne invented all of these marvellous quotations from people like myself; but when he actually got the quotations in his hand they were nothing like the quotations he referred to in his speech. All that added to his sadness: his sadness about uranium; his sadness about Coronation Hill; his sadness about his ability to recall quotations; and his sadness about the quotations that he actually found.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the debate. Let me say at the outset that I do not want to deal at any length with the question of the Government's policy on uranium. It is not an appropriate subject for the present debate in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not read my amendment. You are obviously deficient to that extent.

—The fact that Senator Crichton-Browne has moved an amendment does not make it an appropriate topic for debate. The simple point I want to make about that is that Australia has a long and well-established reputation as a reliable long term supplier of energy resources, including uranium, to many of its major trading partners.
—Senator Button, your Government threatened to negate the contracts. How can you stand there and say that in all honesty?
—I referred to interruptions. There was a period in which there was some slight hiatus, but it was not an interruption to supply.
—You threatened to.
—That is an uncharitable view.
—From 1977 that was your policy, almost until you were elected in 1983. You were going to repudiate current contracts.

—No, Senator. Perhaps I had better give the honourable senator some text of the history of the matter. Tomorrow night when he is sitting quietly in his room, he could read the history of this debate. Australia continues to meet the energy needs of those countries to which we have supplied resources in a responsible way. Irrespective of whether the Government chooses to retain or change its current policy, we will continue to live up to that responsibility.
—Ha, ha!
—It is true, Senator.
—What modest expectations you have, Senator Button.
—There is nothing wrong with modest expectations.
—We have one-third of the world's known low-cost reserves, yet we produce one-tenth; Canada has one-tenth and produces one-third.

—There is nothing wrong with modest expectations. Senator Crichton-Browne himself has revealed tonight, in a mood of sadness, that he has enormous expectations-indeed, long held fantasies-about where he sits in this place. We have modest expectations in respect of our ongoing capacity to supply the energy market.
—Why don't we sell it to Taiwan?
—I cannot answer that off the cuff. Probably, the Americans would not let us; they do not let us sell wheat to Taiwan.
—What do you mean the Americans won't let us?

—I think I had better get on with the topic. Senator Crichton-Browne has spoken for a very long time. I want to deal with a few of the points made by other honourable senators. Senators Parer, Tambling, Macdonald and Brownhill all raised the question of whether government export duty is discriminatory. The Government is anxious to ensure that environmental costs are equitably shared and, of course, the present arrangements of levying the tax only on operating mines in the Alligator Rivers area has some shortcomings which are acknowledged by the Government. These will be addressed in the Government's consideration of the Taylor review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. There may be some concern about delays in implementation of that review, but the question of equity will be addressed in that context.

SPEECH.PARA: Senators Tambling and Macdonald raised the relevance of the Office of the Supervising Scientist at the Ranger mine. It is not just a role of the supervising scientist to conduct research relevant to solving mining engineering problems of the companies. It would not be appropriate for taxpayers' money to be used in a way that directly benefits those companies. Rather, research of the Office of the Supervising Scientist is summarised in the 1989-90 annual report, which was tabled in the Senate in December last year.

One or two matters were raised by Senator Vallentine to which Mr Kerin has asked me to respond. Senator Vallentine made some wide-ranging criticisms of Mr Kerin, personally and of his views expressed in a letter to colleagues. I want to refer briefly to some of those criticisms. I refer to those criticisms with some difficulty since Senator Vallentine's remarks were merely a recitation of several assertions and misrepresentations contained in an ill-informed document of Greenpeace, which purported to respond to Mr Kerin's views. Mr Kerin believes that the Greenpeace paper did no credit to the organisation and that it was a contribution of low standing.

Senator Vallentine raised five issues which purported to represent points made by Mr Kerin. I want to refer to some of the more gross misrepresentations which Senator Vallentine, possibly in ignorance or unwittingly, has repeated. First of all, her comments on non-proliferation were just a mish mash of bilateral safeguards and wider unrelated arms controls issues. The point which detractors of the Government's safeguards policy consistently misconstrue is that we have bilateral safeguard agreements in place under which Australian uranium is fully accounted for in the fuel cycles of our customer countries. In addition to these arrangements, our uranium is subject to international safeguards applied by the International Atomic Energy Agency. For nuclear weapons states, including France, these arrangements confirm that Australian uranium is used only in their peaceful nuclear programs.

Secondly, the question of safety is, of course, a legitimate concern. The difficult aspect of this issue is maintaining a balanced perspective. As unpalatable as it may be for those who would play up every incident in the nuclear industry to bolster their stance, the nuclear power industry has a good safety record. Chernobyl is not representative of the industry. The recent incidents in Japan did not cause any exposure of the public to radioactivity. There have been 5,000 years of reactor experience and in that time only Chernobyl has had major consequences for public health. The level of safe performance will continue to improve with the introduction of new technologies and the retro fitting or closure of older types of reactors and some Soviet design models.

Worker health and safety, which was raised by Senator Vallentine, is an issue which the Government takes very seriously. There are health and safety risks for workers in every industry. That cannot be avoided. But these are not risks exclusive or in any way peculiar to the uranium industry. Many industrial and medical staff encounter similar risks and measures are in place which ensure that these risks are as low as possible. The exposure level of uranium miners in Australia is significantly below the level set.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the UK, Minister.
—I am talking about Australia.
—Yes, and our standards are higher than the United Kingdom's.
—We cannot legislate in this Parliament to fix up the United Kingdom's exposure levels.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to Aboriginal interests, Senator Vallentine's comments focused on Western Australia. They are based on a number of unfounded assumptions about the Kintyre deposit, the main assumption being that it was virtually up and running, which is not so. Mines on Aboriginal lands have proceeded only after agreement has been reached with the representatives of the traditional owners, and that process will continue.

Finally, on the issue of uranium markets, Greenpeace-its views being articulated here by Senator Vallentine-seems quite misinformed about uranium supply and demand and its relevance to the debate. Governments do not hinder the development of their economies because someone's supply and demand projection for a national resource might indicate that other countries could meet supply needs, particularly when the projections have been manipulated to that end. Just to indulge Senator Vallentine's sources, even Greenpeace, with its dire forebodings about the nuclear industry, concedes some growth in nuclear generating capacity, although it manages to extrapolate commercially unreal low levels of uranium demand from its capacity estimates.

There is a lot of confusion between supply capacity and actual supply, and ignorance of what is really happening in the industry. The sorts of claims being repeated by Senator Vallentine show no appreciation of either Government policy making in the resources area or basic commodity supply demand economics.

Senator Vallentine later today had some remarks to make about insurance and radioactive waste disposal, and went a little further on the question of the uranium market. It added nothing to what was said in her earlier remarks. On the question of insurance, Senator Vallentine argues that uranium mining should not be allowed to expand because it contributes to an industry which is too dangerous to be covered by normal insurance. A lot of areas of industry are not covered by normal insurance. Specific insurance cover in these areas can be and is negotiated with insurers. Cover for nuclear accidents is widely negotiated overseas and Australian companies participate in underwriting such policies. So those comments are incorrect.

On behalf of Mr Kerin, I just wanted to correct some of those misapprehensions which were, not surprisingly, contained in Senator Vallentine's speech to the Senate on these issues. I thank other senators for their observations and wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crichton-Browne's) be agreed to.
