TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill demonstrates the extent to which this failed Hawke Labor Government remains the captive of trade union bureaucrats, especially those in the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and especially that de facto Cabinet member, Bill Kelty.
—The one who controls Senator Cook.

—Indeed, he is the de facto Cabinet member who probably has more say over industrial relations than the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) himself. The legislation is a blatant example of the Government's determination to ensure that trade union leaders who have the capacity to wreak havoc on the general community remain above the law as it applies to the rest of the community. This is because this legislation is the first step towards the establishment of a separate labour court, which could well have the effect of removing jurisdiction over industrial relations from the Federal Court and the High Court where they should remain.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, in handling this legislation in this place on behalf of my colleague the shadow Minister for industrial relations, John Howard, in the other place, let me make it plain at the outset that the Opposition is totally opposed to this Bill and believes that it should be defeated. I urge the Australian Democrats, who I see are at least represented in the chamber by Senator Bell, to support us in throwing out this Bill after the second reading debate. However, if the Australian Democrats lack the wisdom to do that, I foreshadow that our opposition will be reinforced with amendments in the committee stage of this debate.

It is ironic that the Government is introducing legislation which ostensibly seeks to bolster the importance and independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and to centralise wage setting structures for the defence forces, which this legislation also seeks to do, at a time when it has rejected the recommendations of the Industrial Relations Commission and is busy trying to impose its own wage guidelines under the guise of decentralisation and enterprise bargaining.

The crucial part of this legislation is Part III of the Bill, which is a consequence of the long running dispute between the ACTU and the Industrial Relations Commission about whether Industrial Relations Commission salaries should be linked to those of Federal Court judges, rather than be determined under the wage guidelines which the Industrial Relations Commission determines and administers for ordinary workers. The Federal Court-Industrial Relations Commission nexus was abandoned in May of last year under intense pressure from Bill Kelty and the ACTU, when the ACTU demanded that any remuneration tribunal increases for Commission members must be consistent with the guidelines it laid down for national wage increases.

The Government was forced to reject the Remuneration Tribunal's recommendations, including part of its own submission to the Tribunal, at the bidding of the ACTU. To avoid further embarrassment the Government appointed a committee of review to find a way out of the corner into which it had painted itself. This committee, headed by the former head of the New South Wales Premier's Department, Mr Gerry Gleeson, conducted a review of the Commission, including a work value survey. It reported to the Minister recently, on 1 March this year, with a series of recommendations that, when one considers them, are remarkably similar to the Government's own submission to the committee.

The Opposition is opposing these recommendations because they have nothing whatsoever to do with the interests of working Australians and everything to do with placating Mr Kelty. The recommendations propose new classifications within the Commission that are clearly linked to the industrial jurisdiction of the Federal Court of Australia and the future creation of a labour court. It is intended that the new senior deputy presidents will also sit as judges in such a labour court; yet, the members of the Commission, however well qualified in the law, are not judges.

At the time of the boilermakers case in 1956, the High Court of Australia declared that it was unconstitutional for the then Commonwealth Court of Conciliation and Arbitration to exercise judicial power, being a body concerned with conciliation and arbitration. It was after that case that legislation was passed to form two distinct bodies: the Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and the Commonwealth Industrial Court, which later became part of the Federal Court. This Labor Government resurrected the idea of a separate labour court in its major rewrite on industrial relations legislation drafted in 1987. When the Government rushed to an early election in mid-1987, community outrage caused the Government to drop this proposal from the legislation along with the proposal for a minimum union size. These proposals were also left out of the new legislation introduced and passed in 1988.

Last year the Government, grateful for the convenient reversal of attitudes by the Australian Democrats, rammed through legislation to force the creation of mega-unions. Now the labour court is back on the agenda. The Minister has made this very clear. But it is quite unacceptable to have a special labour court judging matters of law concerning industrial relations. Undoubtedly, members of a new labour court would be appointed from the Industrial Relations Commission or related networks, weaned on the ethics of the industrial relations club and accepting fully, no doubt, the industrial relations club's ethos.

Industrial relations matters taken to such a court are obviously matters being appealed. Indeed, quite often they are appeals against the legalities of the Industrial Relations Commission decisions. For the Industrial Relations Commission in this circumstance it would be a case of Caesar appealing to Caesar, quite unfair to the party which might be opposed to the Industrial Relations Commission in the court hearing.

The establishment of a labour court could also be used to remove the right of resort to common law actions which have been so successful in recent years in resolving disputes and beating intimidation by union leaders. The Dollar Sweets and Mudginberri disputes are significant examples of such successes. The people of Australia are entitled to ask why this Government steadfastly refuses to make the real changes to our industrial relations system which are essential if we are to be internationally competitive in creating wealth to be shared by all Australians instead of changes, such as those we are debating tonight, designed to further entrench the industrial relations club.

One only has to look yet again at the waterfront situation as an example of the appalling mess in which industrial relations in this country currently exist. It seems that the centralised wage fixing system was acceptable as long as it was producing higher wages but, once it was seen to be in danger of producing across-the-board wage cuts, decentralisation suddenly looked a better prospect.

I shall describe the events which led to this situation. In April this year the Industrial Relations Commission brought down a wages decision that rejected the accord mark VI that had been agreed between the Government and the ACTU in February 1990, the first part of which had already been implemented in September last year. This accord has been in place in one form or another since 1983, generally rubber stamped until now by the Industrial Relations Commission. However, the Industrial Relations Commission has at last thrown it out. Instead, it proposed a 2.5 per cent national wage rise based on productivity increases and an agreement not to make other claims.

This was rejected by both the Government and the ACTU, and particularly by the waterside workers. Suddenly, a national wage case, because it included conditions in the form of productivity increases, was not acceptable either to the Government or the ACTU. So much for the oft-repeated claim of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that the umpire's decision should be accepted. The reality is that it is accepted by this Government and its ACTU mates only if the umpire is wearing their guernsey. The Government and the ACTU, hitherto the champions of centralised wage fixing, opted for accord mark VI, an across-the-board increase of $12 a week from 16 May, a three per cent superannuation increase and an accelerated shift to so-called enterprise bargaining.

Just to prove it was serious, the Government has made a commitment to pay the accord package to Australia's 400,000 public servants. The waterside workers, however, did not want accord mark VI. They wanted more than that. That is what they have after a nifty bit of blackmail over waterfront reform. The Waterside Workers Federation asked for increases of 10.8 per cent, which would have added about $40m to its wages bill, an increase in costs on the waterfront which this country obviously cannot afford in light of the existing inefficiencies and excessive expenses in that industry. The fact that business has dropped by about 35 per cent is apparently of no concern whatsoever to the waterside workers.

After lengthy negotiations with unions, employers and the Government, an agreement has been reached that gives the waterfront workers an initial across-the-board increase of $12 with a further aggregate adjustment of 6.12 per cent. This further adjustment will be in three equal instalments. The first instalment will be effective from 1 July this year on an enterprise by enterprise basis, once enterprise-based agreements and reclassifications have been completed. The second and third instalments will be effective from 1 January 1992 and 1 July 1992, provided that the enterprise-based agreements and productivity improvements are in place according to the agreement.

This agreement means that waterside workers will receive an across-the-board average increase of $41 a week over the next 15 months. Of course, this agreement with the Waterside Workers Federation is still subject to ratification by the Industrial Relations Commission. It would certainly be a very brave Industrial Relations Commission that rejects the will of the Government and the ACTU at a time when the Government in this legislation is pushing through a law that gives its members significant increases in their remuneration packages. It is sad and regrettable that these deals are all being worked out in the name of enterprise bargaining and enterprise-based agreements when they are nothing of the sort.

The Government's version of enterprise agreements are Claytons enterprise agreements. Do we need reminding that early in 1987 Prime Minister Hawke told the Business Council of Australia that enterprise bargaining would be introduced over his dead body? Do we need reminding that Bill Kelty pointedly turned his back on Peter McLaughlan and Professor Hilmer when they presented arguments for enterprise bargaining on behalf of the Business Council to an Economic Planning Advisory Council meeting in 1989? Do we need reminding that last June Industrial Relations Minister Cook told the Metal Trades Industry Association that agreements for enterprise bargaining were fairies at the bottom of the garden stuff? Have the three central players in this Government's industrial relations policy suddenly experienced a dramatic conversion? Of course not.

The fact is that the Liberal and National parties have set the agenda on industrial relations policy and debate. It is the Liberal and National parties which have, for at least six years, advocated decentralisation and deregulation of industrial relations and wages determination in order to encourage direct and improved communication between employers and employees and recognition of their shared and mutual interests. This approach has won widespread community support, despite strong opposition from the Government and the ACTU.

At last this Government, on its last legs, has recognised that support. So it seeks to use the language which has won acceptance-terms such as `enterprise bargaining' and `enterprise agreements'. But while it seeks to clothe itself in the terminology that has won widespread support, in reality the Government has no clothes. It is not introducing genuine enterprise-based agreements, as the attempted waterfront deal shows clearly. The waterfront deal may not have originated with the Industrial Relations Commission but it is nonetheless a centrally determined arrangement. It has nothing to do with genuine industrial relations reform which is directed at real enterprise bargaining.

Nothing the Government has put forward as enterprise agreements meets the three criteria which are essential for true enterprise agreements. Those criteria are: firstly, that employers and employees must be free to come to an agreement over wages and conditions without duress and especially without the requirement of ratification or arbitration by the Industrial Relations Commission or interference from any third party. Secondly, the principle of voluntary union membership must be in place and must be protected by law. Thirdly-and this goes against all of the recent legislation on union amalgamations which has been brought in by this Government-workers must have the right to form new unions and, in particular, enterprise unions as well as industry or craft-based union structures.

The Government's arrangements clearly fail to meet these criteria. In their absence, the Government's claim that it is embracing enterprise agreements is nothing more than empty rhetoric. The Prime Minister is proposing that workers and employers agree, on an enterprise-to-enterprise basis, to apply for a wages deal that has already been decided by the Government and the ACTU. It is essentially an industry-based decision that takes no account of the wishes of individual employers or employees, or the ability of employers to pay. It is strictly a take it or leave it deal.

In making its decision for a 2.5 per cent wage increase, the Industrial Relations Commission took into account the present state of the Australian economy-the recession in Australia and overseas, the rural crisis, the likelihood of an imminent recovery and the potential effects of the emergence of increased and excessive labour costs on that recovery. While acknowledging that some modest wage increases may be justified in line with continuing inflation, the Commission nevertheless pointed to the benefits of continuing wage restraint.

In its reasons for its decision on the national wage case, the Commission reiterated that it took the decision to reject the accord mark VI in the national interest-something about which this Labor Government seems to have very little concern. Some passages from the Commissions's report are worth quoting. The report states:

Because the ACTU had pressed certain views about the remuneration of members of the Commission, there had been a clear impression amongst many trade union members and officials that the Commission may be biased against the ACTU . . .

The Commission is concerned with its independence and integrity . . . it is our view that integrity and independence has been jeopardised by the manner of the recent actions of the Commonwealth Government and the ACTU . . . [the Commission] has not been-nor will it be-influenced by the source of submissions made to it.
This serves only to reinforce what I said earlier about this Bill: it is here as a consequence of the Government trying to get itself out of a difficult situation.

What we are seeing is a bizarre situation: on the one hand, the Hawke Government has always seen the Industrial Relations Commission as the holy of holies with regard to the conduct of industrial relations in Australia; yet, on the other hand, in the past few months-and especially the past few days-the Government has appeared to be supporting Kelty and the ACTU in what amounts to a vendetta against the Industrial Relations Commission. The Opposition will have no part in this and strongly opposes the Bill for this reason.

Another part of this legislation relates to the Trade Union Training Authority. As honourable senators would be aware, the Opposition does not support the continuation of the Trade Union Training Authority in its present form. In the Opposition's Economic Action Plan we said:

The Trade Union Training Authority provides industrial relations training for trade unionists at taxpayers' expense. The Authority will be offered for sale to the trade union movement, and/or any other interested buyer. If the Authority is not sold it will be disbanded.

Therefore, we do not see why the Trade Union Training Authority should not be either self-funding or funded by the trade unions. After all, the Government has adopted a policy of user pays for everyone else and has even introduced legislation to make companies spend a percentage of their payroll on training. So why not the trade unions as well? We can therefore see no good reason for the amendments proposed in this Bill with regard to the Trade Union Training Authority.
In conclusion, this Hawke Labor Government has caused a lot of pain and suffering to ordinary Australians through wrong-headed decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Horrific problems.
—As Senator Brownhill would be aware, as he represents the rural parts of New South Wales, it is particularly in the bush that people are suffering.
—I wish they really understood the problems they have caused.

—They are simply not aware of it in many respects. As I have said, this Government has caused a lot of pain and suffering for ordinary Australians through wrong-headed decisions-but they are decisions which the Government refuses to acknowledge as being wrong-headed. It prefers to claim that we are in a recession that we had to have.

SPEECH.PARA: But in the area where hard decisions and major changes are desperately required, this Government steadfastly continues to refuse to act. The reason is simple: such initiatives as are required would cause a bit of pain and suffering to its masters-the trade union bureaucrats. Many of them might become redundant.

This Government refuses to introduce genuine enterprise bargaining, where employers and employees agree voluntarily to do their own deal. Be assured that the next Liberal-National Party Government will introduce this. This Government refuses to allow freedom of association by ensuring that people have the right to join or not to join a union-that is, voluntary unionism-or the right to join any union of their choice. The next Liberal-National Party Government will. This Government refuses to provide incentives for profit sharing with employees and for employee share ownership. Be assured that the next Liberal-National Party Government will.

So the litany of the shortcomings of this Government's administration of industrial relations goes on. Fortunately, it will not go on beyond the next election, after which we will most certainly introduce the dramatic changes which are desperately required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 proposes amendments to industrial relations areas within the Industrial Relations Act 1988, Defence Act 1903, Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 and the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1974. Therefore, it is comprehensive in its proposed changes.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the amendments to the Industrial Relations Act are a direct result of the Government's acceptance of the report from the Committee of Review into the structure of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the remuneration of its members, which was chaired by Mr Gerry Gleeson.

The Australian Democrats are pleased that the Government has accepted, in essence, the Committee's recommendations because they will strengthen the Industrial Relations Commission (IRC). We have, at all stages, firmly supported a strong Commission which is able to adequately take responsibility and supervise negotiations between employees and employers for pay and conditions and to oversee the crucial process of amalgamations which the Australian Democrats unashamedly supported in the legislation of 1990.

We note the revised structure of the Industrial Relations Commission with the addition of a vice-president and senior deputy president, which will strengthen the Commission in its increased range of responsibilities. It is the intention of the Australian Democrats in the committee stage of this Bill to introduce an amendment which gives more substance and authority to the position of vice-president.

We also note that there is scope for increased cooperation between the Commission and its State counterparts, with members of each being commissioned to hold office in both the Federal and State tribunals. However, we have considerable reservations concerning the proposed amendment to subsection 30 (2) of the Industrial Relations Act, which gives effect to a recommendation of the Gleeson Committee that greater flexibility in the constitution of full benches of the Industrial Relations Commission be permitted. Even though flexibility in the affairs of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission is to be supported, the proposal has some notable drawbacks.

This is clear when the range of matters that a full bench is permitted or required to deal with is considered. All are significant and warrant a highly qualified full bench. Some examples include: national wage cases under section 106; appeals under section 45; referrals by the President of a matter of industrial dispute `of such importance that, in the public interest, it should be dealt with by a Full Bench' as appropriate under subsection 107 (2); reviews of awards, orders or certain other decisions of a member of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission under section 109; the consideration of proposed certified agreements that are inconsistent with national wage principles in accordance with subsection 115(6); the review of the operation of certified agreements under subsection 117 (1); and the cancellation of awards under section 187. These are only some of the substantial matters which should be considered by a full bench. The Australian Democrats have some reservations about the proposed amendment to subsection 30 (2). We will address those reservations in an amendment which we will move in the committee stage of this debate.

As well as practical concerns, attention has been paid to remuneration and various other entitlements of members. It is the Government's intention that these recommendations will be implemented shortly. In essence, the recommendations of the Gleeson report strengthen the Industrial Relations Commission and at the same time augment its independence-an independence which the Industrial Relations Commission asserted controversially as recently as last week.

These recent events have challenged the Commission and the position taken by both the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the Government on the decision of the IRC to grant a 2.5 per cent national wage increase rather than a flat $12, which was sought, and to defer further moves to extend occupational superannuation has had serious implications for the centralised wages system and for the gradual but substantial workplace reforms brought about to date by the accord. It is to be hoped that the Industrial Relations Commission can withstand this assault. Workplace reform is vital if Australia is to overcome the current recession and emerge from it intact to regain our position and standards of living relative to other nations.

The Australian Democrats welcome the recent suggestion by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that the wages accord may be broadened later this year to include employer organisations and also the trade union movement beyond the ACTU leadership. This would go a long way towards preventing the types of mindless confrontation which so typified industrial relations in this country over past decades.

The amendments to the Australian Trade Union Training Authority (TUTA) are also important as they will significantly reform its structure. These changes have been undertaken so that TUTA will develop a national focus, which is already being implemented at an administrative and policy level, and also increase the productive use of its resources. The amendments will establish an executive council of TUTA with power to establish regional advisory councils to deal effectively with issues arising in a particular geographical area. As a result of this new national approach, TUTA's Australian Council and regional councils for the States and territories will be abolished. The position of National Director and Director of Studies will be abolished and will be replaced with the one position of executive officer.

For many years, the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal has been labouring under restrictions which have resulted in slow progress and various inefficiencies. These amendments to the Defence Act will give rise to more efficient and faster procedures. The Chairman can now direct that a matter be dealt with by a single member and provision will be made for a single member to instigate review action. Provisions dealing with intervention by interested parties and the ratification of consent matters by the Tribunal will be clarified. These amendments to the Defence Act 1903 have no financial impact but, hopefully, will have positive, practicable implications.

The amendments to the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989 are of a minor drafting nature and have no financial implications. The Democrats therefore indicate their support for the general thrust of this amending legislation, but will seek in the committee stage of the debate to resolve by amendment two reservations which we have in relation to the first series of amendments proposed by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appropriate that the debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991 should follow the urgency motion debated today in which the Government was asked to clarify its position on industrial relations in view of the confusion that has been caused since the decision was made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission with regard to the national wage case. It goes without saying that we have seen a situation in this particular case where the Government, despite many statements by Senator Cook and others, has chosen to take a different position because this particular national wage case decision does not happen to suit the Australian Council of Trade Unions or its mates. This is in direct contrast to the position that has been adopted recently in the meat industry. The undermining of the Harrison inquiry goes on and on, to the point now where we may see some of the parties pulling out despite the millions of dollars that has been spent on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The real question that has to be asked about this particular legislation is: what is the hidden agenda behind it? I want to address two principal changes: firstly, the implementation of the Gleeson Committee's recommendations for changes to classification in salaries within the Industrial Relations Commission; and, secondly, the prevention of trade unions from avoiding the amalgamation provisions of the Industrial Relations Amendment Act 1990. We strenuously opposed the Industrial Relations Amendment Act because, under its provisions, it is impossible to develop a true enterprise agreement situation when one is dealing with mega unions. Enterprise agreements will occur only if they are allowed to develop between enterprise unions and employers-or however groups in the workplace want to structure their particular operations.

In addressing this particular Bill, those matters I see on the hidden agenda, which has yet to come out, and the changes which have occurred over recent weeks, I pose these questions: is this the forerunner to a labour court? Is this the beginning of an attempt by the Government, aided by the Democrats, to bring about the demise of subsections 45(d) and (e) and common law actions in the industrial field? Is part of that situation the introduction of right-to-strike legislation?

The Government needs to come clean on all these issues and state where it stands precisely so that the Australian community can make a judgment about the direction which has been taken at this time as far as the future of industrial relations in this country is concerned. This is particularly the case at present when unemployment is soaring. We will be seeing new figures this week which, I predict, will move significantly upwards again. We see many instances in which businesses are going bankrupt.

It is worth noting that Senator McLean spelt out clearly the position of the Australian Democrats in an article in the Bulletin last week. I found it extraordinary that in that article he was adopting a position where third parties who had been damaged should not have redress to claim for that particular damage. That would certainly be a step backwards of some 10 years or so in industrial relations. One must have a balance between the people involved in a particular situation and when one party can significantly damage a second or a third party, it should to be held accountable.

Let me deal in a little more detail with a couple of these points. I deal first with the implementation of the Gleeson Committee recommendations. We see the present three tiers of classifications within the Commission-that is, the President, the Deputy President and the commissioners-being expanded to five by the creation of the position of vice-presidents and senior deputy presidents, between the existing positions of President and Deputy President. I believe, as I said earlier, that that is the first step in moving towards an attempt to introduce a labour court into this country-a position which was adopted prior to an election and which was soundly rejected by the Australian community.

The next point I wish to deal with is the prevention of trade unions avoiding the amalgamation provisions of the Act. We had much debate on this matter on the previous industrial relations Bill that we had before us, and we took a very strong stance against that Bill. First, it sought to enshrine power in the hands of a few trade union officials, and particularly the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU); and, secondly, it was defying what was happening in the marketplace in terms of development of enterprise agreements.

I want to make the point that there are some things that are very important in getting successful enterprise agreements off the ground. An enterprise agreement must be on the basis of the enterprise-that is, the employer and the people involved in that enterprise. For that to be successful it is important that the people involved be able to form their own enterprise union. If they have big brother interfering with that process, it cannot and will not work.

That is the principal reason why we do not see any of the huge number of work practices that we have on the waterfront-some of which I quoted today and some of which I will quote in a moment-being addressed in the latest effort of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). It is plain damned ridiculous that a $12 wage increase will be granted from 16 May when we continue to see many excessive work practices staying in place, at least for another 13 months.

Let me quote a few of these practices. The gross average weekly earnings for a general class waterside worker is $824 a week for an average working week of 27 hours. The waterside worker enjoys five weeks annual leave, with a 27.5 per cent leave loading. The waterside worker enjoys 10 sick leave days a year. In addition, this can be accumulated over a period of time and cashed in after 10 years of continuous employment. These are excesses far beyond any other situation that exists in the Australian work place. There is a gross degree of overmanning. As a result of this there is a considerable amount of `nicking off', to the extent that it is a well known practice to have an organised system to allocate `nicking off' days in a fair and equitable way. What a glorious situation! It is a disgraceful situation.

I quote only a few of these work practices. For example, those involved in the transport of container cargo were paid a weekly consolidated disability allowance of $11.20 to compensate them for the dirty work conditions they might be forced to work in. Those not adversely affected by the conditions still get the allowance. Overtime for more than one hour earns workers a meal allowance of $9.15. A supervisor earns approximately $1,000 a week for a 35- to 40-hour week. Employers estimated that if the first deal put to Conaust Ltd were accepted, the package would cost at least $50m or more a year if the wage package were granted. Idle time, where employees are paid to stay at home because of lack of work, is estimated to cost about $27.5m a year.

I ask, in the light of what is being put in front of us in this Bill: where does all this fit into the hidden agenda and what is now going on in the industrial relations arena? If we look further in terms of developing enterprise agreements, if we are serious about it, there are some fundamental points which must be emphasised and which are essential if the system is to work. The first is that the legal right to establish enterprise agreements must be between employers and employees without intervention. Closed shops have to be abolished. Voluntary unionism must be introduced and there must be enterprise unions. The Government's current position fails on all these points.

Unless the whole issue of enterprise bargaining is addressed on these lines, as a result of what occurred on the waterfront we will see that agreements will come out of bullying and coercion. They will not produce the benefits that are required to address Australia's current economic and industrial problems. On the one hand, we now have operating one situation for the meat industry-an industry which provides some $3 billion of export income earnings for this country-and the preferred treatment of Wally Curran and his abuse, in his way, of the Harrison inquiry and what is occurring there, aided and abetted by the Victorian Government. Yet, on the other hand, we have the situation now, having been repeatedly told in this place that the matter has to be dealt with by the Commission with the Commission as umpire, that when the Commission brings down its national wage case the Government takes the view, `That's no good. Bill Kelty doesn't like it'. So the Government adopts another position and suddenly the Commission is no longer the umpire.

I would now like to address what is happening in the wool industry in its current crisis, which is a difficult one but one that is worth looking at for a moment. I refer to a survey carried out in my district in Western Australia which shows that the cost of producing wool is $2.96, or near enough to $3 a kilo, which equates to 450c clean. That does not include the 15 per cent tax proposed by Minister Kerin, which we will be dealing with at another time, but, effectively, it will take the cost of producing wool up to about 500c a kilo clean to break even. That does not include anything for any works on the property-for example, fencing, improving the water supplies and conservation. It is just the bare cost of producing the wool.

How has that industry responded to it? How have the people involved in the workplace responded to it? They have responded-and I have seen this-by going to the people who employ them and saying, `We want this industry to be around for a while. We want sheep to be shorn'. There are examples now of sheep actually being shorn for around 85c. That is a response of people in the workplace who know that the industry is in a difficult situation, despite the fact that the price for shearing is around $1.40 a head. That is what genuine enterprise agreements and bargaining are all about. The employer and the employee work out a price which can keep both in business and avoid or minimise the number of bankruptcies.

We can look at other aspects of the wool industry. Once again, we see that wool classers have been prepared to accept approximately a 35 per cent decrease in what they were getting paid when a reserve price of 870c was in place, because they want to go on classing wool, they want to be part of the industry, they want to be able to provide their families with a living they have earned, and they do not want to be a liability to society. The situation with rouseabouts and other people demonstrates that, when we are in recession and when industries are down, we must have flexibility in place so that there can be an adjustment in the marketplace.

I could go on quoting many examples, but I just want to come back to what I set out to say on this Bill and on the direction we see occurring now in industrial relations in this country. It appears to me that over the next 12 months we are going to see a number of actions taken which, in fact, will be designed to enshrine the power of the ACTU and to make it more difficult for a government that is prepared to address this issue to do it in a rational and sensible manner. These actions will make it more difficult to address the excesses which currently exist in the workplace, as will this so-called agreement, which really achieves very little or nothing on the waterfront.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), among other things, is basically fiddling with a structure in which the Government has no confidence and which has been subject to continued attacks from the Treasurer (Mr Keating), the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and Senator Cook. These amendments are seeking to prop up, to somehow change, the Industrial Relations Act along the lines of the Gleeson Committee review, so that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will remain the subject of scorn and ridicule by the Prime Minister, but the structure will be changed.

SPEECH.PARA: One wonders about the relevance of this sort of legislation at a time when the Industrial Relations Commission is at least an anachronism and at best will be performing under the next government a totally different role from the one that at present has meant that it has contributed enormously to the level of unemployment and economic disaster facing this nation.

We have seen quite clearly the irrelevance of the present Industrial Relations Commission in the way that the Government has arrived at its decisions about the waterfront. We have seen the irrelevance of the Industrial Relations Commission by the Government's response to the Commission's failure to follow the Government's lead on the accord. I am not going to suggest that the specific amendments that are listed will either improve or diminish the status of the Commission. What I want to concentrate on is the Commission and whether or not it has played, and will continue to play after these amendments are passed, a disastrous role in the economy.

There is no doubt, for example, that, as a result of the deals done between large employer groups and large union groups, there have been a whole series of ludicrous decisions made, which have had a specific impact on those people who do not get the opportunity to be represented before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. I speak specifically about a group of people whose concerns I seek to represent in this place, that is, the young people of Australia. They do not have an opportunity, specifically, to put their case to the Industrial Relations Commission, and yet they are the very people who are most in the firing line and who have suffered most from this Commission's determinations, which effectively have been rubber-stamping the Government's deals with unions.

All I need do is refer honourable senators to the latest official labour force figures-and there will be some worse ones, I think, coming out on Thursday for April. The March figures indicate the irrelevance of the present structure to labour in terms of proper response to the marketplace. Because of the rigidities in the system, which are in no way addressed by this amendment, we see this sort of situation.

We see that over the last 12 months the number of full time adult jobs that have disappeared, that have been wiped out as a result of the recession we had to have according to Mr Keating, has been something like 81,500. The number of full time jobs of young people, that is, people aged under 20, that have been wiped out over that same period is 110,700. In other words, something like 58 per cent of the jobs that have been wiped out over the last 12 months are young people's jobs, and yet young people make up only 5.3 per cent of the total number of people at work. More than half the job losses in Australia have come from this 5.3 per cent of full time workers.

What does that tell us about the systems we employ to establish wage rates in this nation? It tells us that the wage rates we have set for young people, that have been set by the structure which we are dealing with tonight, are such that there is a massive concentration of job loss among young people who have no capacity to represent themselves in front of the Industrial Relations Commission. They have no capacity to come to private arrangements, private deals, with the Commission. They are subject to the control and domination of the unions which clearly, in their deals with big government, with the club and with the Commission, put the best interests of young people last.

I am concerned that the Commission has continually adopted the approach of applying cash pay rises, which diminishes the proportional gap between adult wages and youth wages. One of the problems that emerge when this happens is that it becomes relatively too expensive to employ young people as against employing more productive older people. If the marketplace were allowed to exist, we would not get this disproportionate job shedding or job destruction at the young end of the employment scale in an economic downturn. If the rates of pay that young people could negotiate bore a real relationship to the market, we would not see a concentration of job loss in the young end of the market. If wages bore a relationship to productivity and to the level of experience of an employee-in other words, a relationship to the marketplace-there would be no economic pressure on employers to dispose of so many young people and to make it impossible for young people to get jobs.

In the Government's continual reviews of industrial relations, in its consideration of amendments like those before us today, it is clear that absolutely no interest has been displayed about the disadvantaged position that the present system puts young people in. The fact that 110,700 jobs have been wiped out throughout Australia in the past 12 months means that something like one in four jobs for young people-those under 20 years of age-have been wiped out. We must have a system that is more responsive to that situation, particularly as among adults the proportion is relatively minute. I recognise that, as I said, there have been 81,500 jobs lost among adults, but there are still something like six million full time adult workers in Australia, whereas there are now only 320,300 young people at work after this 25.7 per cent wiping out of full time jobs.

The consequence of the unemployment that has emerged as a result of this inflexible and inappropriate industrial relations arrangement is that real unemployment rates for young people are far higher than the official rates suggest. The current official unemployment rate in Australia for people seeking full time work is something like 25.2 per cent. That means that about one in four young Australians simply cannot get jobs. It is interesting to note that this unemployment rate overwhelmingly understates the real unemployment rate because the number of job losses far exceeds the increase in unemployment.

Of the 110,000 young Australians who have lost their jobs, only 41,000-odd have gone on to the unemployed list. What has happened to the other 70,000-odd? When we ask that question, we come up with some fascinating answers. The 70,000-odd, who have lost their jobs largely as a result of inflexibility of the industrial relations arrangements, have disappeared from the unemployment statistics. There is apparently a combination of reasons for this disappearance. It has resulted in a massive fall in the participation rate.

A few years ago the Government changed the definition of unemployment so that a person who worked for one hour or more a week-unpaid-was no longer regarded as unemployed for the purposes of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That means, for example, that if an unemployed young person engages in work experience, say with a member of parliament or with one of the media organisations-which I know happens-that person, getting no pay, is not on the unemployed list according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics and according to this Government. That is just a farce. Someone who cannot get a job but works on his parents' farm for no pay-and I know very few farmers who at the moment could afford to pay even their children to work with them-is not regarded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics as being unemployed.

We also have the situation now where Austudy has been extended to secondary students. Last year $300m-odd was spent to get young people who could not get jobs to go back to school. That will be of benefit to some of them, and I would not criticise the Government's attempts to increase the skill levels of large numbers of young Australians. Even within the inflexible and ludicrous industrial relations system that is enshrined in the accord and manifested by the deals that the Government does with the trade union movement, and for which the Government seeks the rubber stamp of the Industrial Relations Commission, people who have increased their skill levels at least have a greater chance of getting jobs-if and when there is an upturn in the economy under this incompetent Government-than those who have not learnt some skills.

The problem is that a large proportion of those people who are being paid to return to school are simply in a teenager-sitting exercise. They are not being provided with skills. They are not back at school by choice; they are reluctant attendees because they know perfectly well that they cannot get a job in the private sector or the public sector. Their only way of getting income basically is through Austudy. They may as well be on Austudy as unemployed. It seems to me that this is a measure of the failure of the present industrial relations system. When we add the rate of hidden unemployment to the unemployment figures, we see that in Australia there are something like 35.6 per cent unemployed. However, when we look at the unemployment figures, these people have magically disappeared from them.
