DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the Senate an apparently unprecedented decision made by the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The Committee held a meeting today with the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), Mr David Hill. Through my colleague Senator Macdonald, a distinguished member of that distinguished Committee, I asked whether I could attend the meeting as I have a particular interest in aspects of the ABC's operations.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken in this chamber on a number of occasions on the need for an external, independent complaints procedure at the ABC. Interestingly, I understand, this is also the policy of the Hawke Labor Government. As it turned out, this apparently was one of the major issues canvassed at that meeting today. My request to attend the meeting was put to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Foreman, at the commencement of the meeting. A decision was made that I would not be able to attend the hearing. I would like to hear from the Chairman of the Committee the reasons why I was excluded. In the meantime, I have sought advice on whether honourable senators who are not members of committees can attend those committee hearings. The advice that I received is that an honourable senator who is not a member of a standing committee may participate in its public sessions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get this advice from?

—When I sit down, Senator Faulkner will be able to stand up and answer these questions. He should not get excited; he will have a chance. I am putting some serious questions before him and I will wait here with great interest to see whether he rises to his feet and effectively addresses these issues. He should stop cursing and prepare his speech now.

SPEECH.PARA: The advice that I received is that an honourable senator who is not a member of standing committee may participate in its public sessions and question witnesses unless the committee orders otherwise. In other words, an honourable senator has a right to attend public hearings of a committee and question any witnesses before the committee unless the committee makes a deliberate decision to exclude the honourable senator.

In relation to hearings of evidence in private sessions or in briefings, a committee may decide to allow an honourable senator who is not a member of the committee to attend and participate in the proceedings. On the request for such an attendance being made, the committee should make a decision on that request.

In both circumstances, I understand the decision must be a decision of the committee and not of the chairman alone. I would be interested to hear from the Chairman of this Committee whether this was his decision or whether it was made on the votes of the honourable senators on the Committee. Does the fact that this was a so-called informal meeting make any difference? Apparently not. Proper notice was given for the meeting and the usual rules of meeting procedures applied.

I have asked whether there are any precedents to exclude an honourable senator from a committee meeting when a specific request has been made. None of the experienced colleagues I have been able to contact can recall such a precedent. In fact, I would be very interested to hear from Senator Foreman whether he can provide any such examples. Does this mean that I happen to be the first? I am not sure and I would be keen to hear the precedents. The Committee can establish rules governing participation by honourable senators who are not members; for example, it is a general rule that members of the Committee have a priority in putting questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order--
—This is Gareth's point of order. He gave him the standing order number.
—I got under his skin.

—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 187-I appreciate Senator Evans's assistance in reminding me of the number-which says that a senator shall not read a speech. I point out that Senator Kemp's contribution is in flagrant disregard of this standing order.
—There have certainly been aspects of Senator Kemp's speech which were not read. I will keep Senator Faulkner's point of order in mind and observe Senator Kemp.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I was quoting some advice that I had received. I am sorry that that caused some particular distress. I noticed today that Senator Evans was very careful to read his briefs in relation to matters in Western Australia. Perhaps he wanted to choose his words particularly carefully to make sure that they coincided with those of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).
—Order! Senator Kemp should get back to the subject matter of his speech.

—I make the point that I was being provoked by Senator Evans and Senator Faulkner. If Senator Evans is worried about people reading speeches, he might look at his own performance today where he was being particularly careful to attune his words to exactly what the Prime Minister said in the other place. Of all people in this chamber, it ill behoves Senator Evans to raise that particular issue today. I appreciate the chance that Senator Evans gave me to make that point, which was very obvious to all my colleagues on this side of the chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Returning to the point, there are a number of particular ironies in this case. I understand that, whereas I was being excluded from the Committee, David Hill, the gentleman who was appearing before the Committee, was quite happy to answer my questions. Senator Faulkner will have to find out who told me this: when the Committee made its particular determination, David Hill made a very kind offer to come around and speak to me, to brief me about the matters which he thought were of some concern and give me the chance to raise some questions. If I had been given that opportunity, I would not be up here this evening raising these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the strongest argument you have put so far.

—It is a good argument. Because Senator Faulkner keeps on provoking me, this might go on for some little while, so he should brace himself. There were some matters that I would have liked to raise with Mr David Hill today. I would have liked to have had the opportunity to be at the Committee hearings to make these points to him. Some of my colleagues will be aware that today the ABC announced a new independent complaints procedure for viewers and listeners who have particular concerns about ABC programming. I would have liked to ask David Hill how these new procedures, which apparently have been announced today, differ from the sorts of procedures that the Commonwealth Ombudsman would have liked to apply in relation to ABC programming. Over the last 10 years there have been constant disputes between the ABC and the Commonwealth Ombudsman as to whether the Commonwealth Ombudsman has a particular right to investigate allegations and complaints against ABC programming. If Senator Faulkner does not mind, I will read from a statement made in a special report by the Commonwealth Ombudsman in relation to the ABC. This special report was tabled in this chamber in 1985 and in it the Ombudsman referred to `the self serving attitude of the ABC' and pointed to its `determination to resist the Ombudsman'. The Ombudsman then called for an:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . effective mechanism of external-
and I stress the word `external'-
accountability to protect individual members of the community against unfair and unjust treatment by the publicly funded agency.
He went on to say:

It is simply unacceptable that this government instrumentality under the guise of independence, or some other assertion, be allowed to function at a Caesar's Palace when legitimate complaints are made about it.

That is what the Commonwealth Ombudsman said in 1985. As far as I am aware, this dispute between the ABC and the Commonwealth Ombudsman has not been resolved, although I understand there was a meeting on Monday between the Commonwealth Ombudsman and Mr David Hill of the ABC. I would have liked to ask Mr David Hill some questions about the new guidelines that he proposes.

As I have stated, the ABC has hardly adopted a constructive attitude towards complaints. It effectively denuded the complaints procedure by its highly restrictive interpretations of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983-in particular section 82. This eliminated public complaints about matters of bias and restricted complaints to alleged errors of fact by the ABC. Complaints from individuals were not accepted where the ABC argued that it had a `lack of sufficient interest'.

The question that therefore arises under the new guidelines is: what precisely is meant by allegations of serious bias, lack of balance, or unfair treatment arising from an ABC broadcast? Are we to have the same restrictive interpretations of the plain meaning of these words? Who indeed will be deciding the meaning of these words and whether any particular complaints fall within these categories?

A serious problem with new guidelines is that, if one agrees with an ABC review under these procedures, one must give a guarantee not to pursue any legal claim; in other words, the procedure cannot be appealed against. This seems to be most unsatisfactory. A further problem is the fact that legal representation is not permitted under the new guidelines. Whereas this may be appropriate in a large number of cases, they would undoubtedly be complex cases in which the complainant may need legal advice. Finally, the new procedure comes into effect from 13 May. This excludes all the complaints about the coverage by the ABC of the Gulf war.

The fact that the ABC has decided to announce a new complaints procedure is a vindication of the many critics of the ABC who have argued for a long period that the approach of the ABC in dealing with complaints is unsatisfactory. While the new complaints procedure may well be a step in the right direction, it cannot be described as a proper external review process, as would occur, for example, under the Commonwealth Ombudsman Act 1976 or if an independent ABC ombudsman was appointed. The new panel will be reporting to the ABC board.

I understand that the Government has committed itself to a genuine external review procedure for the ABC. In the interests of the ABC and the Australian public, it should pursue its stated policy. Perhaps David Hill would have been able to answer my questions today. It is a pity that I did not have the opportunity to ask them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to detain the Senate for long this evening. However, I do wish to take this opportunity to address a few remarks about a meeting which I attended last Friday in Mackay in the company of the honourable member for Dawson, Mr Ray Braithwaite. It was a meeting of young people in Mackay and the surrounding districts and was called a youth forum. The purpose of the meeting was to solicit the views of people aged between approximately 16 and 25 as to what they think should be the future direction of Australia and the problems they see this country meeting in the next five to 10 years.

SPEECH.PARA: One point that was stressed at this meeting by many of the participants was a grave concern about this country's future, because they, like myself, are the people who will be paying the debts for a long time into the future. The consensus was that one failing of the last 20 years has been this nation's expectation of future generations to pay for the mistakes of their predecessors. They therefore turned their attention to what Australia needs to do in order to have a sound and stable future.

What was of prime importance to many of these young people-especially as most of them were in grade 12 and about to complete their studies at high school-was the very grim prospects they have of obtaining gainful employment or, indeed, any employment at all. They said that this was partly an educational problem; in other words, what they were taught at school did not necessarily prepare them for life outside school.

A frequent criticism I hear in many places is that students are asked to learn about maths 1, maths 2, physics, chemistry and all these other subjects solely to get a good tertiary entrance score but that at the end of the day they leave school without necessarily having a sound understanding of how the world outside works. The issues that are of concern to them are how a bank account is worked, how a credit card is managed and how a bank statement is read when it comes at the end of the month. These are criticisms that are frequently made and criticisms that need to be answered by our educational system if we are to equip this next generation of school leavers with the necessary skills to become good Australians.

We see and read so frequently in the newspapers stories of people my age or younger becoming bankrupt because they could not properly manage their credit cards, their cheque books or whatever. These are tales of woe and wasted opportunity, of young lives that have been blemished because the educational system failed to prepare them for what they would meet outside the school gate.

These young people also suggested that it was perhaps necessary to change the way in which we assess people; in other words, we should not ask everybody to study maths 1, maths 2, physics and chemistry because it does not necessarily mean, for example, that they will be good lawyers, carpenters or plumbers. Increasingly, society is demanding school leavers be academically qualified but not that they be qualified for life. Of course, it does not take too long after leaving school before we forget all the things we were taught and all the academic subjects which have been shoved down our throats for so many years.

Schools could profitably teach people how to be good citizens and how they can get jobs when they leave school. Many of these people said to me that they do not even know where to start to look for a job. They do not know how they should equip themselves to have the maximum chance of getting a job. Senator Michael Baume has been diligent in bringing unemployment rates to the public attention, and so he might as the shadow Minister for youth affairs; it is only appropriate that he does so. Whilst we have these enormously high youth unemployment rates, it is incumbent upon schools and teachers-and parents and citizens associations for that matter-to ensure that the students who leave our schools have the skills to get the jobs.

Even then the problem does not end because jobs need to be available for the taking. Here we find the great dilemma facing young Australians today: there just are not the jobs to put them into the work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —They did not plan for a recession.

—No, of course they did not plan for a recession. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) says that he planned for a recession, but it is a bit rum to expect young people to plan for a recession; Senator Kemp is quite right. Once they leave school full of vim and vigour and an enthusiasm for life, after so many months on the dole queue and so many months of being shunted from one place to another, that enthusiasm evaporates. They are concerned about us creating a climate, an economic condition, in this country where it is increasingly difficult for them and other school leavers to get the jobs they need.

SPEECH.PARA: The comments that I am hearing amongst young Australians are really quite interesting. They are saying that there ought to be work for the dole schemes because nobody has a right to get a living off the State. They are saying that we should not be paying ourselves more than we deserve, because we are being greedy and the people who have the jobs are depriving those people who lack the jobs of the opportunity to get into the work force.

These are the problems that the young Australians of today demand that we in Canberra address. These are the problems which they believe are critical not just in the future of some abstract group called the public, but in the future of so many important young lives-so many young people who are about to embark, for the first time, upon life in the real world.

Whilst my comments must necessarily be brief and whilst I draw to a close, I hasten to add that I am very pleased and proud to have had the opportunity to met those people in Mackay-people who came in their own time because they were seriously interested in meeting with parliamentarians and expressing their view. It is an honour for me as a young Australian to bring their views down here to Canberra. That is one promise I made to them and one promise which I am very proud to have delivered.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —A few minutes before the adjournment debate commenced this evening, I was notified by Senator Kemp that he was going to raise a matter that transpired earlier today regarding the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure of which I am Chairman. On 17 April the Committee decided that it would call the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC), Mr David Hill, before it to discuss a number of things that some Committee members felt they wanted to discuss with him.

SPEECH.PARA: At that meeting on 17 April the point was raised that other senators from the Opposition might want to attend that meeting. The Committee discussed that matter on that day and decided that only members of the Transport and Communications Committee would attend the meeting to be arranged with the Managing Director of the ABC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that with your casting vote?
—Whatever it was, it was a decision of the Committee.
—Was a formal vote taken?

—Yes. So the meeting was arranged for today. As the meeting started, Senator Macdonald raised the issue again and it was again opposed by Committee members. Senator Macdonald was told that the issue was opposed at the previous meeting, and it was finally decided that, if the matter was to be raised again, another meeting should be held before the meeting started.

SPEECH.PARA: During the meeting, and as that matter was raised, Mr Hill said that he knew Senator Kemp and some of the matters that he was interested in. Mr Hill said that he was quite prepared to see Senator Kemp personally after the meeting or at any time he liked to discuss those very issues. Senator Macdonald left his chair at the meeting and rang Senator Kemp's office. We were of the opinion that everyone was happy as far as that arrangement was concerned and the meeting continued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you use your casting vote to exclude him?

—It was a decision of the Committee. Whether it was a casting vote or not, the Committee agreed that no other senator was to attend the meeting. That is how I dealt with the matter and that is the way it was dealt with today. As I mentioned before, Senator Kemp's office was notified that he had the opportunity to see the Managing Director of the ABC personally today, and apparently he never took up that opportunity. He came in here to waste the time of the Senate and everybody else, which has been the case with quite a number of senators lately, especially the new Turks who have recently come here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this debate reluctantly, but I do so because of the principles raised not only by Senator Kemp but also in the extraordinary interjections of Senator Faulkner. His suggestion that it is none of our business what happens in a Senate committee is a disgrace. It is the concern of the Senate what happens in all matters--
—Humbug.

—The expression `humbug' from Senator Evans reminds me of someone looking in a mirror and asking, `Who is the most beautiful of all?'. I can say to Senator Evans that the greatest humbug here is the person who just uttered that word to the mirror.
—It was a private meeting.

—This was stated to be a private meeting. That has been the interjection from Senator Kernot and it has been the statement from Senator Foreman in the only speech I remember him giving here that was not read. If Senator Faulkner wants to play the monkey to Senator Evans's organ-grinder, he should be a little more effective and sensible and recognise who is sitting next door to him when he pulls out standing order 187. What is the purpose of a private meeting of a Senate committee?
—To keep out Senator Kemp.

—I acknowledge that interjection because that is, in fact, the reality. The intention of having this as a private meeting was deliberately to keep out honourable senators who may have a great interest in this matter. For example, had the normal procedures been adopted whereby a list of standing committees is circulated to honourable senators so that one can attend if one wishes, I would have let Senator Evans know that I would have attended. So he has had a great victory-he has kept me out too-and I hope he enjoys it. The fact is that Senator Hill's presence here in this place was of significance to many people who have major problems which have just been raised in Senate Estimates--
—Senator Hill is your Leader.

—Senator Evans knows what I am talking about. Had I known of this meeting I would have attended Mr Hill's gathering. For example, it is a matter of major concern that Mr Hill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) have been charging the amateur sporting bodies of Australia hundreds of thousands of dollars to televise their sporting events, funding for which can only be raised by getting sponsors. Yet the ABC is now refusing to acknowledge and recognise those sponsors when it televises the programs. This is the sort of issue I would have liked to have had the opportunity to raise with Mr Hill. I should imagine that if a decision was taken by this dynamic, secretive Committee making an unprecedented determination, to my knowledge, to exclude--
—What a beat up this is becoming.

—If I can respond to that interjection, how many times is Senator Kernot aware of the Committee excluding other honourable senators from its gathering? How many? If she cannot put up, why does she not shut up?
—Because this is the only Committee I have been involved in in my short time in this place.
—Order! Senator Baume will address the Chair. There are too many interjections.
—There certainly are, Mr President.
—Do not respond to them.

—Interjections of the calibre of those from Senator Kernot accurately reflect her understanding and knowledge of the seriousness of this matter. The fact is that it is improper for a committee of this place to exclude honourable senators unless there is a strong, sound and special reason for doing so. There has been no attempt tonight by the highly literate and totally capable Chairman of that Committee to explain to us what were the special pressing reasons for excluding honourable senators from this meeting, for not allowing other senators like me to know that the meeting was on.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I would suggest to you that, when we have the arrogance being displayed by Senator Faulkner saying that it is none of our business what happens in Senate committees, we have an accurate reflection of the arrogance of this Government and the style that is bringing it into the sort of disrepute that the Western Australian Labor Party has demonstrated for all of us to see.

I hope that Senator Foreman has discovered from tonight's activities that what he and his Committee did was, firstly, foolish; secondly, not in his best interests; and, thirdly, not in the best interests of the Senate. All of us should have, paramount in our thoughts, the best interests of the Senate when we are determining issues such as this. It might have suited his convenience to exclude some honourable senators. It does not suit the Senate. It does not suit the conduct of this place. It does not suit the principles which should prompt all of us in our endeavours here. It certainly does not suit the Senate to have idiotic interjections by Senator Faulkner demonstrating the arrogance of this Government.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, the person whom the decision of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communication and Infrastructure does not suit is Senator Michael Baume. He has made that entirely clear tonight. Apparently, what occurred at the Senate Standing Committee on Transport does not suit Senator Kemp. We have a decision made at a properly convened meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport to invite the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to a private and informal meeting of that Committee to discuss matters of interest to committee members.

SPEECH.PARA: As we are apparently going to bore everyone stupid in this Parliament tonight, we may as well accurately go through the history of the matter. What occurred is this. Senator Macdonald proposed at a private meeting of the Committee that we seek a informal briefing from Mr David Hill. There was a deal of discussion at the Committee and it was determined by majority decision-I think by unanimous decision-that that would be a very appropriate course of action. Having done that, in accordance with a properly convened and constituted committee decision, the informal briefing was held today.

I was present as a member of that Committee. I do not normally come into the Senate chamber and wax lyrical about the affairs that take place at private committee hearings. However, as the matter has been raised and as Senator Michael Baume had a source at the meeting-normally these matters are confidential-I advise that Senator Macdonald came to the Committee meeting this afternoon and asked whether it would be appropriate for Senator Kemp to attend. There was a brief discussion. There were two Opposition senators present at the Committee hearing. There was no motion proposed by Senator Macdonald.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who were the two?
—If we must go through the history: both Senator Macdonald and Senator Panizza were present.
— I have a point of order, Mr President. I wish to put Senator Faulkner straight that I was not there when that discussion took place.
—That is not a point of order. I cannot determine who was there.

—There were two Opposition senators present at today's meeting: Senator Macdonald and Senator Panizza. At no time did either of those honourable senators or any other honourable senator who was present at the meeting move a motion in relation to who could or could not attend the meeting. However, what did occur was that the Managing Director of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Mr David Hill, generously offered, if there were a problem-because Senator Kemp had some questions to address to him-to meet him privately. He actually offered to meet him today, if it suited Senator Kemp's program. I think most people in this chamber would consider that a generous offer from a very busy person. Senator Macdonald, because he raised no further objection at the Committee, I thought accepted that as a reasonable compromise, because Senator Kemp could not be contacted as far as I know. Senator Macdonald, having attempted to contact Senator Kemp--
—This is supposed to be an accurate description and you have made a 50 per cent mistake.
—Order!
—He did contact me.
—Order!

—Senator Macdonald, having attempted to contact Senator Kemp, came back and made no further contribution to that matter at that private and informal meeting of the Transport Committee. Talk about trying to make a mountain out of a molehill on what I consider to be an absolutely minor issue. I know that Senator Baume and Senator Kemp do not have a great deal to talk about in this place. For heaven's sake: we have already wasted 40 minutes on a complete and total non-issue. There could not have been a more proper procedure by any Senate committee. It was a properly convened committee meeting that made an original decision about inviting Mr Hill. I thought, and I would hope that most of the honourable senators there would have thought, that the process and the Committee's deliberations were very worth while. The fact that Senator Kemp has an axe to grind against both Mr Hill and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation ought to be of no further interest, I would have thought, to the Senate.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I think it is important to make it clear that the policy I am supporting is the Government's policy. To suggest that I have an axe to grind is absurd.
—There is no point of order.

—I believe that we have wasted enough time tonight on this non-issue. I hope that the next time Senator Kemp or Senator Baume have a contribution to make in an adjournment debate in the Senate it will be a great deal more substantive than their absurd contributions tonight.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure: Australian Broadcasting Corporation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to be brief. I am also a member of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I supported Senator Macdonald's request for this briefing. I did not support his request for any member of the Opposition-and I take that, I would hope, to include any member of the Australian Democrats or any member of the Government-to be included in what was a private and informal briefing.

SPEECH.PARA: I really regret what has happened tonight. It is a perfect example of what the public finds so odious about the parliamentary process, when egos get in the way of important issues. I think we have to ask: what is to be gained from this little beat-up tonight?

TALK.START.PARA: —Was it unprecedented or not?

—My knowledge extends only to my experience in this place. I believe the Committee, which was examining the Very Fast Train proposal, had a private and in-camera meeting with the consortium in the course of its deliberations. I do not think it is appropriate that we use a private meeting of a committee as a format through which every Rod, Mick and Ian can hijack that committee. I think it is perfectly legitimate to have private briefings on matters which are within the portfolio area of that Committee, and certainly communications is within that portfolio area.

SPEECH.PARA: I can only suggest to Senator Kemp that he lobby within his Party to get himself elected as the representative from the Liberal Party on that Committee if he has such a passion for the area. I ask Senator Kemp, through you, Mr President: why cannot he pick up the telephone and ask Mr David Hill all of the burning questions that he wants to address every night on the adjournment debate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not keep the Senate long tonight. I did not particularly want to enter into this debate. The Chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, Senator Foreman, gave a reasoned account of how he saw the meeting and I had no objection to anything he said. Had the matter been left at what Senator Foreman said-which was accurate-there would have been no need for anyone else to speak.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not hear Senator Kemp's speech, but I read the notes of it when I came into the chamber very late in the piece. There is nothing in Senator Kemp's speech which I find offensive. But the contributions of Senator Faulkner and Senator Kernot have of course made it imperative that I do set the record straight in relation to a couple of matters.

As I understood him, Senator Faulkner suggested that I should not have gone out and told Senator Kemp what had happened in the meeting. Senator Kemp had made a request to me and I brought it, quite properly, to the attention of the Committee when it consisted of the Chairman, Senator Faulkner, Senator Kernot and myself-the same people who were there when the matter was first discussed; not a full committee meeting. There were two Australian Labor Party people and one person from the left wing of the Labor Party, the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Schacht was there.

—Senator Schacht was not there when this happened. That is the first point. At the meeting I put the request to the Chairman and the Chairman determined, for various reasons-which I accepted when the majority of three, Senator Kernot, Senator Faulkner and the Chairman, all agreed-that Senator Kemp could not come. I asked to be excused while I telephoned Senator Kemp to tell him that he was not permitted to come and to give him the reasons why.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is any breach of confidence in that I would like Senator Faulkner to enumerate it. Senator Faulkner and Senator Foreman both knew--

TALK.START.PARA: —You phoned when Mr Hill made the offer.

—Having been told by the Chairman that Senator Kemp could not attend and having requested permission to use the telephone to tell Senator Kemp that he could not attend, I cannot understand why Senator Faulkner should then suggest that I have breached some confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to make it clear to Senator Faulkner that at the time this matter was discussed, in that room, apart from officers, were the Chairman, Senator Faulkner, Senator Kernot and me. Senator Panizza was not there; neither was Senator Chapman.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were there later.

—They were there later, but not when this matter was discussed. As someone who supposedly gave an accurate record of this meeting, the honourable senator's mind is as inane as his interjections. There was also a suggestion by Senator Faulkner that I did not contact Senator Kemp. I do not know where he got that information from. I do not know whether he was eavesdropping my phone call. He did not need to eavesdrop, because it was quite open. It was done in front of him. I did contact Senator Kemp. To stand up in this chamber and say that Senator Kemp was not contacted is absolutely ridiculous. If that is the sort of effort we see from the Deputy Whip of the Australian Labor Party, we might wonder about the veracity of some of the things that happen here.

SPEECH.PARA: It is, as honourable senators have said, much ado about nothing. I simply want to end with the comment that I can see absolutely no reason why Senator Kemp could not have come along if he had a wish to speak to Mr Hill. Mr Hill certainly did not object. He offered, when the request was made, to speak to Senator Kemp. That was passed on to Senator Kemp. I spoke to Mr Hill's assistant and told him that Senator Kemp would be available tonight. However, Mr Hill said that he had an important meeting with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and he did not know whether he would have time to get back to Senator Kemp tonight. I informed Mr Hill's assistant that I was sure that Senator Kemp would be quite happy to meet him at any time.

As for the reason for Senator Kemp not being allowed at that meeting, or for Senator Bishop, Senator Baume or any other honourable senator not being allowed there, it completely escapes me. There was no great secrecy. There was no Government policy involved. There were no state secrets involved. There was nothing that would bring down the Government. It was a general chat with the chief executive officer of a very important arm of this Government. Several senators would have liked to have gone along. Why Senator Kemp could not have been invited or allowed to come in completely escapes me.

I might say that the Chairman went along with the rest of the Committee. Senator Kernot and Senator Faulkner, for some reason, seemed to have a particular fix against letting Senator Kemp in. I do not know why. It seems absolutely amazing to me that that should happen. Why it should happen completely nonpluses me. I am about to finish, but, Mr President, as you and every other senator would agree, it would have been so much simpler if the Committee had said, `If Senator Kemp wants to come along, why not let him'. We would have avoided all this. I am simply amazed at the decision. As my name had been mentioned in this debate, I wanted to ensure that the facts that had been wrongly stated were corrected.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 18 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Within the $8000 million Commonwealth Budget surplus for 1989-90, what was the domestic balance and what was the overseas balance.
(2) What was the domestic balance as a proportion of Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
(3) For the Budget year 1990-91, what is the forecast domestic balance and what is the forecast overseas balance.
(4) What is the expected percentage of GDP in 1990-91 for the domestic balance.
(5) Have the figures in (3) and (4) actually been published in the Budget papers or elsewhere.

(6) Has there been a change by the Department of the Treasury in its views on the usefulness of calculations of the domestic and overseas balances contained within forecast overall Budget results; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commonwealth Budget surplus for 1989-90 of $8,036 million reflected a domestic surplus of $10,901 million and an overseas deficit of $2,865 million.
(2) The domestic surplus of $10,901 million in 1989-90 represented 3.0 per cent of GDP.

(3) The Budget estimates for 1990-91 incorporate a domestic surplus of $10,733 million and an overseas deficit of $2,626 million. Since the release of those estimates, the forecast for the overall Budget surplus of $8,107 million in 1990-91 has been revised downwards, reflecting mainly the effect of the slowdown in domestic economic activity on Budget outlays and revenue. The decline in the overall Budget surplus can therefore be expected to be reflected, in large part, in a decline in the forecast domestic surplus. The overseas deficit, however, will also be somewhat larger than estimated at Budget-time because of higher than expected disbursements on defence and interest payments.

(4) The estimated domestic surplus of $10,733 million for 1990-91 in the Budget estimates represented 2.7 per cent of the Budget-time forecast of GDP. While the domestic surplus and the level of GDP are now expected to be lower than forecast at the time of the budget, the overall effect is expected to be a lower ratio of the domestic surplus to GDP relative to the Budget-time estimate.

(6) Less emphasis has been placed on the distinction between the domestic and overseas components of the Budget balance in recent years as greater attention has been given to the extent to which the Budget (and the public sector more generally) contributes to or draws upon aggregate domestic saving. The balance between domestic saving and investment determines the extent to which the nation is required to draw upon foreign savings and thus the size of the current account deficit. There is no reason to distinguish in this regard between the domestic and overseas components of the Budget balance, as a surplus in either would represent an addition to saving, while a deficit would represent a subtraction from saving.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 20 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What is the effect of putting gains in annual aircraft movements against the capital cost expenditure, shown in table 7.6 of the Environmental Impact Statement, for the proposed third runway at the Kingsford Smith Airport (ie. what is the cost, in capital cost terms, of additional aircraft movements gained by capital expenditure on the three options shown).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The cost of providing capacity for additional aircraft movements forecast to 2005 using expenditure projections in Table 7.6 in the Draft Environmental Impact Statement for the proposed third runway at Sydney Airport is:
(a) Proposed third runway at Sydney airport plus staged Badgerys Creek, $14,800/aircraft movement.
(b) Directed Badgerys Creek plus current programme at Sydney Airport, $20,719/aircraft movement.
(c) Active traffic management at Sydney Airport plus staged Badgerys Creek, $14,904/aircraft.

The relative cost of providing additional capacity in the long term at Sydney Airport, and at Badgerys Creek, is not meaningful in terms of aircraft movements due to the wide variation in passenger numbers carried by aircraft of different types that will be permitted to operate at both airports. The cost effectiveness of expenditure is best related to the cost in dollars per passenger to meet the forecast level of incremental demand.

Under this measurement, construction cost per passenger in 1990 dollars to provide capacity under the three options is (a) proposed third runway at Sydney Airport with staged Badgerys Creek, $99 per passenger, (b) directed Badgerys Creek plus current programme at Sydney airport, $113 per passenger, (c) active traffic management at Sydney Airport plus staged Badgerys Creek, $112 per passenger.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1991 (Hansard, page 1547) Senator Tambling asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs a question without notice about Cambodian boat people in Australia, which, inter alia, made reference to the Government consideration of the claims of these people to remain in Australia and whether this was dependent upon the negotiation of arrangements for return of the Cambodians. I undertook that if there was any further information that I could usefully provide, I would do so. The Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following additional information to the answer which I provided to Senator Tambling's question:

ANSWER.PARA: On 11 March, in a question in the Senate, Senator Tambling asked whether the assessment of the Cambodian boat people against refugee criteria was dependent upon the failure to negotiate arrangements for the return of them.

As at 30 April 1991, the status of the 224 (now 259) Cambodians is not yet resolved. Twenty-six full and final applications have now been received from members of the Melbourne group, and 16 from members of the Sydney group. Further finalised applications are still awaited for the remainder of these two groups. The Darwin group are yet to submit any applications.
I have deliberately allowed those involved time to seek all available assistance in the preparation of their applications. This has resulted in a situation where most have yet to lodge applications.
The consideration of their claims is a lengthy and complex process and I do not expect final decisions on any of the group for some time yet.
I do not want to become involved in speculation about the outcome of the decision on these claims until the decision process is complete.

It is far from clear what may emerge from this process. Those whose claims are accepted will be able to remain under the conditions provided for refugee asylum. Others whose claims fall short of refugee status but who have strong humanitarian claims may be allowed to stay. Those who do not meet the refugee criteria and who do not have other admissible claims will be required to leave.

In this context officials from my department discussed possible arrangements for return with the authorities in Phnom Penh in June 1990. These discussions resulted in a simple arrangement for return being prepared and agreed. This was reflected in an exchange of notes at an operational level by the officials involved.

The arrangements proposed closely follow normal deportation procedures that apply to all people who are required to depart Australia. The slightly novel aspect of the arrangements as discussed arose from the fact that I believed that the Government needed to ensure that normal and acceptable arrangements for return existed and would be met. This appears to be the case.The situation in Cambodia is very complex. Opportunities for people in Cambodia to emigrate are limited. There are many seeking family reunification with families in other countries including Australia. As a consequence I have instructed my department to explore the possibility of establishing arrangements for the emigration of the family of Cambodian Australians from the territory of the State of Cambodia. To this end a delegation of senior officers from my department visited Phnom Penh recently to discuss possible arrangements. These initial discussions (held over the period 2-5 April) were most useful and I am confident that effective arrangements will be established in the near future.
